content:
Posted: March 13, 2016
												Let's start with the overall setting: the game's very atmospheric. The world is finely crafted and believable and makes the player want to go exploring it further. It's designed like a TV show, and it pays homage to Twin Peaks and other mystery/thriller shows. I also liked the tongue-in-cheek humour in the Twilight Zone parodies and TV talk shows. The characters are memorable and even likeable (except Alan himself IMHO). The characters have a pretty decent voice acting, but horrible lip-syncing. Their mouths are just unnatural and gave me the creeps (purposefully uncanny valley or just inability/laziness?).The gameplay is smooth and involves a heavy use of light, which adds to the atmosphere nicely. The shadows are impressive. Unfortunately the gameplay repeats itself and you start noticing some patterns. For example, you mostly run through linear paths, fighting enemies every 2 minutes. And at the end of the path there's a calm area and you always drop down into a lower platform, so that you can't go back where you came from. This is an arena, where you have to hold out for a certain time or fight a miniboss. Or your path is suddenly blocked off by some falling debris or something and you have to find another way around. You always see it coming and it gets really tiring after a while. This is my main gripe with the game; it's repetitive.The game starts slow and picks up the pace around midway through. It kind of keeps you interested throughout, just enough to not make you want to uninstall it before finishing it. But if you're not a patient player, this game might not be worth your while. In the end, you're not missing much. I'm recommending this game for its atmospheric qualities only, the rest is a bit unrewarding. There are a few moments that I'll remember fondly, like the "rock concert" or the part where Sarah and Barry join you. The game has some frustrating moments, but it's never too difficult if you take the time to learn the mechanics.

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												This is a very enjoyable game.  It is a 3rd person shooter/horror game.  The horror elements of this game are very well done.  You are very happy when you reach a safe lighted area, which is rare versus the darkness from which your enemies are spawned.  Both shock and situational frights, really spooky and i dont scare easy...  The story is gripping and well thought through.  The voice acting and characters are superb, very rare.  Although it is a fairly linear game, to learn the secrets of the story, get accomplishments, more weapons/ammo there is some branching that can be done.   It will also increase the difficulty and reward of the game.The game on Normal difficulty is pretty challanging and Nightmare really requires skills.   The gunfights are intense and must be accomplished using as little ammo as possible.  There is no abundance of weapons, so you must be crafty to conserve.  It also has a different system of killing enemy which eliminates just spraying at them and involves constantly dodging unpredicted melee attacks.  The settings are graphically very beautiful and diverse.The draw of this game is the story....  the gameplay and settings enhance this.  Very little boring parts to this game as you never can really tell what is happening and why you are doing what you are doing... until the end.  My biggest complaint about this game would be that the controls where somewhat clunky at times, esp when trying to walk or run with precision.  It did not ruin the gameplay, it just could be better.  Also there is no levelling, skill tree or extended inventory, but that seems to fit with the game.  Your supposed to be a writer, not a soldier...  Dont work you stilll reign hell on your enemies...  Hope you enjoy this Title as much as I have.   Looking forward to more Wake games.  I would talk more about the story line, but dont want to spoil.FInal verdict 85/100 - easily worth 10-15dollars and a play through.... Alan Wake: American Nightmare is also well done but more like 70/100, also worth a play through.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												This is a spoilerfree review of an entire playthrough of the german version of the game and its bonus missions on medium difficulty, playing with mouse and keyboard.Since I said spoilerfree I'm only give some vague hints if anything when talking about the story. With which I shall also start. The story tries to be a horror story, if it was a book though it would be a really crappy book. If you start thinking about it even a little bit it becomes a swiss cheese of plotholes. Ironically in the game it is being said, that a good horror story has to be very logical and yet the parts of the game are so unlogical. Since its a game and not a book though the story gets you through the game pretty well. The story also would give room for a huge variety of enemies, but this variety isn't there. The enemies are: guy with a hammer, guy with a chainsaw, guy with an axe, guy with a knife, guy throwing knifes, guy with a pipewrench... you get the idea. Except for the guys throwing knifes they all engage in melee kombat. The kombat itself is either bad or good depeding on how lucky you are. Its one out of two scenarios: 1: Shine your light on the enemys and fire when their shield is gone. Reload while shining the light, give a headshot, turn 180 degrees kill the sneaky guy who wanted to kill you from behind, dodge the hammer of a big guy trying to crush you, get some air firing a signal pistol at him and watch him go BOOM kill the last 2 guys and walk on. OR 2: Try to dodge an attack, fail, get hit, tumble forward, get hit again, get circled, die. The controls ( I repeat, with mouse and keyboard) could really be better. Dodging is a matter of luck sometimes and since you shine your light on your enemies sometimes you have a hard time seeing where you shoot, especially since there is no crosshair and you basically shoot where you shine your lamp, but especially on long distance your lamp shines on a pretty wide area. Its not unplayable though, I only rarely died because of controls-in combat that is. There is also small sections of the game where you balance on fallen down trees or jump over small holes or whatever. You will die in at least one of those sections. The things that kills you most often in combat is actually the camera angle. It third person , but you still cant see if someone is behind you until it is to late. You also cant really hear people coming from behind you. At least my experience with the entire game was that it was insanely quiet. I actually had to put my headphones on instead of having them run at maximum volume, which is something I never had to do before in any other game. The talking is quiet even if you turn up the volume, well more quiert than the music and sound effects at least, so that I often didn't understand a word. That is not a problem though because the voice acting (again: I played the german version) is pretty bad. I find it amazing how uninterested you can be about being surrounded by guys with weapons not knowing if you will survive. Nah, Wake doesn't care. He comments on it like he would tell the weather to someone when he is extremely tired and bored.  Some of the other characters do a better job though. What I like about the game is that, even though its not an open world and you just go forward from place to place, it actually feels real. The mountains, mines, forests, villages all look convincing. And the line you walk forward on isnt as narrow as it could be. There is many a house or cave on the side where you can either get ammo or collectibles. Some of the collectibles are actually so hard to find that I would say that with a bit of effort you will find around 80 percent and without effort 60 percent, but finding all of it? Good luck with that. There is actually signs telling you more about the history of the place the game plays in and radio transmissions that tell you whats going on at the moment. Its not anything particularly interesting, but it makes the world feel more real and is of course nice for those who care a bit more about a fictional world that they are only gonna spend a couple of hours in anyway. Well a couple of hours is a bit underexxagerated, since I am not going to play the game again, as it has no replay value, just look at the time I played it and take away around 2 hours in which I just left it running while eating or something and you have the amound of time you spend on this when you dont rush, die a couple of times and actually try to get as many not so hard to find collectibles and ammo crates as possible and play the bonus missions. Speaking of which, I almost missed them. I finished the game and was like "hm since I cant press continue anymore lets see what these other buttons do before I shut off the game forever" so I pressed on "episodes" and there was the ones I had and two epidoes, that each said "special episode" and I was like "dafuq? lets give it a try" and man those missions were pretty long and pretty decent, so why hide them like this? Anyway: to the atnosphere. It never really scared me once. The things supposed to scare you are pretty cheap once you have already seen them. O there is a haystack at the end of these stairs? I wonder what is gonna happen. Focus your lamp on the wannabe jumpscare, fire the shotgun and move on after reloading. O there is a bridge that looks like its about to collapse? Dont worry, even if you spend 3 hours on it everythings ok, but as soon as you reach the end BOOM everythings gonna crash behind you. Man that was close I guess? I can't say the game didn't make me feel uneasy though, but that's about it. I also don't think the nightmare difficulty would give me the feeling of "OMG I am going to die, I better run", rather "ugh, yet another death, screw it this time i'll just run and skip all of this." As a fazit I can reccomend it though, not for the insane 28 euros it costs at full price, but I would already pick it up at 10. Its not a bad game, its actually a decent experience that will keep you occupied for more than just 4 hours.

												After having played Alan Wake on xbox360 and now on PC I can definitely recommend this game. It does a really good job at immersing the player into the dark and beautifully designed world, this is one of the most detailed and well crafted game worlds I've seen. The atmosphere, story and pacing is really well done and is probably where the game shines the most. Don't expect a horror game, this is an adventure/thriller that takes the player on a nail-biting adventure that won't be forgotten easily.The gameplay and mechanics are fun and fluid with some room for improvement for buggy running and jumping controls. Other than that, the gameplay is quite unique and fun making for some intense, interesting and horrifying moments. I've played this with both keyboard/mouse and controller. The game plays easier with keyboard/mouse since it makes aiming and camera controls easier to do. A controller is definitely not required but it does come down to preference. Definitely a game that must be played if you like Thriller/Adventure story based games with unique 3rd person gameplay.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												Simply put, Alan Wake plays like a Stephen King novel turned into a TV miniseries turned into a videogame. This is intentional by Remedy and this narrative complexity is one of the game’s strengths. Remedy has woven a very complex story into Alan Wake and that’s really half of the reason to play this game. The main story, told in episodes like a TV series, is about Alan piecing together what’s happened in his missing week while the ever-present darkness corrupts the townspeople and relentlessly pursues him. However during that missing week, Alan apparently wrote a pre-cognitive novel about the very events that are happening to him, because as you play you keep finding manuscript pages that he wrote and that describe everything that subsequently happens to him. These are a lot of fun to hunt out and collect because they explain the rather fragmented story and make you feel just as desperate and paranoid as Alan—groping in the dark for answers, desperate that the next chapter page will reveal the truth he needs.Blood and gore are so downplayed in Alan Wake as to be next to nonexistent. There are no chainsaw wielding psychopaths or bloodthirsty monsters—just the creeping darkness, and the unsettling things it does to the citizens of Bright Falls. People go missing in the woods and nobody sees this as unusual; later, when you’re lost in the woods, these missing people come after you, shrouded in oily shadows and out to gut you with whatever bladed implement they have handy.Alan is a writer, not a warrior, but he has his trusty flashlight and an assortment of small arms to beat back the Taken, as the infected townspeople are called. First you must aim Alan’s light at an enemy and boost its output to burn away the darkness, and then finish off the Taken with a few shots from your pistol or shotgun. It might sound repetitive but with multiple Taken emerging from the shadows and your flashlight dwindling, it can get pretty hectic as you juggle reloading your tiny snub-nose and popping fresh batteries into your light, all while running away from and dodging attacks. Later on you can get better lights and weapons, including flares to give you breathing room and flash bang grenades to clear an area, but ammo is usually scarce and you must balance exploration with your limited reserves.Everything in the PC version is essentially the same as the Xbox 360 version. Alan Wake is one of the best converted, least buggy PC ports I have played in a long time. The quirky characters and stark daylight sequences might temporarily pull you out of the terror, but the memories of wandering around in the woods, hounded by eldritch shadows, will haunt your nightmares for months to come.DISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

content:
Posted: March 18, 2016
												Long time horror-games fan here, action-horror especially. Have lots of games to compare Alan Wake to. And I have to say the game is just mediocre. Was OK in the beginning, but because negatives piled up with the time and it dragged on for way too long (partially because of "brilliant" idea of developers to hide story details behind collectibles, I care about stories in my games, I couldn't ignore them) I started to dislike it by the endWhat was bad:-in-game ads! Crime in any game, doubly so in horror game, which lives and dies by it's atmosphere. "On a way to finally end it all, destroy the darkness, save your wife? don't forget, this is really, really important! VERIZON!!!"-Shooting. It is tied to the story, yes, but as feature in a game, imho, it doesn't work that well. Your flashlight is like a laser sight in other games, except worse. You have to keep pointing it to the enemy, waiting till the game decides it wasted enough of your time and let's you deal damage.-Only 4 weapons - gun, shotgun (2 variants), hunting rifle and flaregun + flares and flashbang grenades, that's it-Few enemy types. Smaller dudes, bigger dudes, teleporting dudes, crows and poltergeist. Combined with limited weapons variety encounters get stale really fast and don't change in any way from beginning to the end-random encounters, like in some cheap old JRPG. About 5 (!) seconds after dealing with one group, another appears. Again and again. Combined with previous two points.. you get the picture. This got much better in second half of the game though-camera, in close areas, especially inside buildings, it really doesn't know what to do, cost me several retries-unlikable main character. Spoiled whiny diva, gets angry when he has problems with writing then gets angry at Alice for trying to help him. Also, pointing a gun at a sheriff, who just saved him, as answer for offered help? What an asshat!-story wasn't really engaging, "save the princess" with lots of talking, but nothing to make me care. And when everyone is a character in a book written by Wake, why worry if something happens to them? They aren't real anyway-Darkness as main antagonist. Just darkness, with some old woman's face, doing it's evil Darknessy things. No amount of cheap jumpscares makes it actually scary or interesting or anything but boring.-no sense of progression. Comparing with amazing Resident Evil 4 - you could chose the weapon you liked, chose what you wish to upgrade, make it yours (dat Red 9!). Here it's the same weapons all the time, with the game taking them away constantly, just because (for you to find them later casually laying around)+it looks good, night forest with trees swinging and shadows of the clouds running through. Pretty creepy+Night Springs stories were cool, until once the game tricked me showing ads instead - bye immersion!... I think that's it. Other things could be good, but left me disappointed or I got sick of them (combat) so they went to negatives.What could make it better? If Wake writes it, and it's a fiction, what stopped him to give himself some supernatural abilities maybe? He could add new ones with time, get better with old ones the more he used them. This could add new ways of dealing with enemies, and add new types of enemies with abilities to match. Why it only has to be possessed people, birds and stuff lying around, reanimated as poltergeist. Is it all "the almighty Darkness" can do?No random encounters, hell no. Enemies appear from nowhere and disappear into nothing when defeated, only to come back 5 seconds later, leaving you with a sense that they are there only to waste your time and ammunition.Also, don't start with combat 10 minutes in and then push it almost non-stop till the end - the town is beautiful (with Twin Peaks vibes), spend some time with it. game! Make Alan interact with townsfolk more, build an atmosphere. And then, gradually, with only hints and suspicions at first, go into horror mode.could add more but it's already a wall of text, nobody will read it all anyway, lolOverall, I understand why this game could be enjoyable to other people. Depends on how much the stuff I mentioned will bother you. I just couldn't ignore it all in the end. Could have been really good game, but Remedy wasted this opportunity

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												One of my favorite games of all time. It's like a Stephen King book come to life. It manages to be very scary by preying on your fear of the dark without resorting to cheap jumpscares. I definitely recommend you play it.The story is filled with suspense and mystery, it's super engaging. It's heavily inspired by Twin Peaks, so fans of the show take the time to spot some easter eggs and find some thermoses filled with some damn good coffee. The soundtrack is awesome too. The "light" combat system this game utilizes is pretty neat, and although people say it can get repetitive, I think it's fun enough that it doesn't detract from the game. This is also one of the few games where playing on a harder difficulty can make the game harder without making it needlessly frustrating.I will list a few cons, however. This version is a console port, and this really really shows on older end machines. Luckily, most PCs today should be able to play it no problem. I can run it on highest settings at 60FPS on my GTX670 no problem, but the game doesn't visually seem like it would require as advanced a GPU as it actually does. The aiming and walking may also seem a bit wonky, but that's also a consequence of it being a console port.Overall rating: 9.5/10. I absolutely love everything about this game, but I gotta take half a point off for the issues stemming from it being a console port.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												One of the games that, sadly, didn't get the recognition that it should have got, because it manages to get you immersed in a truly astonishing world with its atmosphere (one of the main features of the game's engine), sound design ( with such a soundtrack that words cannot express! ), believable characters (professionally played by each one of the voice actors) and beautiful scenery. And of course, all of this is driven by a unique story inspired by Stephen King, a mastermind of horror books, which is the main interest of the game. Even though all of the aforementioned parts of the game are very well done, it has a few annoyances, like the gameplay itself. It isn't bad at all, but it isn't something special either, like the developers wanted you to believe, and once you get used to the idea of how it works, it can become just a little boring at the 4th episode or so. Don't get me wrong, it isn't bad in a way that it will distract you from the game - not at all! You won't even think about it because you will be too occupied to pay attention to actual important stuff – I promise you: it will be totally worth it! As a conclusion, I would certainly pay the full price for such an experience because I consider this game to be one of the best games ever made and I will happily recommend this game to anyone looking for an amazing and unique adventure. Be sure to play this game with headphones and no light in your room to be fully immersed! Also, please, please, please, and I beg you: after you finish the game, play its two DLCs (The Signal and The Writer) because they are the true end of the game - they are include for free in the Steam version of the game.  Otherwise, you will remain with a bitter taste regarding the game's base game ending - a bad decision on behalf of the developers, but I'm glad that they continued the story with these two DLCs to fix this "problem".

												9.5 / 10BLUF: Fantastic story brought to life with great graphics and excellent gameplay.  Highly enjoyable throughout.I finally beat this game today after purchasing it four years ago for $7 on Steam.  You can really see that Remedy put a lot into the game.  The graphics are excellent, the gameplay is fun and exciting, and Remedy does a really fantastic job at bringing the story to life.The game does get progressively more difficult, and you will die a lot in the later levels, but it never has you pulling your hair out or tossing the controller.  Speaking of later levels, the final few chapters and the two DLCs have some really incredible set pieces and nightmare-invoking level designs.The environments are dark and eerie, and are augmented by really excellent sound effects and music.  The game is dark but it doesn't ever get Silent Hill dark.  The flashlight exploration and occasional jump scares do provide a good sense of dread, and the game can be quite scary if played alone at night.My only complaints: Seemingly pointless collectibles.  The in-game collectibles don't unlock any extras or special items or anything.  They pretty much only tell you that you've explored every nook and cranny of each level.The cliffhanger ending!  Unless Remedy makes a sequel, Alan Wake's story may never have a proper ending

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												I'll make this quick, Alan Wake is not an easy game to play and it does have a few things that can frustrate the player but the story here reminds you of Silent Hill. It's not a Silent Hill clone per se, but a fresh take of the horror genre even though there's not much horror here.Gameplay:Enemies here are called the Taken. They are essentially human beings that have been taken over by the darkness. Unfortunately, they are practically invincible. You can't kill them with gunshots if they still have darkness within them. Here you will quickly learn that your worst enemy is your flashlight. To kill the Taken you have to shine your light at them making them vulnerable to gunshots. However, if you run out of batteries (which will happen often even on the normal setting) you are almost guaranteed to die. The dodging mechanic doesn't really help you much because as soon as the enemy hits you, you are unable to do anything. They pretty much stun you into submission and this will happen a lot when the game decides to throw groups of Taken at you. There are tools that can help you evade these groups such as the flares, flare gun and the flashbangs. These are uncommon but very useful items. The game forces you to create a tactic in which you decide whether you want to run or fight. This game is definitely not easy and during my playthrough (on normal, which is the hard mode of this game) I died at least 7-10 times.Graphics:The graphics here are nothing special but the scenery and the mountains will take your breathe away. Remedy has put a lot of attention to detail in the way they create this world and the little town of Bright Falls, and even to the surreal world of the Dark Place. The characters you encounter have their own set of personalities which sets them apart from any other characters. They aren't just NPC's here, they actually feel alive. More often than not, they will actually help you survive groups of Taken in some Episodes. Let me tell you that they don't miss!Controls:The controls feel stiff and that really doesn't help in surviving the night. As I said before dodging kind of sucks as Alan will only take two steps the the direction you want to dodge and if you don't time it right, the enemy will hit you. In fact its better to fight from a distance. Stay away from large groups! There is no reticle for aiming so you will miss a couple of shots. This isn't a first person shooter and therefore you can't look down the barrel of the gun. Running also can kill you if you run out of breathe. No stamina means that Alan will walk slower and aim his flashlight much slower. Another thing too is that running is pointless since the Taken can run much faster than you. Unless you are standing 5 feet from the next checkpoint, running away is near impossible. Overall: Did I say I was gonna make this quick? Ooops....Alan Wake is not for everyone. It is definitely not an easy game to beat and the controls don't help it much. It is clear that Remedy has put a lot of thought into the mechanics of the game but I felt like I was being hindered which in this case as a survival horror game it did well to keep me on my toes. Every death felt cheap but not cheap enough to get me to rage quit. Eventually I understood why I died and I grew to like this game even more. Now the story portion is what attracts everyone to this game and I'm glad to say that it did not disappoint. Alan Wake is an episodic adventure and it was meant to be treated as such. If you like a good challenge and a good story, then this is the game for you. However, that being said expect a lot of deaths and instances of frustration!                                    -7/10

Posted: December 13, 2013
												This is a terrific game. The real kickers of it are the story and the atmosphere. The story involves a writer named Alan Wake who goes on a search for his missing wife, Alice. But is he really searching for her or is there something bigger, more devastating going on here? The atmosphere envelopes the player in moody darkness as Alan traverses the great outdoors and fights his way past the possessed dark known as the Taken. The gameplay can get quite repetitive, but different segments diversify it up (such as surviving an assault with loads of ammo and batteries for your precious flashlight). Light is the key in this game, as the player must make his way to each lampost emitting light which is always another checkpoint. Some may find this repetitive as well, but I was always relieved to get to the next one as many of my resources (my batteries and ammo) were quite exhausted. I played the game on normal and while there were some moments that inflicted great frustrations, all in all it was a great experience. It is a survival horror game, and while it is not as scary as Silent Hill or Amnesia, it definitely gives you moments of panic and/or fright. For me, these moments typically came because Alan can not run fast for too long as he gets tired and slows down. This can prove to be frustrating if you are being chased by too many Taken (as I was on many an occasion), but I believe it was purposely done this way, else the game would be too easy if Alan could just run faster than the Taken to each checkpoint and never have to stop, turn around, flash and kill as many Taken as possible, and go back to running. Overall, I had an enjoyable experience with this game. I would recommend that everyone who plays it, also play the 2 Special DLC chapters upon completion of the base story. This will provide closure upon finishing the two specials, or at least more closure than the ending of Alan Wake by itself.8/10

Posted: February 19
												Alan Wake is a good test of how important you find gameplay in video games. Essentially, Alan Wake is a cool episodicallly presented story about a man doing everything he can to find his spouse. It's strong narratively, and the presenation of rural northwestern America is pretty spot on. Voice acting is good, and by the end of the story you'll be wanting to jump on the DLC for the next chapter just to see where it goes.Unfortunately, Alan Wake has serious issues in terms of gameplay. Don't get me wrong; it works , it's just that you essentially do the same sort of survival gameplay (stop the darkness by blinding it with light) through the whole game. The game's combat sequences are almost all the same, with nearly identical enemies defeated in identical ways. It's a solidly long game too; my game time as of this review (~15 hours) is the equivalent of one playthrough.In other words, Alan Wake is extremely repetitive. This is why it's a good test of how much you really care for a game's narrative. If you love strong stories in video games and are fine with repetitive gameplay, this will be a blast. If you came here looking for invigorating gameplay, it isn't happening.In short, I can't recommend this game if you can't handle repetitive gameplay. If you can, then buy this game. It's a great story everyone deserves to see.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2014
												I'll make this quick, Alan Wake is not an easy game to play and it does have a few things that can frustrate the player but the story here reminds you of Silent Hill. It's not a Silent Hill clone per se, but a fresh take of the horror genre even though there's not much horror here.Gameplay:Enemies here are called the Taken. They are essentially human beings that have been taken over by the darkness. Unfortunately, they are practically invincible. You can't kill them with gunshots if they still have darkness within them. Here you will quickly learn that your worst enemy is your flashlight. To kill the Taken you have to shine your light at them making them vulnerable to gunshots. However, if you run out of batteries (which will happen often even on the normal setting) you are almost guaranteed to die. The dodging mechanic doesn't really help you much because as soon as the enemy hits you, you are unable to do anything. They pretty much stun you into submission and this will happen a lot when the game decides to throw groups of Taken at you. There are tools that can help you evade these groups such as the flares, flare gun and the flashbangs. These are uncommon but very useful items. The game forces you to create a tactic in which you decide whether you want to run or fight. This game is definitely not easy and during my playthrough (on normal, which is the hard mode of this game) I died at least 7-10 times.Graphics:The graphics here are nothing special but the scenery and the mountains will take your breathe away. Remedy has put a lot of attention to detail in the way they create this world and the little town of Bright Falls, and even to the surreal world of the Dark Place. The characters you encounter have their own set of personalities which sets them apart from any other characters. They aren't just NPC's here, they actually feel alive. More often than not, they will actually help you survive groups of Taken in some Episodes. Let me tell you that they don't miss!Controls:The controls feel stiff and that really doesn't help in surviving the night. As I said before dodging kind of sucks as Alan will only take two steps the the direction you want to dodge and if you don't time it right, the enemy will hit you. In fact its better to fight from a distance. Stay away from large groups! There is no reticle for aiming so you will miss a couple of shots. This isn't a first person shooter and therefore you can't look down the barrel of the gun. Running also can kill you if you run out of breathe. No stamina means that Alan will walk slower and aim his flashlight much slower. Another thing too is that running is pointless since the Taken can run much faster than you. Unless you are standing 5 feet from the next checkpoint, running away is near impossible. Overall: Did I say I was gonna make this quick? Ooops....Alan Wake is not for everyone. It is definitely not an easy game to beat and the controls don't help it much. It is clear that Remedy has put a lot of thought into the mechanics of the game but I felt like I was being hindered which in this case as a survival horror game it did well to keep me on my toes. Every death felt cheap but not cheap enough to get me to rage quit. Eventually I understood why I died and I grew to like this game even more. Now the story portion is what attracts everyone to this game and I'm glad to say that it did not disappoint. Alan Wake is an episodic adventure and it was meant to be treated as such. If you like a good challenge and a good story, then this is the game for you. However, that being said expect a lot of deaths and instances of frustration!                                    -7/10

content:
Posted: April 26
												TL;DR: 8.75/10, great combat, dorky dialogue, fun setting, food for thought.As a non-horror fan, my first impressions when I played back in 2013 were not so good: combat can be a bit wonky at first, and the main character is a famous author but his writing is absolutely atrocious (e.g. he uses the phrase "a gruesome slushie" to describe blood on snow). But to be honest, a big part of my problem was that the game was simply too hard. I was constantly being overwhelmed by waves of axe-wielding enemies and eventually just quit.Well, I'm better at games now and understand a few things that I didn't before-- all things that this game relies on heavily. First of all, resource management. In many segments, the game gives you barely enough ammo to get through, if that, so you have to ration it out carefully. (Sometimes you are also just better off running away from a fight, which is not an approach I'm used to in other games I've played.)Second, visual and especially audio feedback. Alan Wake really shines with this aspect. There is no minimap, and enemies don't have obvious health meters and such, but you always know what's coming up and what state the enemies are in ("armor" and health) based on the visual and sound design. The evil growls, the ringing blades and the thumping sledgehammers are damn frightening too-- but the powerful sounds of your own weapons give you a strong feeling of fighting back effectively. Actually the best past is the use of flashlights, flare guns and the like to weaken enemies so that guns will actually hurt them-- it takes a  while sometimes, but you can see and hear how the bad guys suffer under the light. All in all, a really solid and immersive combat experience. Bloody (!) difficult at times, but great stuff.The story is an enjoyable mishmash of Twin Peaks and Stephen King: crazy convoluted and sometimes a bit excessively quirky (yes, it has its equivalent of the Log Lady), but ultimately a fun ride. Some aspects even stuck with me for quite a while, like the "who's writing whom?" aspect of the overall plot. And then there's the Anderson farm, which edges out the Konstantin Brayko fight in Alpha Protocol as the greatest rock-themed 3rd-person set piece in video game history. Respect.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
Alan Wake: a unique, horror themed casual-action game.Alan Wake is a self-aware, chapter based, mainly combat-driven action game that anyone could get into. Personally I recommend that you play on easy, because if there is one downside to the game, it's that the combat system wears you down after the whole experience. There's also a difficulty spike right at the mine, but it's not too bad. The game isn't scary, but does have a light v. dark sort of theme.It's also kid-friendly, for the most part.Alan Wake's story reminds me of a Steven King novel (Wake himself makes the comparison). A writer comes to an old small-town cabin to get away from the fame and fortune. He runs into some issues, and his wife (who fears the dark) is captured by some darkness-something-or-another. It's pretty cool and non-complex, but mysterious enough to remain intriguing. The entire game is narrated by Alan Wake, in the form of a novel, while you traverse the dark countryside.Combat is simple. Fight the nightmare-men by getting rid of their (as I call them) "darkness shields" then shooting them. Their darkness shields are shown by a circle of lense flare when you aim your flashlight at them. Shoot them with either the revolver or shotgun to kill them. Alternatively, flare guns do both simultaneously. Flares and flashbangs clear crowds.Fight men from your dreams (and people you have met) through a story with cool bits of radio and TV clips.The story is good, but unfortunately to prevent the game from being a 5 hour experience, there's a lot of repetitive combat. Some people really like it, but in my opinion it could have been a bit shorter.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												I suppose I'll start this review off by saying I really didn't want to reccommend this game, but because I "sort of enjoyed it enough to play it twice I guess", then I shall. It's an impressive game, but this is going to be a very critical review. I find people get more out of a review if it states somethings faults rather than its values, so that is what I will do here.In this game you play as Alan Wake, an acclaimed but troubled writer who hasn't written a word in years, who is brought to the remote town of Bright Falls by his wife in the hope that he can find some inspiration for writing. This all goes disastrously wrong and results in Alan trying to save his wife from a dark evil presence. (hoorah)The story is clearly the winning point of the game, I mean it's kinda hard to avoid when your main character is a writer. Theres little bumps and bits that spark a lot of questions along the way, but it's always interesting enough to keep your fullest attention and wanting to find out whats next.The problem with this game is the lack of balance between the excitement of the story compared with the gameplay. The majority of the game pans out like this-1. Oh look its a really cool story, I want to know more2. Oh dear...looks like I have to walk around a forest for an hour shooting things until I'm given the next part of the story.3. Wash rinse repeatI would have no problem with this method, a lot of games do it well. But this game just butchers it.The gameplay consists of shining a light at enemies, and shooting them. It's an interesting concept, but becomes boring after a while, and by the time midgame comes you're only shooting things to find out what happens next. It becomes a chore, and just no fun. It's as if a writer who knew nothing about videogames wanted to make a videogame, that's the kind of vibe I get from this.Another note I have to make about this game is the difficulty. When you load the game, you're given the options of easy, normal and nightmare. Wanting to play the game as it should be, I play on normal for two playthroughs. I didn't find it difficult, I found it frustrating. Deaths were always unfair, you were punished for exploring, and in the early game ammo was often non existent in certain areas of a level. Combine this with the fact that this is a story driven game, it doesn't pile up to much fun. After my troubles, I looked online to see if others had similar problems as me and I came across something that triggered a facepalm.The difficulty levels on consoles and pc are labeled differently. On the console, the difficulties are labeled normal, hard, and nightmare, where as on the pc they are labeled easy, normal, and nightmare respectively. Keep in mind that they are the same difficulty, simply labeled different. This means that when I was playing what I thought was normal mode, it was actually set to hard. I even got the "complete in hard mode" achievement on steam. Whether this was deliberate or a mistake, either way it should be made more clear to anyone playing the game. Still, for a hard mode it wasn't fun, it was just frustrating. I'd hate to think what nightmare would be like.Like I said at the top of this review, this is a good game, but I was going to critical, and I have been. It runs amazing, it looks amazing, it has an amazing story, let down by less than amazing gameplay and truly faulty mechanics.This game is constantly on sale for 90% off, that's 2.99 euros. When that time comes, buy it if you so wish. If not, leave it.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
												SPOILER FREE. You're running through the forest- gasping for air, a revolver in your left hand, flashlight in the right,  low on ammunition and batteries, with enemies behind you, too many- swarming, coming closer. You won't get far. You narrowly dodge an axe swing, only to have to keep running- not being able to stop and catch your breath-Then you see it.Your safe haven. The one true friend in this cold, desolate and horrifying region. The one thing that can save you from the monsters that chase behind you.You step in- into the light. You catch your breath, and look up at the lamp above you, sighing. Knowing you cannot stay inside this heaven. You keep going.. until it's over. Until the light comes. And your story continues. Until it cannot continue anymore. You're on a crazy rollercoaster, with many twists, turns, and drops. But eventually it ends. It all ends, and the light consumes the dark. Contrast.Alan wake is definitely an intriguing game- concepts I haven't seen much of, though I've been told by one friend the light/darkness system is reminiscent of ''Alone in the Dark.''The combat system is like this- you have a flashlight which destroys the darkness surrounding the ''Taken.'' The monsters in this game. You are then able to shoot them, after first destroying this games concept of a shield. The weapons in this game are powerful- enough to take out the enemies, sure. However, sometimes you get (no pun intended) taken over by the enemy. And your only choice is to run into the light. Your choice of weapons in this game are as followed as found during the storyline: Revolver, Shotgun, Pump Action Shotgun, Hunting Rifle, Flare gun.My preference for using these weapons were this- if I had to take care of the Flankers, (the ones with a sickle, or axe, that attack rapidly) I'd use the Revolver primarily, considering, if you shine the flashlight on them and then shoot them with the Revolver they usually die with one bullet. For the Common Taken, if I got overrun I'd use a flare and drop it to give myself room, and shoot them with the shotgun. But the revolver still was my primary.For the Tele-taken, (the ones that teleport) I would stand, and wait for them to lunge towards me, quickly turn to them, and shine the flashlight on them until their darkness was gone, and then shotgun blast them. For the Assault Taken, (the ones with the chainsaws) I would either run, use a flashbang to help lower their shield then take them out, or flares. The Ravens that attack, I would just shoot the swarm with flares, and they would dissipate, but you also can use the various flashlights throughout the game to take them.This game also has Poltergeists, which I recommend running from because they have the ability to throw objects at you- whether it be a tree, a car, or anything of the sorts. But if you want to stay on the offensive, use the flares to give you some room, and shine the light on the objects and they will disappear. There is also liquid Taken, which looks like black goo, and if you step it, it instantly takes damage. Shine your flashlight on it, and they'll be gone. Just look out, however for it. At one point when in the forest, there are also bear traps, and if you're not careful your own book will become your demise.There's many different flashlights in this game- and the better the flashlight, the more you'll have to be careful about how many batteries you use. Along with ammunition, you should do your best to conserve. However, the good thing is that ammunition and batteries and all of those commodities aren't scarce- but in the heat of combat, you DO NOT want to run out of resources.The storyline goes like this- you are Alan Wake. Horror novelist. You haven't been able to write a book in 2 years because of writer's block. Your  friend, and agent Barry Wheeler has suggested you take a vacation to clear your mind. And your wife Alice has arranged for it. You're going to Washington State, into the town of Brightfalls. You arrive at the cabin, and your wife tells you that she arranged for the trip to try and help you get over your inability to write. You storm out, and then look back at your cabin to see that your wife is being taken into the lake by a mysterious force- in this game, your main objective is to save your wife, rewrite the story, and defend your friends and yourself against 'The Darkness.' (I'm not spoiling anything, that's the main few points though.) You'll travel through the mountains, near the lake, over logs on a river, into desolate and empty towns filled with darkness waiting for you, a gas station- many MANY locales all in this one region.The storyline is beautifully written in my opinion- it's sublime, the pacing is good- you do sometimes get the feeling of Deja Vu when the game does something over- or you see something play out in a different way. There are lots of twists, and honestly, a lot of it is nonsensical, however, it is poetic, the dialogue is well written and funny- there are light tones with the characters speaking, such as your Agent Barry joking around, to help contrast the threat you're up against. There are dark parts of the dialogue, bright, and humorous, it's very diverse, in a well thought out and intriguing way that makes you keep coming back for more. There also are manuscripts you'll find yourself collecting throughout the storyline- they're enjoyable to collect, because they tell you how a character feels, what comes next, or valuable storyline information, and Alan's thoughts. Keep in mind, all of the manuscripts in this game are read by the character of Alan Wake. The soundtrack to this game is beautifully- fitting, and haunting in certain parts of the storyline. Definitely one of my favorite soundtracks for a game. At one point, you also have a song incorporated into the game by a record player, that tells you a certain thing you have to do. The graphics to this game also looked very pretty, and serene and induced shivers at some points in it. Having it foggy- and a tele-taken teleporting around you and you can't see where they are is definitely a thrilling and slightly chilling experience. The facial animations are lacking in certain spots, such as Alan's eyebrows. But, I thought overall the graphics did this game well. I felt the atmosphere, felt like I lived it, and it made the game that much more successful for me. The negative I can think of- is that over the time I spent beating this game, the combat gets very repetitive, and the running sequences and certain assault sections. I had to take breaks to get through it, albeit short breaks. Also, because of the dark and light and the various shadows, I found, if you over play it like I did, you can actually get a headache. However, that's probably just me. Another negative is that I thought that there isn't much characterization- from the start to beginning, I didn't think Alan grew too much as a character. And pretty much every character seemed stagnant. That isn't to say this game isn't beautifully haunting, with it's atmosphere, storyline and twists and turns. This game is great, and one of my favorites as of right now. If you're looking for a storyline driven game, with Stephen King esque horror elements, go for it. The combat can be repetitive, but it is fun nonetheless. The characters are good, the different enviroments are diverse, and eerie, and at the same time beautiful.Overall an enjoyable experience, I'd definitely buy it again. Over and out.(Hope you enjoyed my review)

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												There are very few games that I go back and replay immediately after finishing them, but Alan Wake is such a game. This is the survival horror genre done impeccably well and worth every cent of it's asking price.RIGHT: Alan Wake is a story driven horror game shot over the shoulder, RE4 style. And though the plot is very twisting, it's not difficult to follow or over laden with cut scenes. It takes great pains to stay true to it's own world, with the protagonist saddled with all the gifts and foibles a middle aged author would have battling the supernatural. The characters are engaging and well developed, with only one exception that I will discuss later. Combat is not only well executed but also ingenious, making a flashlight your primary means of defense, with any fire arms becoming secondary. Alan's aim is imperfect but realistic and not burdensome, adding to the air of horror as you are only as good as a man who was suddenly thrust into extraneous circumstance. Controls are fluid and well plotted for both keyboard and Xbox game pad. Though the game has a climb function, the detection is perfectly controlled so you wont be grabbing every ledge you bump into. You can also fall and take damage, but again the game is so well plotted out that you almost have to be purposely trying to harm yourself for it to be an issue. The overall design of this game is such that it creates a mood, aiding the story elements and hammering home the "light vs dark" theme and just immerses you into Alan's rapidly disintegrating world.  Even the “Night Springs” and late night radio bits are done so well, you don't mind taking a small break from game play to watch and listen.WRONG: I really have only one complaint about this game, and it revolves around Alan's wife. Where every character in this game is perfectly sculpted for their role, even if you only see them for mere moments, Alan's wife who is the motivation behind the protagonist’s progression in the plot, is incredibly vapid and pointless! I mean this woman is beyond insufferable, her character is so completely empty and uninteresting, I could almost believe she is based on a real person rather than written for the purpose of a game. When she isn't whimpering about being afraid of the dark, she's badgering the man that obviously supports her floundering liberal arts carrier and even goes so far as to check Alan into a mental institution when it looks like he wont be providing her with a fat pay cheque from his writing anymore. She's monosyllabic and completely vanilla to the point I think even the voice actress realizes it and phones in her performance. I completed the game yesterday, and as of this moment I can't even tell you her name because she is so uninteresting I've already forgotten it. Lucy? Lisa? Lara? Who cares... Anyway, Alan is confronted at every turn in this story by what a horrid ♥♥♥♥♥ he's married, but somehow comes to the conclusion that he's to blame by being more successful than she is! So obviously the only was to fix this is to save her from the darkness and maybe he can be worthy enough to coexist with probably one of the most worthless women on the planet. In all seriousness, Alan's wife is pure plot device and nothing else, though I am at a loss as to see why they chose to make the only undeveloped character, such a major part of the story and motivation. Was an elder creature trying to control Alan's creative ability to write itself into existence and destroy reality, not enough motivation for him to go on this journey?Well, that being said, Alan Wake is still one of the best if not THE best survival horror game I have played. It does everything right, and has enough of a difficulty curve to make you want to go back and try playing it again on more challenging settings.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												What started off as an impulse purchase became (without exaggeration) one of the most amazing gaming experiences in my life. Alan Wake is an outstanding game that mixes elements of psychological horror, thriller and and dark fantasy. Bright Falls are a perfect setting for the story of a dark, somewhat magical, entity going after the protagonist. It also features a lot of meta-elements (like the manuscript pages the protagonist finds scattered throughout the game, which give us insight into the plot and, in some cases, the events that are about to occur or which we do not see on-screen).As for the gaming aspect: although some might find the combat monotonous, I personally always get the cold shiver each time Alan steps into a secluded part of the forest that's bound to hide malavolent lurkers. The limited amunnition and the character's poor stamina add an extra spice to the gameplay, but the developers made sure that you are able to get to the next chekpoint even with no bullets left in the barrel (alhough it's much harder). The fights are not quite scary nor horror, as the game even hints that there are enemies inbound, but is definitely adrenaline packed and fun.The story is well-crafted, and the narration helps bring it to life. The entire plot is a huge nod to Stephen King and a myriad of other contemporary horror writers. There are a lot of references to "The Shining," "The Twilight Zone" "The Birds," "Poltergeist" and "Lost" scattered throughout the game. The dialogues are neither superficial nor superflous, and I used to spen an extra minute or two to hear out some of the characters (who sometimes provided a crutial hint for the later story development). The division into episodes, the different songs at the end of each stage and the "Previously on Alan Wake" cutscenes help make Alan Wake feel like a TV show you don't want to miss at any cost, so you keep coming back for more.To conclude, I beleive that this game is definitely worth both your time and your money. content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												What started off as an impulse purchase became (without exaggeration) one of the most amazing gaming experiences in my life. Alan Wake is an outstanding game that mixes elements of psychological horror, thriller and and dark fantasy. Bright Falls are a perfect setting for the story of a dark, somewhat magical, entity going after the protagonist. It also features a lot of meta-elements (like the manuscript pages the protagonist finds scattered throughout the game, which give us insight into the plot and, in some cases, the events that are about to occur or which we do not see on-screen).As for the gaming aspect: although some might find the combat monotonous, I personally always get the cold shiver each time Alan steps into a secluded part of the forest that's bound to hide malavolent lurkers. The limited amunnition and the character's poor stamina add an extra spice to the gameplay, but the developers made sure that you are able to get to the next chekpoint even with no bullets left in the barrel (alhough it's much harder). The fights are not quite scary nor horror, as the game even hints that there are enemies inbound, but is definitely adrenaline packed and fun.The story is well-crafted, and the narration helps bring it to life. The entire plot is a huge nod to Stephen King and a myriad of other contemporary horror writers. There are a lot of references to "The Shining," "The Twilight Zone" "The Birds," "Poltergeist" and "Lost" scattered throughout the game. The dialogues are neither superficial nor superflous, and I used to spen an extra minute or two to hear out some of the characters (who sometimes provided a crutial hint for the later story development). The division into episodes, the different songs at the end of each stage and the "Previously on Alan Wake" cutscenes help make Alan Wake feel like a TV show you don't want to miss at any cost, so you keep coming back for more.To conclude, I beleive that this game is definitely worth both your time and your money. It's fun and has a lot of replay value, especially when you have the commentary feature that comes with the collectors edition. Recommended!

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Stephen King once wrote that “Nightmares exist outside of logic, and there’s little fun to be had in explanations; they’re antithetical to the poetry of fear.”Alan Wake, a survival horror game developed by Remedy Entertainment and published by Microsoft Game Studios. You are Alan Wake a best selling thriller novelist trapped in a horror story he wrote which has to come to life and has taken his wife. The game is heavily inspired by thriller which draws concepts from the T.V show Twin Peaks and draws inspiration from the works of Stephen King! As Alan Wake you must battle through the night to fight the Taken, a darkness that takes over living things and brings life to inanimate objects while trying to find yourself and your wife, which the darkness has taken. Gameplay is in third person and the primary weapon used in the game is light (Flashlight, Flares, flareguns, environmental lighting, flashbangs) as well as guns.  Fighting through lush green national parks and into the town of Bright Falls, Washington the atmosphere psychologically engulfs you, waking up from this nightmare is not an option!Pros:-The use of light as a weapon-A great story, short but sweet will really leave you with a "Wow, amazing!"-The atmosphere although intense is also distrubing and horrifying-Narration really makes it easy to understand whats really going on.-Truly is a great looking game, feels like you're really in a national park XD-Highly replayabe, played through about 4 times-Combat mechanics make you feel like your are constantly in danger-Stephen king, Stephen king, Stephen king, Stephen king!Cons:-Weak ending-The game was a little short but there are DLC as well as American Nightmare.-Facial animations could've been done better-The recaps at the end of each chapter aren't necessary, it does feel like its trying to be a T.V showBut all in all a solid and rich game full of awesome, 10 foxes out 10 foxes, put de lime in de coconut!

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												There are very few games that I go back and replay immediately after finishing them, but Alan Wake is such a game. This is the survival horror genre done impeccably well and worth every cent of it's asking price.RIGHT: Alan Wake is a story driven horror game shot over the shoulder, RE4 style. And though the plot is very twisting, it's not difficult to follow or over laden with cut scenes. It takes great pains to stay true to it's own world, with the protagonist saddled with all the gifts and foibles a middle aged author would have battling the supernatural. The characters are engaging and well developed, with only one exception that I will discuss later. Combat is not only well executed but also ingenious, making a flashlight your primary means of defense, with any fire arms becoming secondary. Alan's aim is imperfect but realistic and not burdensome, adding to the air of horror as you are only as good as a man who was suddenly thrust into extraneous circumstance. Controls are fluid and well plotted for both keyboard and Xbox game pad. Though the game has a climb function, the detection is perfectly controlled so you wont be grabbing every ledge you bump into. You can also fall and take damage, but again the game is so well plotted out that you almost have to be purposely trying to harm yourself for it to be an issue. The overall design of this game is such that it creates a mood, aiding the story elements and hammering home the "light vs dark" theme and just immerses you into Alan's rapidly disintegrating world.  Even the “Night Springs” and late night radio bits are done so well, you don't mind taking a small break from game play to watch and listen.WRONG: I really have only one complaint about this game, and it revolves around Alan's wife. Where every character in this game is perfectly sculpted for their role, even if you only see them for mere moments, Alan's wife who is the motivation behind the protagonist’s progression in the plot, is incredibly vapid and pointless! I mean this woman is beyond insufferable, her character is so completely empty and uninteresting, I could almost believe she is based on a real person rather than written for the purpose of a game. When she isn't whimpering about being afraid of the dark, she's badgering the man that obviously supports her floundering liberal arts carrier and even goes so far as to check Alan into a mental institution when it looks like he wont be providing her with a fat pay cheque from his writing anymore. She's monosyllabic and completely vanilla to the point I think even the voice actress realizes it and phones in her performance. I completed the game yesterday, and as of this moment I can't even tell you her name because she is so uninteresting I've already forgotten it. Lucy? Lisa? Lara? Who cares... Anyway, Alan is confronted at every turn in this story by what a horrid ♥♥♥♥♥ he's married, but somehow comes to the conclusion that he's to blame by being more successful than she is! So obviously the only was to fix this is to save her from the darkness and maybe he can be worthy enough to coexist with probably one of the most worthless women on the planet. In all seriousness, Alan's wife is pure plot device and nothing else, though I am at a loss as to see why they chose to make the only undeveloped character, such a major part of the story and motivation. Was an elder creature trying to control Alan's creative ability to write itself into existence and destroy reality, not enough motivation for him to go on this journey?Well, that being said, Alan Wake is still one of the best if not THE best survival horror game I have played. It does everything right, and has enough of a difficulty curve to make you want to go back and try playing it again on more challenging settings.

content:

A Paladin's Review: Alan Wake. Thrills and Dark Chills in this Darkness VS Light Story.Genre: Third Person Psychological Horror Thriller Shooter. Developed and Published by: Remedy Entertainment (on PC). Platform: Windows and Xbox 360. Business Model: Base Game.Copy purchased by myself in a Humble Bundle.Read the full & unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]Overall Gameplay ThoughtsAlan Wake plays out like a television series or interactive book with six episodes and two special chapters afterwards. A linear story with the writer Alan Wake trying to battle the forces of darkness that have sprung up in a small town while trying to find out what happened to his wife, Alice Wake. If you’re thinking this might be a survival horror game, no, it’s definitely not. AW is more focused on the action and gunplay than it is about surviving things that are trying to scare you to death. It’s a game that works to build up the tension in the player as he/she experiences the weirdness going on. There are some jump scares but I think they rely more on you being tense than trying to break your speakers with a loud noise. In that, Alan Wake is very effective. I often jumped when getting attacked by an enemy to the side and the constant creeping atmosphere keeps you on edge. Especially when they combine that with visuals which make liberal use of shadows and visual warping to distort what you’re seeing as well as limiting the amount of ammunition Alan Wake will be able to find. Nothing is quite so horrifying as running out of bullets and still be surrounded by enemies. I’m not into the horror genre but I do really enjoy thrillers that work to build tension. Alan Wake is one such thriller that’s very memorable and one of my favorites. Story ThoughtsBestselling book author Alan Wake is taking a vacation with his wife to the fictional town of Bright Falls to get away from the pressures at home. Ever since he published his last book, Alan has had a severe writer’s block that’s prevented him from doing any writing for the past couple of years. Subsequently putting a strain on his relationship with his wife, friends and publisher. His hope is that the vacation will help reinvigorate him to write again. But not all is as it seems at Bright Falls. Alice Wake, his wife, disappears. Alan is suspected of foul play. He sets out to figure out what happened to his wife, to discover what darkness is lurking at Bright Falls and fight it. Along the way, Alan realizes just how much of that darkness he’s been carrying inside himself. Of course, he can’t fight it alone so he enlists on his friend Barry who shows up when all the craziness goes down. I don’t feel like spoiling Alan Wake so I’ll just end the explanation of the story here. Suffice it to say though, it’s well paced and keeps a good balance of lightheartedness and dark themes. Light, Darkness and Gunplay MechanicsTo defeat enemies, you simply need to shine enough light on enemies to clear the darkness off of them and then shoot them until they disappear. However, those enemies aren’t simply going to stand around and let you do that. The amount of darkness that surrounds enemies will depend on the type you’re facing. Enemies are shadowy figures that take on a human look, often times looking like firefighters or loggers. While they look human, they aren’t. There’s the usual grunts that will attack you with melee weapons, others that will throw axes at your face and more that have a lot more health or speed. Luckily for the player, none of them have guns. (As the game explains it, it’s because the darkness can’t properly handle complex weapons). There’s a couple of other enemies including birds that swoop on him and environmental objects that get thrown about. There’s also some disturbing boss fights and big arena fights that Alan will need to survive through. For the most part, it’s enough variety to keep the gunplay interesting though I do feel towards the end it starts to lose steam. The AI for enemies is pretty intelligent for the most part. While each enemy isn’t that big of a threat, they will often try to attack from multiple sides and side-step the flashlight being shone in their direction. Worse, most battles take place in cramped quarters with enemies dropping down from all around Alan. This can lead to some rather intense battles throughout the course of the campaign. So, the player needs to keep as much awareness of his surroundings and keep moving as much as possible. PC Port Report and Visuals/AudioAlan Wake is very well optimized and comes with a plethora of PC options that belies its console origins. It comes with all expected resolution options, fullscreen on/off, Vsync on/off and HUD enabled/disabled. Advanced graphics options include: antialiasing up to 8x (which seems to be MSAA) and FXAA off/low/high quality. That seems a little bit odd that FXAA and MSAA could be mixed but they can be. Anisotropic filtering goes to 16x, shadow quality low/med/high, SSAO quality low/high, godray quality off/high, volumetric light quality low/high and finally backdrop quality low/medium/high. You can also adjust the level of detail, draw and grass distance with sliders that don’t quantify what you’re adjusting but at least you have them. There is a field of view slider (in the controls section of the settings menu oddly enough) but it also doesn’t quantify what you’re adjusting. According to PCGamingWiki[pcgamingwiki.com], they make recommendations on what your value should be for your particular resolution. Still, there should have been an in-game number to tell you what it did. All of the keyboard keys can be rebound while the controller only offers an alternative control scheme. Finally, there are four separate audio sliders for music, sound effects, speech and cinematic volume. All in all, outside of AW missing some in-game explanations for what everything does, the PC settings menu is very well done. Alan Wake goes for a fairly realistic style that’s heavily punctuated with bright lights and dark shadows. It looks rather good and the setting of Bright Falls feels like a town that definitely could have existed in Washington or Oregon. Their attention to detail and setting sells the Pacific Northwest vibe you can get while exploring. I will mention that there is some awkward/slightly off animations with cars, facial expressions, body movement and other little things. You can notice it but it's not enough to ruin the experience. Final ThoughtsAlan Wake has a great atmosphere, style and combat. The visuals still hold up and the use of shadows, fog and bright lights is very effective. Bright Falls feels like it could have been a real town in the Pacific Northwest. The combat system is really unique and quite enjoyable, even if your enjoyment of it may fall off towards the end of the game. The story is also well paced, constantly upping the ante without getting overwhelming and the characters are well designed and memorable to boot. One of my favorite thriller games I’ve ever played and well worth experiencing. Read this review and more on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]A Paladin's Review: Alan Wake: American Nightmare

There's a couple of jump scares in there, but for the most part it relies on a deeply unsettling atmosphere to pull you in. And it works well. content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												Alan Wake is one of those games that really surprised me of how good atmosphere can really be!It's about a writer dude that comes to Bright Falls with his wife to get rid of his writers blockage and to get some hot wifey action on a lake in a boat (but they never tell you that)..Ofcourse,♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan and some misterios, unexplained events happen, his wife is missing, everyone think he killed her, but few townsfolk actually have some hints on what is going on there.. As the story develops, you learn about similar events that happen before and about Alan's troublesome past..Game is action/adventure survival, in third person view that doesn't have that much adventure puzzles in it, it's more of enjoying the story as it builds up from chapter to chapter with great cut scenes that are directly in the game.. Sometimes you really can't tell if Alan is crazy, imagining things or things he is going through are actually real! Game is divided in 6 chapters and 2 special features that furter explains the story behind Bright Falls and bla bla spoilers..PRO- incredible atmosphere, heavily influenced by Twilight Zone, one of the best TV psychological horror show..- Graphics and scenery, game is spread over a town Bright Falls, mountain, cabin on the lake, roads, many awesome places, a lodge, old sawmill, farm etc.- gameplay is smooth and enticing, story is very well paced and delivered and for once, there are not many logical errors..- sounds and music are very good made, music get little wilder when you fight enemies, and all that clasic♥♥♥♥♥♥hehe- weapons and stuff are very well made, there are few clasic weapons like pistol, shotty, flare gun, flares, and as you play, you really don't need much to think about saving ammo, there are plenty (until you play on hard or nightmare mode :)CONS- controls are somewhat "slow" i.e. Alan needs few steps to stop or slow down, which is actually realistic but it can be problem when he doesn't stop when you want him to,- field of view, to my liking, is somewhat to close to main character, so you can't really "see" what is behind you.SHOULD I PLAY IT?Yeah, especially if you are into psychological horor games and liked to watch twilight zone (NOT SAGA), or any kind of survival game like Silent Hill (all of them :) especially SH2!, in some degree Resident Evil (first 3 parts, rest of them didn't quite fell good on me)..Something that really made this game excellent in my mind is as you "approach" the ending of the game, events get really weird/crazy with very good subcontext about whole plot, with many details that gives you small hints about Alan psyche and people around him (his wife, best friend,..)Anyway, it's 4 years since this game is out, and I played it just now, and it's still a MUST PLAY! content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												If you love kinds of mystery, you should find this interesting.I will be spoiler free as much as I can.::: Story :::The story is a bit hard to get a hang of, I was confused until I was in the middle of the story, where everything started to reveal themselves. Nice story with twists here and there, and keep me wanting to see more till the end. However, I personally think that it shouldn't end where it is, just a little bit further would be nice !::: Visual and FX :::The game looks nice indeed, you can play as vanilla or enhance it with tool of your choice, sweetfx for example. One thing to look for is that the game use a lot of light FX, i mean, tons of them. (as the game concept is based around the light and the dark) If you have problem with dynamic lighting fx, feeling dizzy from looking at them, you might not enjoy the game much.::: Gameplay :::The overall gameplay is okay, the unique combat system, light the darkness then blow it away, is fresh enough to be enjoyable. however, I was expecting that it would be more of the adventure, but instead, it is more action-oriented game. I don't mean that it is bad, but the game will throw enemies at you along your journey to the level that it losts its charm as mystery-themed game.Most encounters give you choices, to fight or to run. You can blast everything in your path with whatever at your disposal (tools, weapons, or even world's interactive objects), or avoid the encounter (if it isn't forced you to fight in the story), you can perform a timed-dodge, or even knock enemies off balance to get away from harms. The game utilized checkpoint system, when you reach it, the pursuers will be disappeared, and believe me, you will strive to get to it than stay and fight (especially in nightmare difficulty on your 2nd playthrough).Encounters are well-designed, though they lack of visual variations (you will see them again and again). Almost all of them can be staggered, which will give you some breathing room for whatever reason. They will surprise you from time to time (on your first playthrough).Your first playthrough will be a good experience, but on your 2nd or 3rd one on Nightmare difficulty, which you will be forced to play if you are intended to 100% the game, will become quite a task to finish, if you are the go-loud type. The achievements can be annoying (collect 100 of easily missed bottles), refering to the guide can help, a lot. It is fortunate that the game is in episodes, and can be replayed later.The control is responsive and is good enough to allow you to face multiple enemies at once without too much troubles, although sometimes it is too fast XD.::: Overall :::The game is good. The designs match the concepts, however, they seems to think that more actions are better for this kind of games, but really, they are too much. It play nicely from the beginning to the end. I recommend this for a single playthough, as it lacks of dynamic elements, making the game predictable. 2nd or 3rd playthough will be more like archievement runs.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2015
												A richly detailed environment, in lightness and darkness, bring this game very much to life. Atmospheric surroundings and sound effects, embellished by excellent cut-scenes that help the narrative as the story unfolds.The plot is fantastic yet grounded at the same time, riddled with clever what-ifs and many-layered implications of what it means to write creatively and what it is to truly push the boundaries between imagination and reality in this process. The gameplay itself is pretty damn epic as well. Action remains fast-paced and challenging without being too frustrating, supplies such as ammo or batteries are plentiful enough to stop you ever running the risk of being completely defenceless while remaining sparse enough to keep you considering what to preserve and when, and there is a varying degree of weaponry and enemy strength and speed to keep it interesting.One thing I really like about this game is that the game never gives you too much ammo, so you never really have that safe feeling when you are trudging through the woods. In other games you usually stack up on a lot of guns and ammo and end up being a one man army - not so in Alan Wake. Here, your character really is a frail writer with a flashlight and a tweed jacket, not a super soldier - your most powerful weapon is also the light. Without light, even the most potent gun cannot so much as even scratch the enemy.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Alan Wake is a mystery wrapped inside an enigma. Nothing else. If you try to make sense of all this, then you are certainly a brave one.The story, really well written I must say, is heavily inspired by Stephen King, H.P. Lovecraft and such. It does not have the crude horror of Stephen King, but it has the darkness. It does not have the overworldly presence of the Lovecraftian stories, but it has the unexplainable, the evil. Story driven to the core, Alan Wake will make you think twice before going in the dark (even if there isn't a single moment of true horror in my opinion). It's not about the horror really, it's about the darkness. You need to find out what lies in this darkness, what can be found and what should not be found. Will you be able to kill what you can't see?Alan Wake is a serious 9/10.
