content:
Posted: November 13, 2016



YouTube™ Video: IDGSL #1 - Alan Wake 

			Views: 16		

			The first episode of my game review serie. Be indulgent, it's the first game review I ever record. it's bounded to be flawed.		

~ I'D GIVE SOMETHING LIKE... ~~ #1 - Alan Wake ~=STORY=Alan Wake is the story of a despicable popular writter who wants to take a break from the celebrity of being a writter.It is as hipster and cringe worthy as it sounds.In love with a dumb*** woman who's scared of the dark, Alan has to take care of her everytime a fu**ing light turns off somewhere.And also every nights, for obvious reasons.Lights shutting down in the evening is enough to make her :jarate: herself.Every day must be a stressful event where she's more anxious the more the time goes.Blinking and closing her eyes must be a constant ~Nightmare~.Getting to the end of episode one, I realised that this game was made to be similar to a TV show, just like many episodic games such as TWD.The thing is, the story in the former is absolutely ret-/-/- while the one in the later is actually good.The story tries to go for this dark and grim tone, like a psychological thriller with some kind of deep and complexe paradox... but every dialogues are a reminder of how absurd the story and characters are.IDGSL : 3/10=GAMEPLAY=The idea behind the gameplay mechanics is interesting, casting light with your flashlight to break some kind of darkness shield and shoot the enemies when unvulnerable.The fact that it's pushed aside for a dumb TV-like story is pretty sad. But I'm not over yet.The game was obviously made for consoles with auto-aiming in mind. If you're looking for any kind of real skill requirement, this isn't the game for you.Without auto-aim, the game would be a chore, pretty much like Resident Evil 4 actually is.My despise for the Over-The-Shoulder view is beyond and above and every game using this broken third-person view confirms my hatred towards it.Even though the auto-aim makes shooting somewhat fun, the fact that you need to break the darkness shield of other enemies makes it a hassle.You will often shoot at an enemy that is not unvulnerable, wasting ammo in the process.The enemies are fast and taking the time to reload after wasting ammos will often get you hit and most probably killedFortunatly, batteries for the flashlight and ammos are abundent in game and you will respawn to the closest checkpoint when you die, which makes the game feel easy, even if you die. Playing the game at an harder difficulty obviously won't fix these things that are simply balanced to be unbalanced. Less Ammo, Less HP and staring from further awaydoesn't make a game more enjoyable.It just makes it more annoying and frustrating to play.IDGSL : 4/10=GRAPHICS=The graphics are alright, the shadings and lightnings are a wonder but the facial expressions of the main character are just laughable sometimes (at times).The animations aren't the best we've ever seen, it's working from far away but the closer you get, the more you see the uncanny valley of their expressions.Shading & light : 9/10Character design : 9/10Animations : 5/10IDGSL : 6/10=SOUNDTRACK=While not memorable, the soundtrack fits well with the story-telling in overall. It isn't annoying, it isn't pleasing, it's just bland and neutral.The music played at the end of the first episode is absolutely ridicoulus for the dark and grimy theme the game and story is aiming at. This wasn't good at all.The sound effects are alright, nothing special, it get's the job done. I've got nothing more to say about them other than that the revolver's sound feels great.IDGSL : 5/10=LAST NOTE=As the timer goes up, I'm actually writting this review instead of playing the game.And it's the second time I'm trying to get into it. I think it says a lot about my feeling toward it.I really liked the dark aspects of the game but the clunkyness of the gameplay, the awful story and the annoying protagonist and his wife makes me wonder if I really want to go further than the first episode.As a TOTAL, IDGSL : 35/100

Posted: September 10, 2013
Classic but underrated horror adventureThis is a very good game indeed. It does a marvellous job in telling a convincing story, and it gives you the felling to be part of a unique setting. This is not done by a large amount of cutscenes or - worse - voice-overs, no: the game manages to give you the feeling to be the protagonist in a good, and scary, movie. Everything in this game is polished to - almost - perfection, but most impressive is the way in which Alan Wake succeeds in drawing you into the story and the setting. After sometime, you feel like being Alan Wake, and like living his story.Very impressive is the way light is used in a dark setting, both as a weapon against the "dark presence" and as a safeheaven. Sometimes, you are so overwhelmed by enemies, the only valuable option is just to run for the nearest lightpost - which happily double as saving-points.Ok, there are some shortcomings: the difficulty can be a bit frustrating at times, but the story drives you further because you really want to know how things develop. The frightening part is sometimes a bit predictable, but still makes you jump a lot of times. Even during a second playthrough, I found myself being scared quite often, which is a rare thing in these kind of games. Worst: the camera angle is very weird, one has the feeling of walking not in a straight line forward, but after an hour or so, also this gets used to. Still, this could have been done better and is the only indication of the pc-version being a port from the consoles-version. Graphics happily can be tweaked to everyone's liking, so that this game can also run on a less powerful system. Still, it was one of the first games ever being optimalised for quad-core processors, but I only own a dual core, so I can't tell if this gives a noticable performance difference. On my 6-years' old rig (Core 2 Duo 2,66 Mhz & Radeon HD 5850) it runs very smooth indeed on completely maxed out settings.Graphics are very fine for a game of some years ago, and the sound is simply perfect. One very important thing: play this one in a dark room at night and set the brightness in the options as low as possible, since the light-dark contrast is an esssential part of the game. It will manage to make you jump quite some time! And o yeah - the two DLC's are masterfull, sometimes even better than the main game. So be sure to get them, they're worth it.Gameplay: 25/30Graphics: 16/20Sound: 10/10 (very, very frightening at times)Stability/patching: 20/20Replayability: 14/20 (singleplayer only, but the immersive story really asks for a second going)Played on: Intel Core 2Duo E8200 @ 2,66Ghz, Radeon HD 5850, 4GB RamOverall: 85/100

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Alan Wake id undoubtedly a triple-A game and there's no questioning in it being a GOOD GAME. After playing for several hours and not completing it, there's one thing I need to point out: the. story. is. killer.In all due seriousness, however, Alan Wake is a writer to have found himself in a messy situation when Mr. Wake and his wife just wanted to go relaxing outside of the city. His wife goes missing and he needs to figure stuff out. It all gets way more complicated than that, and it makes you scratch your head at times. Overall, the story makes you feel; that's what makes a good story! And the environment certainly adds to it. Whoever designed the levels need to be glorified. They did a stellar work designing/creating levels that makes you fear the night (literally fear it) and adore the day. During the daytime, you're found in a 1960-style small town that really makes you just want to grab a chair, sit down and relax. It's so calm and beautiful. But then comes the night, and Alan needs to fight for his life and so do you.Speaking of fighting for his life, you get extraordinarily limited attempting to do that very task. There's a ridiculous limit on the ammunition you can carry (despite ammunition being found everywhere, it does run out quickly) that makes it incredibly difficult to get out of a hairy situation. For example, if you get stuck and there's no ammo around & you meet a ton of enemies, well, tough luck.. your best bet is to run away from them.. in other words, no combat action. CHEAP AND UNACCEPTABLE ♥♥♥♥ING "SOLUTION". But, usually you do have ammo if you use your equipment very conservatively.. no fun doing that, however.Story is fantastic, gameplay is great and the environment & the atmosphere are out of this world.. astonishing, really! And the game is so well done that it's essentially bug-free! Awesome! If there's a game that gives you a great bang for the buck, Alan Wake is certainly on that list. I thoroughly enjoy this.9,0/10

												On my second play through of this gem of a game! I remember waiting for it while it was being developed. It was promised for PC and even showcased on it showing off the latest DX bells and whisles. Then all of a sudden the enemy of PC gaming Microsoft pulled the plug and the Windows version was no more. It became an Xbox exclusive and the sales were poor. I felt they deserved the poor sales after what they did to the PC community and basically forgot about the game after that. A few years later out of the blue I see "Alan Wale" available on Steam and can't believe it! I then find out "Remedy" the awesome developers that brought us Max Payne 1 and 2 funded the port themselves and I was psyched! To top it all off the price was only $30.00 and came with all the game's DLC included. I bought the game and got completely absorbed in it. Not only was it a fantastic game but the port was perfect and the graphics looked so much better than the Xbox version I felt they really did us justice. I remember reading later that week that they made their money back on the PC port in 2 days time! That made me very happy, they were rewarded for taking their time to bring this remarkable title to us PC gamers after all. Since then there have been many sales, I've seen the game go as low as $3.00 and gifted it to many friends and family who never played it before. Everyone ended up loving it and not too long after that we got the expansion pack "American Nghtmare" which was also a treat. The point of this review is not just to recommend this game because it's a great AAA title, it's because it proved there still is a thriving PC community out there that will take care of the developers that take care of us. I hope in the end Remedy ended up making a lot of money off the PC port, hopefully moreso than they did on the Xbox exclusive. I know they showed their gratitude to us by the statements they made and that alone proved to me Remedy is a class act.I look forward to their next title and hopefully they learned their lesson and realize there is a strong PC community out here ready to support them so therefore when the next game is released give us the PC version along with the consoles! I expect great future titles from Remedy and the PC gamer's support we deserve.So if you haven't played this game BUY IT... SALE OR NOT, it's worth whatever you end up paying for it and grab "American Nightmare" as well since Remedy has stated we won't be seeing a sequel to Alan Wake anytime soon... if ever. It would be a shame for any third person shooter fan to miss out on this excellent franchise!! ENJOY!

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Alan Wake is an interesting 3rd person action game featuring intense-yet-flawed gameplay, thankfully held up by the gripping, 'Twin Peaks' style plot.In an unusual choice of protagonist, you play as an author suffering from writer's block. You're taken on a holiday by your ever-supportive wife, but things start to go a bit wonky. Before you know it, the whole place is falling apart, your wife has been eaten by a lake, and you keep finding pages from a novel you don't remember writing. Between the episodic nature, and the overall presentation, this is a game that feels like it wishes it was a TV show.In terms of gameplay, Alan Wake is a solid 3rd-person action game, but it's let down by a lack of variety across the board. There are scarcely half a dozen different types of enemies, and five weapons (two of which are shotguns), of which only two can be held simultaneously (although the pistol can never be replaced, leaving the player with very limited choice).The gameplay revolves around the concept of having to burn away the 'darkness' around an enemy with a flashlight, much like armour, before you can harm them with physical weaponry. This is an excellent concept in itself, but by the end of the game it feels extremely worn. With every enemy you encounter, you'll have to follow the same routine: get far enough away to burn them with the light, then put them down with a handful of bullets. I cannot think of a single exception to this from start to finish, even including prominent antagonists.Aside from being extremely repetitive, the game suffers from the play-style enforced by this mechanic. In a game which wants you to feel panicked while you run for your life, you're constantly forced to stop and stand still while you tediously point your flashlight at yet another enemy. And yes - by and large, this is the only possible tactic.You might think that running away would be a good choice, especially given the thriller/horror tone of the game, but you have an extremely limited running ability, and the enemies run faster than you. Making a desperate break away from a group of enemies turns into an exercise in frustration as Wake puffs and pants like an asthmatic, before being set upon, exhausted, by the same group of enemies you were trying to run away from in the first place.Alan Wake's saving grace is the plot and the atmosphere it generates. I expected nothing less from the studio which created Max Payne (and there are a handful of knowing winks to Payne within this game), and Remedy really knocked it out of the park here. I was genuinely gripped by the story, which is split into six 'episodes' in the style of a TV show. The daytime segments, where you are given more free reign to explore the environment, are particularly excellent.If you enjoy being sucked into a game's world, Alan Wake will not disappoint, provided you can slog through the gameplay to reach the next bit of story. The only real let-down here is the lip-syncing on the character models, which is laughably poor for a game of this time.Part-way into the game, you're given perhaps the greatest spectacle that Alan Wake has to offer - the signal flare. It's hardly surprising, given that this is a game focused so intently on light/dark contrast, but the flares look absolutely stunning. Having obtained them, the most effective tactic when encountering a group of enemies becomes to hunker down.Pick away the shields of the strongest enemies first, waiting for the group as a whole to get close enough. Once they're within arms reach, pop a flare and watch as the screen erupts into ruby red pyrotechnics. Even with the repetitive nature of the overall game, I never got tired of the almost messianic sound and visuals of the flare - Alan Wake's true saviour (aside from the plot).The game also has a number of driving sections, which provide a generally enjoyable change of pace. At worst, they were short enough to not cause any problems. At best, they reminded me of racing over the sand in Half-Life 2. The number of replacement cars scattered throughout the levels does, however, make me wonder if there's a chronic problem with people abandoning perfectly good cars by the roadside in America's north-west...So, as a game, Alan Wake is mediocre at best. If you're looking for a horror game full of scares, or solid 3rd person action, this is not the game for you. But would I otherwise recommend it? Absolutely. For me, it all comes down to the plot, and how easily I can become absorbed in a game's environment and characters. Remedy did a great job on that.The real problem with Alan Wake is that it really feels like Remedy wanted to make a TV show, and accidentally made a game. Given that their upcoming game, Quantum Break, is reported to have an accompanying TV show, I can only hope they get the balance right the next time around.

Short version: 86%Alan Wake is masterfully written mystery horror thriller with great narrative, excellent level design, memorable supporting characters and a combat system that starts out excellent but turns into a chore near the end. If you love a good mystery story and don’t mind that it uses the age-old light versus dark theme, then Alan Wake is certainly a game you should play.Long version:Alan Wake is a little bit like playing a video game version of Stephen King’s early novels; after all it’s a supernatural psychological mystery thriller set in a small US town in the middle of nowhere. (Though instead of Maine it’s situated in a heavily forested area somewhere in the state of Washington.) Therefore the main focus of the game is on the story and the narrative, which complement each other in such levels that is very rarely seen in a video game.As a game, Alan Wake is a mixture of survival horror (the Alone in the Dark kind, not the Resident Evil type) and third-person shooter. The early parts of the game focus mainly on the mystery and the narrative, all enemies are only there to keep up the suspense. Sadly it eventually turns into straight-up arena combat against waves and waves of enemies. And the combat mechanic is really working against these scenarios, turning the last part of the game into a series of trial-and-error fights.The game also has way too many collectibles– almost four hundred, counting the ones in the DLCs– and only two type of them serve any real purpose: the hidden chests, which give you some additional gear; and the manuscript pages, that will eventually tell the story of Alan’s missing week, and shed some more light on the mystery.If you can get past of the combat system, that turns the game into a nightmare in late levels, and focus on the story only, Alan Wake will be one of the best thrillers you have ever played, on par with the most well-known movies in that genre. Good enough to play it more than one time, which is a rare thing on story-focused mystery games. Just don’t try and get all achievements, unless you have a very large amount of patience…

It is made in a way that i have never seen before, the way it plays each chapter like it was an episode from a television serie, the way the gameplay is all about light and dark, i think this is by far one of the best action survival horror games i have played, and not horror because the things you see are nasty, but because it creates the perfect scenario for a horror movie/game, the fact that it happens mostly at night and in the dark, the various scenarios you see throughout all the chapters, the exploration although limited, makes it seem less linear wanting you to check every corner for ammo and batteries if you need'em, and the story... content:
Posted: July 16, 2013
												Alan Wake is a game where you play as Stephen King's arch-nemesis Alan Wake. The game takes place in Alan's subconscious while he suffers from a coma which he got by attempting to stage an imitation-injury involving paying a man to run-over him in a semi-automatic truck. Alan imagines he is in the world of Twin Peaks but gets attacked by the shadows of Stephen King during nightfall, which serves as an interruption to his trolling of Stephen King message boards and fan-sites. To my surprise, Alan Wake is actually a multiplayer deathmatch shooter which licenses the technology pioneered by the America's Army games wherein every player plays as Alan Wake, but appears as Stephen King to other players. After playing through each of the multiplayer scenarios a cut-scene plays which reveals that Alan was shooting innocent people in the world world in his comatose state, and trolling actual Stephen King message boards. For this surprise twist, I can easily recommend Alan Wake to all.

Spoiler Free Review:I had high hopes going into Alan Wake, it being recommended after completing the Vanishing of Ethan Carter, and now that I’ve finished my first run through I’m a bit disappointed.In Alan Wake you play as Alan, a writer confronting a “darkness” with your trusty flashlight to guide the way.  It’s an episodic/narrative type game, not to be confused with Telltale games where you barely get to move around – in Alan Wake you do have combat, driving, and most things you’d expect from a normal video game.My first run through of the story, including the two DLC episodes only took 11 hours.  Each of the main 6 episodes take about 1.5 hours to complete.  While other reviewers are praising the story, I just couldn’t get into it.  The writing and voice acting were excellent, and there were some very good parts, however the story never drew me in, mainly due to Alan Wake’s many faults and the general premise of a writer or artists impact on the supernatural.To the main drawback - the gameplay itself was frustrating.  The camera view alone, being force on a “over the shoulder” experience didn’t fit with the play style.  Sprint in the game became a joke, forced into a perpetual reminder of how they could have done soooo much better.  If you sprint for too long (5 seconds?) you basically stop in your tracks to catch your breath – terrible for escaping enemies.  The main drawback is the gameplay is extremely repetitive.  Walk, trigger a scene, use flashlight to stop darkness, shoot, and repeat.  It’s the same cycle throughout the entire game.  When a boss fight, or a major skirmish does happen, they all unfold in predictably the same ways, with the same waves of enemies, which you combat in exactly the same method.As mentioned before, the DLC consists of two episodes which continues the main storyline, but not in any meaningful way, and there is no multiplayer which is a good thing.  Graphically the game is fine, in line with the times, but nothing spectacular.  The graphical rendering between gameplay and cut scenes is obvious and they could have done a better job smoothing it out or rendering the cut scenes with actual gameplay.With the lack of a gripping story, and lack luster and frustrating mechanics, finally nailed by the repetitiveness, this isn’t going to be a recommendation.  However, just like with books there are some good and some bad, but either way when you’re reading it you enjoy it slightly…. that is kind of how this was.  I still had fun playing it, just didn’t leave a good aftertaste.Rating: 4 out of 10. Just can’t recommend it.Playing on i7-6700, 16Gb RAM, GTX1070

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Alan Wake - Remedy's PasticheHave you ever put down a good psychological horror book and wished you could experience similar thrills in video game form? Well, there are plenty of options for that, but here is Remedy (developer of Max Payne and its sequel The Fall of Max Payne) and their take on the genre. While far from a horror classic, Alan Wake provides enough thrills and atmosphere to prop up the mysterious, and rather compelling, story.The player controls titular character Alan Wake, a successful novelist who finds himself traveling with his wife Alice to the Pacific Northwest in order to break a drought of writing inspiration. The setup instantly draws comparisons to other works, such as Twin Peaks and The Shining, giving the game an instant feeling of familiarity, yet still retaining that feeling of mystery and intrigue. What follows from this setup are even more recognizable tropes (quirky locals, mysterious woods, marital disagreements) which all come together to form an impressive and memorable narrative, however forceful and contrived it gets. The game splits itself into "episodes" (ala a tv show, complete with previously ons and next time ons) which allows the game to set into a nice pacing, however predictably each one has to find new ways to throw Alan into the woods to contend with evil forces.The gameplay continues the trend of familiarity, borrowing heavily from other shooter/horror games. The gunplay is recognizably Resident Evil 4, however looser and faster. Alan Wake may be a writer, however he seems to know his way around firearms quite extensively, though it's only through the game's sole unique mechanic, does he shine. In order to mow down enemies with your arsenal of guns, Alan must make use of his trusty flashlight (powered by real brand Duracell batteries!) and stun enemies with it until their shroud of darkness disapates, leaving them open to bullets. If low on (Duracell brand) batteries and (non affilated brand) ammo, Alan has the option of dodging enemy attacks and running in the opposite direction, however on Normal difficutly, with enough exploring and well placed shots, one should never have much issue with lack of resources.  While fun and novel at first, the game never really adds anything past the flashlight mechanic, which after its surprisingly long campaign (11-13 hours), it starts to see diminishing returns rather quickly, thus the game loses quite a bit of tension and becomes more predictable.Originally an XBox360 exclusive, the game was ported to PC several years after its release (in order to recoup a 5 year development budget), including all the the DLC. The game seemed well optimized and I ran into minimal issues in terms of bugs and graphical glitches, as well as an acceptable amount of graphical options, which is always appareciated in this day of rushed and shoddy console ports. While flawed, Alan Wake is ultimately a game worth picking up, even at its full price. While the gameplay begins to stale in the later hours of the game, there is always a well done cutscene or interesting collectable around the corner to alleviate some of that boredom. If anything, its another portal into the mind of writer Sam Lake (who also was the creative mind behind the first two Max Payne games), who proves to be a capable and inventive storyteller.

												I entered the game trusting only the reviews. Somehow, the numbers didn't fail me - on most parts of  the game, at least.Gameplay's quite unique. You can't just shoot the enemies on sight, you have to weaken them first using any source of light. The answer to the 'why' is heavily related to the story. There were also some puzzles that weren't really head-scratching. Easy ones if I may say so. A thing about combat I didn't like is it isn't easy to find out if the area you're in has an infinte respawn of the enemies. You'll clear a wave carefully and the next thing you know, they respawn 3 seconds right after you cleared them, repeat.The story's good in the sense that it's really gripping. Almost the same level of 'gripping' as Bioshock Infinite with the use of twists and mind♥♥♥♥s. I'll also add that if you're a fan of games with 'notes' in them, you'll be so into this. Almost every part of the game has one for you to find.The songs used in the game, especially the one in the ending, suits the story in their tone. The effects weren't something you'd have to applaud to. And every damn time Barbara Jagger appears in Alan Wake's mind, man, get ready for a '♥♥♥♥ you' from your headphones'. I totally suggest you use loudness equalization. So, yeah. Score's a meh.I recommend this game, but barely. The one con that I really wanna mention are some of the achievements. Most of the time, you're in a forest/mountain-ish settings, and you have to collect: Coffee Thermoses (A hundred of these.) Manuscripts (A hundred as well.) Chests. Pyramid of cans to shoot.And maybe other things I couldn't care less to remember. In forest and mountain areas. In fuuuuuu- forest and mountain areas. Most probably, you'll have to revisit these areas just to find and collect them all. Talk about like playing Pokemon Go but there are darkness-controlled people trying to axe you in half and slice your head thru throwing sickles.Well, anyway, the story makes it all so much worth it.*David Bowie music plays*

content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												A third-person survival horror game, Alan Wake places you in the shoes of the title character, a world-renowned writer suffering from a classic case of Writers Block. The story starts off with a supposedly normal and relaxing vacation with your wife in a quaint, quiet and beautiful small mountain town, and all's going well until your wife vanishes in the dark and you immediately find yourself inexplicably waking up from a car crash. The objective is clear, the narrative is brilliant and immersive and the story is constantly throwing twists and turns, making you begin to question the mental condition of Alan. The controls are simple, but far from dull. Pressing shift at the correct time will allow you to perform a "cinematic dodge" that lets you slip away unharmed from an enemy attack. Though essentially the cinematic dodges are little more than a quick-time event, it is implemented very well and doesn't take up too much room in gameplay and isn't intrusive in the slightest (take notes, Call of Juarez, you piece of rubbish). The combat is intuitive and unique, the player doesn't simply waddle around through the night not giving half a crap as you fire off shells into whatever moves. Instead, all the enemies are essentially "shielded" by shadows, and in order to harm them the player must utilize their trusty flashlight to remove these shadows and leave them open for retaliation. As well as being your only method of weakening enemies, the flashlight also doubles as your crosshair, adding a significant realism factor and makes the game that much more immersive. The light mechanics are cleverly implemented, encouraging the player to pick out their targets and rewards them for using any lights in the environment alongside your flashlight to dispatch enemies in unique ways. Graphics wise, Alan Wake is very demanding. If your specs aren't completely up to the task then you'll average at 15 frames-per-second even on the lowest settings. But if you're machine can handle it then you'll be rewarded with beautful visuals even on medium settings, the American Rockies look amazing and the forests are very life-like, coupled with the minimal HUD and the dynamic lighting Alan Wake will take you into a roller-coaster ride of immersion.I hate to say it, but the immersion is also easily broken by the implementation of stock sound effects, and the character facial animations appear unpolished, making everyone in the game look like they're on dope and just woke up from a night of drinking and drooling on the floor. All things considered, Alan Wake is a thrill ride that mustn't be passed up on. I greatly recommend taking a look at the graphics requirements and seeing if Alan Wake will operate on your system.Also a fair warning: The ending of Alan Wake sucked and set the foundations for it's crummy sequel. Have fun.

												Alan Wake is a highly immersive horror experience with a suspenseful and carefully developed storyline. I began the game with high expectations, and finished with nothing short of satisfaction. content:
Posted: December 29, 2012
												From the makers of Max Payne comes a thriller originally released exclusively on the Xbox360 in 2010. Remedy finally did what it promised to PC gamers a long time ago.As a Remedy fan I had to preorder this, and I was pleased to see this as a port done right, even though the game was meant to be a Windows Vista exclusive in the first place.Because of Micro$oft's tyranny over the IP, many PC gamers felt left down. Some even built new computers just to play this game back in the day.In Alan Wake you collect manuscript pages, damn fine coffee in thermos and shoot stacked beer cans. Light is your key to survival against the dark forces, which try to stop you as you are looking for your loved one. Exciting!If you like Twin Peaks, X-Files, Twilight Zone and Roy Orbison's In Dreams, this is the game for you. Story has been divided into parts to represent a TV series. Gameplay mechanics may be old for some and the combat gets repetitive towards the end, but nevertheless it is still an exciting psychological thriller.Alan Wake surprised many of us by making it's sudden appearance on Steam, and this time on the right platform on which it belongs!For people who like to tweak their games a little there are a number of good SweetFX profiles for the game that sharpens the image, adds more depth to colors and makes the game look overall less washed out. Try 'em!

												Ok, so first of all Alan Wake is my favourite game of all time! But why is it so good, there are many reasons (without spoilers):1. The story is so awesome and well written and different from normal that it keeps surprising you and sometimes you just wonder that why did they tell me all this information, to add more depth to all of the characters and places wich brings me to my next reasons.2. Characters are all different from each other and you can see that how much they put effort for just making each character feel more real, by their looks, movement and their way of thinking cause they are all so different from each other.3. The atmoshpere is awesome! All those little details looks awesome and the light elements are just stunning. It's really dark in the woods but the way Remedy made he light work is just so beatifull! It's so cool seeing it going trough every little holy you can find!4. Gameplay is different than normally 3rd person games are. It's one of the best games to make that cinematic feeling from slow-motion dodges and even when you are just walking in a forest.5.The combat is very cool feeling. First, you have to get enough light to an enemy that it's darkness wears off so you can shoot it. There are not many weapons, but the game doesn't suffer from that. There are also flares, flare guns, flash granades and 3 different flashlight to give you the upper hand.6. The light is the most important thing in the game cause if you have light, you might survive, might. But all the reflections and the light sneeking out from the dark and saving your ♥♥♥ just when you thought you would die, it's just awesome!7. Re-play value is great in this game cause when you beat the game you will unlock nightmare difficulty wich is harder but not so hard that you will rage quit, but it's there so that you would play the game again knowing abot all the stuff and what's gonna happen when you read the pages. 8. Graphics in this game are not perfect but very detailed and cool looking, just perfect for this world.9. Landscape is just so awesome, sometimes you just stop in the middle of the game and just look at the most beatifull enviroment ever in games and take screenshots so that you could make that your new screensaver.10. The game itself tooks about 13-20 hours to complete with the dcl's so it's a good lenght.Those are the main reasons why you should buy this game, I don't recommend Alan Wake Americas Nightmare so much cause it could have been a great game but compared to the original tittle, it's just so awfull. But go buy the game before they release the new one so you could play that one too!

content:
Posted: January 7
												I entered the game trusting only the reviews. Somehow, the numbers didn't fail me - on most parts of  the game, at least.Gameplay's quite unique. You can't just shoot the enemies on sight, you have to weaken them first using any source of light. The answer to the 'why' is heavily related to the story. There were also some puzzles that weren't really head-scratching. Easy ones if I may say so. A thing about combat I didn't like is it isn't easy to find out if the area you're in has an infinte respawn of the enemies. You'll clear a wave carefully and the next thing you know, they respawn 3 seconds right after you cleared them, repeat.The story's good in the sense that it's really gripping. Almost the same level of 'gripping' as Bioshock Infinite with the use of twists and mind♥♥♥♥s. I'll also add that if you're a fan of games with 'notes' in them, you'll be so into this. Almost every part of the game has one for you to find.The songs used in the game, especially the one in the ending, suits the story in their tone. The effects weren't something you'd have to applaud to. And every damn time Barbara Jagger appears in Alan Wake's mind, man, get ready for a '♥♥♥♥ you' from your headphones'. I totally suggest you use loudness equalization. So, yeah. Score's a meh.I recommend this game, but barely. The one con that I really wanna mention are some of the achievements. Most of the time, you're in a forest/mountain-ish settings, and you have to collect: Coffee Thermoses (A hundred of these.) Manuscripts (A hundred as well.) Chests. Pyramid of cans to shoot.And maybe other things I couldn't care less to remember. In forest and mountain areas. In fuuuuuu- forest and mountain areas. Most probably, you'll have to revisit these areas just to find and collect them all. Talk about like playing Pokemon Go but there are darkness-controlled people trying to axe you in half and slice your head thru throwing sickles.Well, anyway, the story makes it all so much worth it.*David Bowie music plays*

												Fantastic experience! The storytelling of Alan Wake is done extremely well. The game is divided into tv-like episodes complete with cliffhangers at the end of each. Cutscenes, collectable text manuscripts, listening to Alan think outloud all do a great job telling the story. The game starts out feeling like an atmospheric horror game. Once you meet the protagonist's best friend, there is plenty of comical banter between the two. The combat mechanic is elegantly simple and surprisingly doesnt ever get repetitive.  The game does a good job introducing upgrades to your items as you progress through the story.The pc port is done very well. As old as the game is, the ingame assets still look great. The only thing that might look dated is Alan's hair. It took be about 18 hours to complete. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This is one game I really, really wanted to like. The beginning looked so promising, too - I was delighted by the intriguing story with its strong Stephen King vibe, and the creepy atmosphere was exhilarating! I bravely set off into the dark woods, armed with only a flashlight and a pistol, to see what lies ahead. It's been a year and I still haven't finished the game. The whole dark, creepy woods thing gets boring after a while, and every time I got my hopes up, thinking that maybe, just maybe, Alan Wake will do something during daytime, there was an unforeseen turn of events and surprise, here we are in the forest again. Ugh! Even more frustrating were the clunky keyboard controls, which caused Alan to duck at the beginning of every sprint and completely lose all coordination when jumping. Using a controller, he handles a bit better, but it still shows his port-y nature. I recommend this game for patient people with controllers. I can see how it could be a really great game, and story-wise, it already is. For me, however, repetitive missions and horrible controls led to a love-hate relationship with this game.

												I have played this plus the DLCs through on X360, and can honestly say that this is one of my favorite games of all time. The graphics, sounds, music all together create a psychological thriller with a chilling atmosphere, that is on par with other great titles such as Bioshock or The Swapper. Alan Wake takes it's influence from many works of cult fiction such as Alone in the Dark and Twin Peaks. The plot itself is quite twisted, but thanks to the brilliantly executed storytelling, Remedy has made sure that anyone can catch up with the narrative. But, as with every game, this game has few flaws. First of all, the combat, which at first is quite fun, starts to come a bit dull towards the end of the game. More types of enemies would be needed. And the second flaw that I have experienced is the driving. Controls just feel too clumsy. Thankfully these flaws are quite minor, as the game is most certainly meant to deliver an brilliantly executed story. A goal which it sure exceedes on a great margin. 9+/10

Posted: December 17, 2012
												This game has, without a doubt, one of the best stories I have ever seen. It's rather dark, and while I wouldn't call it "scary," it definitely contains many horror-esque themes. The gameplay is honestly rather repetitive, and takes some getting used to in that, for whatever reason, Alan doesn't walk straight ahead when you hold forward. But really, it's very easy to overlook and ignore those issues, as they become extremely insignificant when compared to the story. Between the cutscenes, in-game narration and various manuscript pages you find throughout the game, I really got the feeling of reading a great book that you just can't put down. I'd stay up long into the night playing it, constantly on edge, wanting to find out what happened next. The only thing that broke complete immersion for me was the, eh, less-than-subtle and out-of-place product placement here and there. But overall, if you're a horror fan (especially if you like Stephen King) and are looking for an excellent story, do not pass this game up.

												The next major game from Remedy turns out to be a smash as Alan Wake is an engaging thriller of a game that'll keep you enngaged from beginning to end. Taking cues from Stephen King and Twin Peaks, Alan Wake presents a decent tale that is very stylised with frequent narration from Alan himself. The presentation is outstanding with the game looking gorgeous and having a great creepy atmosphere with its various lighting and wind effects, although there is an over-reliance on forest locations for my taste. Also the TV show style structure provides great stopping gaps for playing and give a unique presentation to the usual game structure. Gameplay is fun with the torch and 3rd person gunplay working in tandem to provide a nice spin on the usual shooting gameplay. However it can get a little formulaic at points, with not enough enemy types with it only being Taken, Brute Taken, Fast Taken and Birds being the main enemies. That being said Alan Wake is still a great and intriguing game to play with it's compelling presentation and fun gameplay, definitely check it if it goes on sale.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												Alan Wake is a decent game with an amazing story full of mystery and suspense. Both the characters and the plot are engaging and it's all executed very well. The game is split up into episodes, and it flows very much like a TV show, complete with a "previously in Alan Wake" section at the beginning of each episode. Every episode ends with a song. Yes, a full song. You can skip it, but I find it's actually helps with the pacing of the game a lot. It gives you time to check your phone or stand up and go do something for a minute or two. For a game that's this intense, that short break is actually pretty useful.The same can't be said about the rest of the game. I don't really consider it a horror game. It tries to be scary but doesn't quite achieve it for me. This is largely due to the repetitive loop of:- walk to a new area- 1-3 enemies appear- shine flashlight at enemies until you can shoot them- shoot the enemies- search the area for items- go to the next areathat makes the gameplay very predictable and boring. All I've seen so far is the introduction of more powerful weapons along with larger/tougher enemies, but no added depth to the flashlight mechanic, which gets old fast.In my opinion, it's definitely worth playing once, but I don't see much replay value in it outside of going back for the hidden collectibles or trying to get all of the achievements.

content:
Posted: July 7, 2013
												A third-person survival horror game, Alan Wake places you in the shoes of the title character, a world-renowned writer suffering from a classic case of Writers Block. The story starts off with a supposedly normal and relaxing vacation with your wife in a quaint, quiet and beautiful small mountain town, and all's going well until your wife vanishes in the dark and you immediately find yourself inexplicably waking up from a car crash. The objective is clear, the narrative is brilliant and immersive and the story is constantly throwing twists and turns, making you begin to question the mental condition of Alan. The controls are simple, but far from dull. Pressing shift at the correct time will allow you to perform a "cinematic dodge" that lets you slip away unharmed from an enemy attack. Though essentially the cinematic dodges are little more than a quick-time event, it is implemented very well and doesn't take up too much room in gameplay and isn't intrusive in the slightest (take notes, Call of Juarez, you piece of rubbish). The combat is intuitive and unique, the player doesn't simply waddle around through the night not giving half a crap as you fire off shells into whatever moves. Instead, all the enemies are essentially "shielded" by shadows, and in order to harm them the player must utilize their trusty flashlight to remove these shadows and leave them open for retaliation. As well as being your only method of weakening enemies, the flashlight also doubles as your crosshair, adding a significant realism factor and makes the game that much more immersive. The light mechanics are cleverly implemented, encouraging the player to pick out their targets and rewards them for using any lights in the environment alongside your flashlight to dispatch enemies in unique ways. Graphics wise, Alan Wake is very demanding. If your specs aren't completely up to the task then you'll average at 15 frames-per-second even on the lowest settings. But if you're machine can handle it then you'll be rewarded with beautful visuals even on medium settings, the American Rockies look amazing and the forests are very life-like, coupled with the minimal HUD and the dynamic lighting Alan Wake will take you into a roller-coaster ride of immersion.I hate to say it, but the immersion is also easily broken by the implementation of stock sound effects, and the character facial animations appear unpolished, making everyone in the game look like they're on dope and just woke up from a night of drinking and drooling on the floor. All things considered, Alan Wake is a thrill ride that mustn't be passed up on. I greatly recommend taking a look at the graphics requirements and seeing if Alan Wake will operate on your system.Also a fair warning: The ending of Alan Wake sucked and set the foundations for it's crummy sequel. Have fun.

content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
HIGHLY RECOMMEND.Recommended. On the fence. Play it when hell freezes over. Avoid like the plague.It's powerful, suspenseful, and has enough story to fill a novel. Keep in mind, that's mostly what the game is - a cinematic experience. If it's not your cup of tea, then don't bother. You are Alan Wake, a famous author on vacation who suddenly realizes the stories he wrote have come to life. These stories are no ordinary stories mind you, they are horror stories that want something in particular from Wake. That's when the game truly begins. It is a psychological horror, entirely story driven, that will have you questioning what's real and what's not. Alan Wake is very similar to any TV series - released in episodic content to keep you on the edge of your seat. There's 6 episodes totaling 2-3 hours each of playtime with 2 bonus DLC episodes (approximately 2 hours). Overall you are looking at nearly a 20 hour game. There's also a stand-alone follow-up called Alan Wake's American Nightmare. The gameplay is fairly straightforward - you are equipped with a flashlight and pistol. The flashlight is used to hurt the enemies by shining light on them and the pistol is used to kill them for good. The enemies themselves are hard to describe without ruining the game - essentially they are a paranormal darkness that stalk Wake and members of the community. The game borrows its inspiration heavily from Stephen King novels, Alfred Hitchcock, and the 90s TV show Twin Peaks. Most of the game you'll find yourself running from enemies, battling them, or solving a minor puzzle. Everything is there to drive the story forward. It's more exploration and survival based as opposed to run n gun. Overall, Remedy presented us with the definitive cinematic experience of psychological horrors. It's got an amazing atmosphere, a very fitting soundtrack and score, and the graphics are beautiful. As a game however, it loses points for being limited in what you do. The game gets a solid 7.5/10 from me.

Posted: August 3, 2013
												Fantastic experience! The storytelling of Alan Wake is done extremely well. The game is divided into tv-like episodes complete with cliffhangers at the end of each. Cutscenes, collectable text manuscripts, listening to Alan think outloud all do a great job telling the story. The game starts out feeling like an atmospheric horror game. Once you meet the protagonist's best friend, there is plenty of comical banter between the two. The combat mechanic is elegantly simple and surprisingly doesnt ever get repetitive.  The game does a good job introducing upgrades to your items as you progress through the story.The pc port is done very well. As old as the game is, the ingame assets still look great. The only thing that might look dated is Alan's hair. It took be about 18 hours to complete. I highly recommend this game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												This is one game I really, really wanted to like. The beginning looked so promising, too - I was delighted by the intriguing story with its strong Stephen King vibe, and the creepy atmosphere was exhilarating! I bravely set off into the dark woods, armed with only a flashlight and a pistol, to see what lies ahead. It's been a year and I still haven't finished the game. The whole dark, creepy woods thing gets boring after a while, and every time I got my hopes up, thinking that maybe, just maybe, Alan Wake will do something during daytime, there was an unforeseen turn of events and surprise, here we are in the forest again. Ugh! Even more frustrating were the clunky keyboard controls, which caused Alan to duck at the beginning of every sprint and completely lose all coordination when jumping. Using a controller, he handles a bit better, but it still shows his port-y nature. I recommend this game for patient people with controllers. I can see how it could be a really great game, and story-wise, it already is. For me, however, repetitive missions and horrible controls led to a love-hate relationship with this game.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This game does a thousand things incredibly well that makes the experience completely worthwhile.  Unfortunately, it also stumbles a few times with repetitive gameplay.The good:-Story is very well written, though perhaps a bit unevenly paced-Voice acting is phenomenal-Musical score is incredible (and included in the collector's edition)-Visual effects are great-Gameplay mechanics are simple and easy to learn and many puzzles are well designed-DLC (included) did a great job of keeping things fresh after a lengthy main gameThe bad:-Mostly just one - combat gets very repetitive.  Before long, every time you see the signs that you'll be entering combat, you'll just want to get it over with to get to the next plot point.  They did what they could to make the combat environments, situations, etc as interesting as possible, but it feels like the enemies late in the game are the same as those in the beginning, just with thicker skin.Fortunately, they mixed things up a bit at the end of the game and in the 2 "episodes" that follow.  Ultimately, you'll finish the game feeling satisfied.  And for a few bucks more (less if it's on sale!), pick up American Nightmare too.  It's worth it.Recommended.

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												Alan Wake is a deep & thought provoking work of fiction, its story is engaging & extremely well written. Tense & exciting from beginning to end with an episodic structure to the game that only picks up pace the further you delve into the mysteries of Bright Falls.   Alan wake Deals with the line between fiction and fact, and creativity, this game filters them through tv shows like Twin Peaks, the novels of Stephen King, and throws in references to Edgar Allan Poe, amongst others, to great effect.  Not intended to be seen as a shoot-em-up style game, this is one for adventurers who like a well-crafted puzzler of a plot, and rewards paying careful attention to the events therein.

												This game was a lot of fun to play and to look at. The graphics aren't unbelievable or anything (the facial graphics are particularly lackluster), but the way they all come together to create such an immersive atmostphere really makes the game worth playing IMO.The story itself is pretty cool, although it seriously leaves you hanging. Or at least it did for me. I found out after the fact that there exists a DLC that provides a somewhat more conclusive ending, but it is not available on PC. I think.Still, very cool game. I'm hesitant to call it a horror game, as it isn't really about the scares. Although there weren't really any scares, now that I think about it. I would categorize it as a supernatural thriller of sorts.Game play is super cool and different. It plays somewhat like a FPS/RPG blend, with a couple of added features here and there that were refreshing to me.I loved the play on light/dark, etc. Cool themes. Honestly, my only complaint with this game is the plot. Could have been super cool, instead plays more like a kinda cool story.So play it for what was to me a unique gaming experience, with super interesting graphics and atmosphere. Don't go in expecting a superb story, a la Red Dead Redemption or Bioshock.7/10, would recommend.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												85%Alan Wake is an amazing game, very well written and with a great ambience and characters, however that doesn't mean it's perfect.First of gameplay, the basic combat mechanic for fighting is very interesting at first, basically you need to use a flashlight to drain the enemy's "shields" until you are able to take him down with a gun, but over the course of the game it grows a bit stale and repetitive, with little to no change at all. Trying the different weapons and traps whoever is pretty fun, you'll spend a lot of time trying to find creative ways to take down your enemies, although sometimes it is better to run. Ammo is scarce, which is nice for a thriller game and the way the story develops in game is pretty interesting (like finding the pages).Now for story, this is where the game truly shines. It's incredible, worthy of a book even. Wake's story place nicely as a psychological action thriller that is well paced and keeps you engaged, the game also features some pretty interesting plot twists, making even the chapters in between battles pretty thrilling. The dialogue and characters are very well written, I can even recall several quotes now.If you are a fan of Stephen King esque novels than this is the game for you, sometimes it may grow repetitive but that can be easily forgiving by the engaging story and amazing atmosphere.Alan Wake is a game that proves to be more than what it seems, truly defining that "It is not a lake, it's an ocean".

content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												This is an amazing game in most aspects. The style of story telling is very unique in video games, and I loved it. The main character is a writer, and his horror stories are coming true. I loved seeing the other real life characters slowly realize that they were in a land of fiction, one of the greatest strengths of the story is that you never really know if you are in the real world or not. The plot is basically the light vesus the dark. The visuals are very nice, and the distortion caused by the darkness taking over is done well. The combat is unique and for the most part good. You must use your flashlight (or someother light source) to kill the darkness around the enemies, and then shoot them to actually kill them for good. It gets a bit repetitive, and can be awkward in close quarters. In the later half of the game, driving becomes more prevelent, which is bad because the cars handle like bathtubs. This game is also frequently only three dollars, and its easly worth it then. It took me about 14 hours to finish the entire story, including the "special" episodes, so its a decently long game. (And I was not looking for every collectable, I only got maybe half of them.)Pros: +Story+Graphics+Atmosphere+Characters+Discounted priceNeutral:*Majority of the combat*ReplayabiltyBad:-Close quarters combat-Driving (Though it is satisfying driving over the dark ones with a car...)Overall: 8.5/10 Buy this game while its on sale.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												This is a brilliantly constructed horror-themed game. Now mind you, when I use 'horror' I'm talking more like a Stephen King thriller novel. It's not terrifying or gruesome and probably won't leave you awake through the night wondering if that creature under your bed or in your closet is going to come out to drag it's nails across your eyelids. Instead, this is a well-written story very much in the same vein as many famous 'horror' writers, told in an interactive way.   It's very much a survival game that will leave you desperately budgeting your ammunition and light source and hoping you can dodge and run your way through packs of monsters. The combat is clever, although I did find it hard at times and found myself repeating areas with some frustration. The graphics are beautiful and our byronic protagonist evolves through the game as the events unfold around him, leaving you surprisingly attached to someone who seemed initially so unlikeable. Many of the mechanics are clever and unexpected, particularly in the DLC.  Overall, I enjoyed this game thoroughly and it stands on my shelf as one of my favourites, next to the likes of a completely different take on horror, Silent Hill 2. The story is intriguing and the world is immersive and filled with nods to horror stories most of us know at least enough to get the reference. I eagerly await the next installation.

content:

												This game excels in many ways and in short -- you should buy it.Most captivating is the atmosphere. This game was developed by Microsoft and it is very apparent that they took inspiration from their home state of Washington. The vast temperate rain forests containing abundant lakes coupled with cloudy skies truly strengthen the setting. Taking on a vibe of mystery and horror the story of Alan Wake is also quite interesting. I'll be honest I mostly play games for the story much like one would read a book or watch a movie. In this regard Alan Wake was incredibly fun but at times I also found myself "grinding" through the game in a sense, wishing to simply continue the story. I suffered from one or two "rage quit" moments but ultimately pressed on and I am glad I did. Another refreshing strength of this game is the unique gameplay. The combination of the flashlight weaponry with unique puzzles and challenges is very refreshing compared to other games and made the game less monotonous. All in all, while not perfect, Alan Wake is a very enjoyable game and everyone should play through it once.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												Alan Wake is what you get if you take a Stephen King novel and put it in a town oddly reminiscent of Twin Peaks. It weaves a great narrative around some tight third person shooter gameplay that stays satisfying to the conclusion of the main game. Just like a serialized TV drama, each episode ends on a cliffhanger leading to a cutscene with credits, and each episode begins with a "last time on Alan Wake" synopsis. That by itself would probably be irritating to some, but the way the story is told works great with that kind of episodic pace.It'll probably last you about a dozen hours if you play through once, with maybe another 2-4 hours tacked on if you play the DLC (free with the PC version). Although the game doesn't run into the issue that other games do of feeling "too long," I did get fatigued by the time I was nearing the end of my first playthrough; I'll admit that could have been because I played this at release on the 360, though, so your mileage may vary. The narrative continuation in the DLC is fantastic, as are the new visual elements brought about by nature of where it takes place, but both pieces suffer from way too much frustrating combat. The second piece also suffers from particularly frustrating bits of "platforming," which don't work well at all.Not a huge deal looking at the bigger picture, however, so if you're looking to play a well made horror game that isn't bogged down by awful combat for once, this is it!

												Truthfully, I didn't know what to expect when I first got into Alan Wake.  It looked like your standard "point-flashlight and run" sort of horror game.  I was pleasantly surprised, however.  Here is my rundown:Graphics:I am getting this out of the way as quickly as possible.  The game looks absolutely stunning.  The atmosphere is great, and the lighting features are wonderful.  You instantly know where to go when you see lighting.  I loved how this game looked.  Gameplay: Very unique.  Unveiling messages with the flashlight was a great idea.  Likewise, certain puzzles were done fantastically. However, it was an enjoyable experience, even up to the end of the game.  Storyline:  Pretentious.  Very pretentious.  However, Alan Wake is a writer.  He will never let you forget that he is a writer, so the player shouldn't be surprised when the game has a very overly-artistic and dramatic feel to it.  It's annoying, at times, but not overtly so.  The game is great for what it is.  I'd highly recommend it for a playthrough.  You might find yourself getting tired of the repetition towards the end, but the payoff is very worth it. content:
Posted: October 12, 2014
												This is an intriguing game. You play as Alan Wake, a best-selling author and the main protagonist in a story straight from the imaginings of a horror novel. It's dark, suspenseful and engaging; most of the action takes place at night, with a bias towards shadowy atmospherics and a distinct contrast between light and dark. It breaks "good" and "evil" down to the most basic concept of "light" being "good" and "darkness" being "evil"; the darkness is your enemy and it brings dangers that will kill you, while light usually represents a safe haven. Your greatest weapon is usually your torch (closely followed by a revolver, rifle or shotgun!) - flares and flashbangs are also put to creative use.The gameplay is relatively simple, being story-led and therefore fairly linear. There is not much scope for exploration/deviation from the given path, but the storyline is immersive enough that it keeps you interested. There are many hidden items to be found throughout the game, though there is not much in the way of problem solivng. Combat is straightforward enough; an interesting concept is having to "burn" the darkness out of an attacker using a torch or light source before using your gun to kill what is left. The weapon selection is very limited, but realistic as the whole game is set within the small mountain town of Bright Falls. This game stands on its atmospherics. Play it at night with the lights switched off and no distractions and you'll find yourself inexorably drawn into the nightmare Alan Wake finds himself stranded in. Is he crazy or is this stuff real? Sometimes it is hard to tell and you find yourself constantly questioning what is going on. It can be tense, creepy and dreamlike, all at the same time. The story becomes more and more involved the further you get into it, but this does mean that, at times, it gets convoluted or downright confusing. The ending doesn't make a whole lot of sense to be honest, but I'll give the game the benefit of the doubt and say that it probably helps to play it through a second time as it may make more sense when you've fully grasped the concepts of the game. This game is all about story and atmosphere. There is little in the way of puzzle solving, nor is the combat particularly challenging. There are no "big boss" type fights that can't be beaten easily in the same manner as regular foes. I played it through to the end, and while I enjoyed the game, I was left feeling slightly dissatisfied as it didn't feel like everything had been properly concluded. That may be intentional but it leaves you feeling a little short, with unresolved questions. It was an enjoyable play, however, an easy game to get to grips with and an interesting, if sometimes bemusing, story. I would recommend this to anyone who is looking for something engaging and an interesting distraction from the norm.

												I quite liked this - the story is solid, and does make it feel pretty much like you are the protagonist in a Stephen King novel or similar (especially with you being a frustrated author). The mechanic of having the enemies damaged/stunned by the light helps the atmosphere, and gives plenty of excuses to have you creeping through darkened houses, woods and abandoned industrial buildings, which always makes for a good basis for a horror game. The third person over the shoulder perspective is personally not something I favour generally, as it always feels clunky and unimmersive to me, but I didn't find it as bad as many other games that use this perspective at least.The game works especially well in the beginning when the enemies are sparse and new. As the chapters of the story pass however, the combat/non-story related parts of the game become less compelling and a bit more "filler" like - this is obviously a common issue with horror themed games, whereas in a 90 minute movie or a book you can have just a few attacks on the protagonist, a game like thus runs much longer and you end up having to deal with many more rounds of threats to deal with. Once you have killed dozens of the same shadowy crazed attackers it does turn the game into a bit of a chore - the story remains solid enough, and progresses reasonably until you get to a combat section where you have to grind your way through a fairly boring stretch of road/woods/whatever dispatching wave after wave of now tedious enemies you have seen a hundred times before, just to "earn" the next interesting bit of story advancement.Still overall worth playing, but a shame that the promise of the early sections of the game is spoiled by this method of stretching out the content.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Alan Wake - Remedy's PasticheHave you ever put down a good psychological horror book and wished you could experience similar thrills in video game form? Well, there are plenty of options for that, but here is Remedy (developer of Max Payne and its sequel The Fall of Max Payne) and their take on the genre. While far from a horror classic, Alan Wake provides enough thrills and atmosphere to prop up the mysterious, and rather compelling, story.The player controls titular character Alan Wake, a successful novelist who finds himself traveling with his wife Alice to the Pacific Northwest in order to break a drought of writing inspiration. The setup instantly draws comparisons to other works, such as Twin Peaks and The Shining, giving the game an instant feeling of familiarity, yet still retaining that feeling of mystery and intrigue. What follows from this setup are even more recognizable tropes (quirky locals, mysterious woods, marital disagreements) which all come together to form an impressive and memorable narrative, however forceful and contrived it gets. The game splits itself into "episodes" (ala a tv show, complete with previously ons and next time ons) which allows the game to set into a nice pacing, however predictably each one has to find new ways to throw Alan into the woods to contend with evil forces.The gameplay continues the trend of familiarity, borrowing heavily from other shooter/horror games. The gunplay is recognizably Resident Evil 4, however looser and faster. Alan Wake may be a writer, however he seems to know his way around firearms quite extensively, though it's only through the game's sole unique mechanic, does he shine. In order to mow down enemies with your arsenal of guns, Alan must make use of his trusty flashlight (powered by real brand Duracell batteries!) and stun enemies with it until their shroud of darkness disapates, leaving them open to bullets. If low on (Duracell brand) batteries and (non affilated brand) ammo, Alan has the option of dodging enemy attacks and running in the opposite direction, however on Normal difficutly, with enough exploring and well placed shots, one should never have much issue with lack of resources.  While fun and novel at first, the game never really adds anything past the flashlight mechanic, which after its surprisingly long campaign (11-13 hours), it starts to see diminishing returns rather quickly, thus the game loses quite a bit of tension and becomes more predictable.Originally an XBox360 exclusive, the game was ported to PC several years after its release (in order to recoup a 5 year development budget), including all the the DLC. The game seemed well optimized and I ran into minimal issues in terms of bugs and graphical glitches, as well as an acceptable amount of graphical options, which is always appareciated in this day of rushed and shoddy console ports. While flawed, Alan Wake is ultimately a game worth picking up, even at its full price. While the gameplay begins to stale in the later hours of the game, there is always a well done cutscene or interesting collectable around the corner to alleviate some of that boredom. If anything, its another portal into the mind of writer Sam Lake (who also was the creative mind behind the first two Max Payne games), who proves to be a capable and inventive storyteller.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2015
												Alan Wake is a really enjoyable survival "horror" game. The way the game is presented (as a TV show) actually fits perfectly into the quality of the story. It's a made for TV kind of scary, and that's not a bad thing. Every horror game doesn't need to be a scary as possible or a total gore fest. There is nothing wrong with more mild scares & the use of suspense to create tention. Though I only have 3+ hours in the Steam version, I played it all the way through on the 360. (Holy Crap does the 360 version run like assy-poo-poo)Score: 7.5/10Pros:-Engaging story-Well done voice acting-scares that aren't just cheap/lame jump scares-quality suspense-beautiful lighting effects-impressive & atmospheric visuals/graphics-fun story-fun/funny/interesting NPC'sCons:-irritating combat (not broken or anything just frustrating sometimes)- Uninspired enemies (ooooh smoke Zombie people, so origional)-too many collectables-one or two of the NPCs are obnoxious (your agent Dave for example)-bland weapons (not necessarily the games fault, it is set in the "real" world.Alan Wake is definitely worth picking up. Not at full price but anything under $20 is a worthwhile proposition. This is a great survival horror game for "beginners", kids, or anyone very easily scared. It looks great, it has a fun story & over all good voice work. By no means is Alan Wake perfect, but its fun and worth you time at the right price. Only the meanest, most bitter gamers wouldn't enjoy playing this game. Give it a shot. If you hate it, feel free to come back to my comment & yell @ me. With refunds now being a thing, you have nothing to lose. You'll know if you're gonna like it before 2 hours.

content:
Posted: February 18, 2016
												Finished, but only because of the story. It's actually quite good. As many have said, it's like Stephen King meets Twin Peaks. I can even overlook the uncanny valley mannequins in the cut scenes with weird sync issues between their speech and how their mouths move.The main problem is that the story is trapped inside an unremarkable game. I understand that Alan is a writer not a fighter. (And sadly not much of a runner either; is he really that out of shape?) So why build a game around him where he constantly has to shoot things to stay alive? The flashlight is cool. The gun play is mediocre at best and gets quickly repetitive.SPOILER: Ninety-percent of Episode Six is a long drive/run through the woods at night with enemies jumping you every few minutes until you reach the story's resolution. They should have made Episode Five twenty minutes longer and wrapped it up as there is no more story between the end of it and finally reaching the lake in Ep Six.I didn't bother with the DLC, and based on what I've read of the follow-on-not-sequel American Nightmare, I'm going to skip it too.If I was re-imagining this game from a different angle I'd have it be a Telltale game with branching narrative and the flashlight would be your primary weapon for killing the Taken. That seems like a far better fit instead of confining a story that could have been even more detailed inside a lame shooter.Rating: 6/10Recommended if you are big fan of horror fiction as that's the only thing it has going for it.

Posted: February 2, 2016
												Your most powerful weapon will only be the light. And you'll love being in the light, in this game.Enter Bright Falls, enter in the darkness. This game's atmosphere is just fantastic. There's a dark secret behind every corner, into the woods, even in the animals. The darkness takes the lead every minute of this game. Your name is Alan Wake, a famous writer of thriller books, with a little limiting problem: He can't write anymore, not a single word. He goes in a vacation with his wife, Alice, in Bright Falls, where's all apparently calm and quiet. But when the black lady shows up in the cottage they're staying and kidnaps Alan's wife, the horror story Alan used to write become real. And he's the protagonist.Fight against the dark, fight for your wife, fight against yourself.I loved this game minute by minute, and i'd strongly recommend it. 10/10.

content:
Posted: January 29
												I found the gameplay (especially first 15 hours) and story very dull but to be fair I am not kinda into this kind of games.  I am recommending this cos its a very good game with graphics still looking good like it was released in 2016.Gameplay is quite good and fun but repetetive, using flashlight to destroy the "shadow shield" of enemies to then finish them off with a gun. Unfortuned this game suffers from pretty bad problem that is variety or more like a lack of it. You weapon variety, enemy variety and locations that you gonna visit are quite boring and limited. Especially that this game is around 20 hours long and I don't know like you but its not fun to use same 3 guns to kill same 4 types of enemies whole time.Zero puzzles or doing anything other than walking forward and shooting, maybe sometimes driving for 30 seconds before you have to leave the car behind you.The story is really average. I understand that they tried to make it more like Stephen King with corny and cliche monsters, dialogue and other stuff, but  it have Stephen King's level of  stupid, confusing story with all plot holes, twists and all you actually do is walking from point A to point B while trying to "fight the dark", "find your wife" and discover that Silent Hill 2 did a similiar and way better story twist than this game. Also The Clicker is probably the most stupid MacGuffin ever. Not to mention how stupid and pathethit is that excuse for a finale boss. All you do is take flare gun, ammo from bottomless box and shoot 4 times into a tornado. I am dead serious. That is your reward for finishing the game. A fight with a tornado that takes less than 20 seconds  Its just nothing special about it and most of the time you probably end up skiping another none important and boring cutscene than watching it. The biggest problem in that you can't skip ANY dialogue and very often you gonna be forced for slow walking exposition. For people who hate collectibles - better avoid Alan Wake. You gonna collect a lot of stuff. Like a LOT. Also most of story is actually hidden behind finding manuscripts.I always put story in video games on the bottom of my list because I am into a good gameplay first, thats why I enjoyed Alan Wake gunplay so much. Its just that I didn't enjoyed the story to the point that I wanted to gave up on playing it but I finish it while repeating to myself "this is so stupid" many times. I still don't understand why everybody is keep telling me how Alan Wake story is so good. I just don't get it - its cliche, predictable and not much important for a player considering you just go forward from point A to point B. Oh well, thats just my opinion. Anyway I ofc recommend this game cos its very good and you can get it on 90% sale quite often. Give it a try.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												I described this game to a friend as the love child of early Max Payne games and movie The Ring. While that's too simplistic of a characterization, it should nevertheless give you a basic idea of how everything plays out. From the outstanding design of the characters, each of which you will develop a connection with, to the simultaneously serene and terrifying portrayal of the Pacific Northwest, this is arguably Remedy's best cinematic gaming experience to date. The only gripe some might have is the combat system, which does take a while to get used to and might frustrate some players in the earlier levels. Stick with it though, as you become more proficient with the controls it will make every hostile encounter and progression through the varied levels an anxiety inducing ordeal in which every bullet, flashlight battery, and any other necessity must be used sparingly to ensure your survival. I have never felt the magnitude of relief and satisfaction this game provides in successfully moving forward in any other title. Follow the light (hah!) and get this game. Quick edit: By the way, this game has the best use of licensed music I've ever seen. Some of the song choices will leave a serious impression on you. So good.

												   Absolutely worth trying out. The game delivers about 10 hours of gameplay (for me), with the 2 DLC-s, adding 1-1 hour of it. The atmosphere of the game is great, the play with the light is absolutely wonderful.    The combat sometimes can be a little boring, and repetitive, but the story and narrating compensates for it. The 2. and 3. episode was a bit slow, and became boring sometimes for me, but after that, I had not a moment lacking of joy. I liked the storytelling very much, the episodic construction was something I haven't seen in a while, although from this follows, that it's mostly linear, however, I didn't feel the urge to start and go exploring. It was great as it was. You just get sunk in the story, and don't want to stop playing the game.   Apart from everything, a little negativity came from the graphics. The light/dark schemes were awesome, but sometimes there were some sloppy textures, although this isn't really a big problem, since most of the time, it's non-visible.   I'd give the game a total of 8/10 in my opinion, so it's definitely a game you should try out.
