This is my opinion of Alan Wake   Aspect Rating   Story 8.5   Graphics 8.0   Sound 9.5   Gameplay 8.0   Overall 8.5 Scores are out of 10. Overall score is an average Remedy has built a world that, despite being a fantastical realm of twisting shadows and realities, is solidly anchored in authenticity. Outstanding environmental design and some brilliant visuals and sound make Bright Falls and its mountainous surroundings look and feel alive. Even the minor flaws are forgivable when you soak in the heady ambiance and get caught up in the foreboding current of this spook story. Killer storytelling, creative combat, and some of the slickest horror atmosphere you can find in a game make this supernatural showdown a memorable excursion to the dark side.

												...Resident Evil, Twilight Zone, Evil Dead, Creepshow, Silent Hill, The Fog, Stephen King, Twin Peaks... these are all references and similiarities tied to the incredible story involving Alan Wake.  This interesting 3rd person game is a adventure based shooter played mostly in the dark confines of the Pacific Northwest.  There is a lot of fog and forest about, the scenery and visuals are top notch.  On a high end rig this has to look fabulous as on my modest system it looks great.  The sound and voice acting are great as well and includes James McCaffrey from Max Payne fame.  Speaking of Max Payne, Alan Wake is a spinoff from the writer of MP - Sam Lake.  There are a lot of Easter Eggs in this game and tie ins to the media I listed above.  If you like story based adventure games pick this up.  It can be rather slow and controls take some practice, bear in mind this is a more casual laid back game with a few hair raising turns inside awaiting your discovery!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Very very very good port. One of the best ones out there.The video settings are as follows:Graphic QualityAntialiasingFXAA QualityAntisotropic FilteringShadow QualitySSAO QualityBackdrop QualityGodray QualityVolumetric Light QualityDraw DistanceNeed I say more? The game is gorgeous.In general, the original engine created by Remedy which is supported by the Havoc engine is pretty neat. The physics is worked out, the lighting is vibrant, the distant fog is pretty volumetric, the textures are smooth and realistic although the face characters and face expressions can get quite silly and not fully be fleshed out.As for the gameplay, well, I am finally able to easily avoid getting hit in the head with hammers, axes, crowbars and other similar household items. I am able to do so because I can finally evade successfully, something that I was not able to fully master on a controller, which is not the fault of the controller but my own. The taken (your foes) are still able to outrun you and surround you constantly so the game constantly forces you to fight back with vigor. You cannot jump high, which is realistic and you get tired faster than in any other game. Three hits to the head on Hard mode and you are dead. There are no med-kits so you recover health by being illuminated by light, any light.Anyway, by this time I assume most people have heard what the game is about so I'll spare further reading. You are a writer who shows signs of his waning ability to write successfully. He decides to go to a resort to attempt to mentally recover however he soon discovers that there is some kind of battle going on between the malevolent and the benevolent forces in the area. Later on, he starts to doubt his sanity and goes on a quest to find out what really is going on. By the end of the game I personally still had no idea what happened. The DLC's did not help to solve the story either. Anyway it's a nice attempt at creating a somewhat vague story on behalf of the developers but I still had no idea wtf happened.The game is filled with Easter eggs, reference to other icons of American pop culture, miscellaneous videos, paradoxes, logical dilemmas, etc.In the end, let us all thank Microsoft for postponing this game for as long as possible for us humble PC folk, so we could buy their xbox instead. My hat goes off to those who resisted and waited.Now for that Red Dead Redemption game....

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												The best horror game I have played since Amnesia. The game is a third person shooter that takes place mainly in the forest and follows the trends of a horror book. The game is influenced heavily by Steven King and even makes references to him from time to time. The story is about this man Alan Wake, a famous writer who can't seem to write another page. Him and his wife go on vacation and she tries to get him to write again, immediately after his wife disappears and everything turns all strange and monsters start coming. The game is about 8-10 hours long with no multiplayer but two DLC that you had to pay for on Xbox but we get right away for free. The graphics in the game are pretty good and is pretty optimized. The developer did a very good job porting this game to PC. One of my favourite things in this game is the attention to detail with the collectibles. One of the things you can do is watch episodes of a fictional show in the universe that is similar to the episodes of The Twilight Zone. The detail is great and I personally sat through each of the episodes that I found and enjoyed each one. Another great collectible that the game had was manuscript for Alan's work. The writing is fantastic and was an extremely rewarding collectible so I strongly recommend that you explore these great environments to find each one. The light mechanics in Alan Wake are really well done and the system that makes the game feel like a television series is excellent. Each chapter is treated like a new episode to a TV show that you tune in to watch every week even with the "Previously On Alan Wake" section at the beginning. I can't wait for a sequel to this game and I can recommend this game to anyone who enjoys an excellent storyline in a thriller/adventure game. 90/100

 To find the light you must dive into the darkness Alan Wake has been delivered to us in 2010 and still manages to be a pearl in an ocean of similar releases.As you embody the best seller writer Alan Wake, you will gradually discover the misteries surrounding Bright Falls, an apparently friendly country town.From the first moments of the game, you will realise how apparences are mere masks that hide the truth.Armed with a flashlight, guns and flares, Alan will become part of this mistery.Alan Wake mixes and perfectly blends various genres: horror, shooter, puzzle, telltale. This mixture is all linked thanks to an involving atmosphere and such a brilliant use of every media aspect (the OST is actually part of the plot, not to mention Poets of the Fall as singers).All the hidden collectibles, references, side-games and achievements enhance and enforce the replayability factor.What I really love of Alan Wake is the complex plot; without getting into details and possible spoilers, I can tell it feels like watching and controlling a very well done adaptation of a great book.The graphic engine helps to get into Bright Falls, even though some motion captures could have been better (not complaining, considering it is a 2010 release).The only small complain (more like a personal opinion) I could make concerns the controls and the camera view: in tight places and among many enemies it can be a bit of a challenge to move around without falling or bumping over an obstacle, but again, it's just a subjective view, and not really affecting that much the gameplay.There is no reason why I should not recommend Alan Wake; every type of gamer can play it with satisfactory results. It's that kind of game you wish could never have an end.

 A Narrative Horror Story What To Expect From This Game?This game is highly referenced as a book, which itself is divided into chapters. While exploring the detailed, graphical scenery and locations throughout the game, the player will be faced to encounter the darkness of the character's imagination or reality. The darkness iteself will try to consume the player and release spawns of evil lumberjacks to hunt the player thoughout the chapters. While surviving through the hordes of lumberjacks and dodging the darkness, there are several collectables to obtain throughout the game.What Are The Pros Of This Game?  Great Graphics (Environment, Scenery, Characters)  Good Story/Plot  Good Soundtrack  Day/Night Cycles  Nature/Ambience  Good Voice ActingWhat Are The Cons Of This Game?  Repetitive Gameplay  Poor AI  Bad Controls (Character Movement)  Poor Horror Aspects (No Thrillers or Scares)  Linear Level Designs  Limited Items & EnemiesWould You Recommend This Game?No, I do not. This game has a lot of potential to be a good Horror game, but does not deliver. I enjoyed the scenic visuals, the detailed character and object designs, but it was ruined by the linear level layouts that did not enable the player to explore the world itself. While playing this game, it was hard not to compare similarities of the story or characters to another game such as "Silent Hill." Although the game has superior graphics than most "Silent Hill" titles, this game lacks of the mystery, puzzles and horror. The repetitive gameplay and objectives is the decisive factor for not recommending this game. **(This game needs help from the "Modding Community", to make it more enjoyable and scary.) Is It Real Or A Fantasy???

												I really thought I was going to play this game and love it, but it's disappointingly bad. Especially after looking at all the high ratings it has pretty much everywhere. I'm not even done with "Episode 2" and I'm thinking about putting it down for good.First of all the combat feels awful. If you need to create distance between you and some shadow things, you can't outrun them even at a full ♥♥♥♥ing sprint, so I have to wonder why there's an option to sprint at all, because you'll turn around and they'll be right on your♥♥♥♥♥waiting to take a swing. This makes fighting more than one mob a headache-inducing experience because the only way to make distance is to backpedal and shine your light, hoping nothing comes up from behind or you don't have your back to a cliff. Alan can't seem to load his weapon and run at the same time even in life threatening situations, which adds to the clunky feel of combat all the more.Doing something as simple as exploring is tedious because every time you think about looking for some scraps of paper or coffee you're thinking how annoying it will be to deal with those shadow people that will undoubtedly ambush you 10 times while you're searching. Part of the fun I have with games like this is the exploration and getting a chance to look at the atmosphere, but maybe that's just me. But no huge loss, I wasn't really reading those papers anyway, because some of them are only available on nightmare difficulty, so it feels ultimately pointless because you're not going to collect them all the first time through anyway."Boss" fights are a cake walk, especially after having to deal with being swarmed every time you take 2 steps in the woods. The boss doesn't really make you feel threatened or limited because there always seems to be a huge crate full of seemingly endless ammo refills sitting around, which you can pretty much stand next to and take a breather because the bosses don't do anything special other than teleport around and make themselves easy targets.The game feels the need to start a new chapter(or "Episode") with "PREVIOUSLY ON ALAN WAKE..." as if you were watching the new episode of a TV series, even if you just finished the last chapter and started the new one without delay. Oh yes, I really needed a refresher on that thing I spent the past 30 minutes doing. Thank you, that was necessary. Couple that with ridiculously bad typos I've found while bothering to read all of the signs I come across and I feel like I would be embarrased to have to admit I was a writer for this game.Finally, you can't at all identify with dear Alan. He's just kind of an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ "celebrity" special snowflake who acts like everyone around him is a nuisance, including his wife, so it's really hard to care what happens to either of them. I genuinely have no drive to finish this game.It's just bad.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Well, I got this game on sale, of course, because that's how you use Steam. I was pretty excited to play this weird psychological thriller about a guy trapped in his own book or something, but that's all I know about the story, since I didn't get too far in before I got tired of the whole thing.The thing is, I want to enjoy this game, but it's hard to bring myself to do so. The gameplay seems straightforward enough, the story's pretty interesting from what I've seen of it, plus I like weird things. I wouldn't mind seeing a little more of the characters in the little town, but maybe I didn't play long enough to get sick of them, I don't know if that's a common complaint or not. Maybe I'll just settle for a Let's Play or something, because a lot of my complaints are with the actual gameplay.I understand it's like survival horror, you have limited supplies and the better strategy is to pick flight over fight if you can instead of mowing everything down. You can aim, but not really. You only seem to aim at the same time you're using your flashlight, and that drains its battery, so you're going to end up in situations where you're wasting it on an enemy who's already lost their darkness shield or whatever while you're just trying to shoot them. Meanwhile, you can't see what's right next to you while doing so and that ends up in a close enemy taking off half your health, probably. Sure, you can dodge, but you're likely to just dodge into another enemy who hits you as soon as you get out of the dodge. I also understand you're not a super soldier so your combat capabilities are limited. Still, if the game managed to control a little bit better, it'd be a lot more playable. If it decided on being either an action shooter or a survival horror more solidly, too, then maybe the controls would be a little more focused as well.I'll also state I've tried this game on both Normal and Easy with the mouse/keyboard and controller, respectively. Somehow, I managed to get further on Normal with the supposed inferior mouse/keyboard setup than on Easy with the controller, yet I ran into the same problems in both playthroughs. You'd think things would be a lot smoother combining the easiest mode with the best controls. Apparently not. Or maybe I'm just really bad at games, I don't know, but I know I've beaten quite a few, so it can't be entirely that, right?If you get into the nitpicking, I found it hard to run this several year old game with a good framerate without turning down all of the settings most of the way. I'll admit that I'm not running any super machines here, but it seems a little not optimized. I got the framerate to be playable, though, at least, just not 30/60 FPS or whatever. Also, there's bits of product placement here and there, but I can look past that. Same goes for the weird pre-rendered but in-engine(?) cutscenes with awkward animations. It's also easy to get lost, but not in the best way. You don't have much of a minimap to go by, but really, it's a horror situation, you're supposed to feel lost. I've played other games with those problems before, but it's really the controls and the game not knowing what it wants to be other than what it'd be good at that gets to me.Bottom line is if you're into small-town personal psychological horror stories but can tolerate not very good controls and sort of indecisive gameplay, and are also probably a better game player than I am, maybe get this for under $5. If not, then... maybe not. Funny thing is, I somehow prefer the original Deadly Premonition with its tank controls, abundant QTEs, and other imperfections, and I even have trouble playing that for extended periods sometimes.

												I might be in the minority when I say this but I really didn't like this game. First off I didn't really know what to expect when I purchased this title on sale only that it had nice atmospheric graphics and good reviews. I thought it was going to be a survival horror type game but I was sadly dissapointed. What kind of game is it? I have no clue. I think what the developers were trying to aim for was a "Indigo Prophecy"/"Heavy Rain" experience but falls short in terms of story and character development. You play as Alan Wake who's a reporter on vacation with his wife and she goes missing. He tries to hunt down her kidnapper while strange things occur in the small town. Sounds like a promising start but there are a few problems. The main character narrates the events happening around him and how he feels as if he was reading from one of his novels. The way the story is told feels artificial and poorly written as if you were reading a short story from a kid in high school. Constantly having to hear what he's thinking plus reading the "manuscript" pages he finds which explains things we've already seen gets really annoying. It also sounds like a cliche plot which ends up having you think the whole thing he's going through is fabricated in his crazy mind.The characters don't have well...any character. They're so hollow. Your wife goes missing, so what? I only knew her in the game for like 10 mins. The main guy Alan Wake has the dumbest robotic look on his face and his voice sounds whiny. The other NPCs have about 2 or 3 lines and when the town goes crazy with paranormal events you don't really care about what happens to them.Gameplay is just as bad. You walk around, talk to people then nightmare world. In nightmare world shadow figures chase you. You shine a flashlight in their face then shoot them when their defenses are down. Rinse and repeat. The combat (if you can call it that) is robotic as Alan Wake's face and not very exciting after the second encounter. Don't get me started on Alan Wake's cardio. I think the writers forgot to explain in the game how he smokes 10 packs a day as he can't run for more then 3 seconds before getting gassed.With the amount of detail and graphics they have in the game engine it could've been a really nice title had they aimed for better gameplay as in Silent Hill. Made it scary and really mess with your senses putting you in constant fear of what's in the dark forest. Or made a story rich games with likeable or even relatable characters like Indigo Prophecy. But instead, this isn't an adventure game, not a survival horror, not scary, not exciting. I don't even know what I paid 5 bucks for.

												Alan Wake is an episodic, third person shooter with traces of psychological horror elements at times. I like this game a lot. The episodic format makes it easy to take breaks between play sessions (each "episode" even starts with a "...previously, on Alan Wake"). The graphics are verry pretty and looks like the team really put time and effort in porting the game. Same can be said for the sound effects and the music.Gameplay wise, it's a TPS with an interesting mechanic - the enemies are defeted by first shining a light on them (Alan is using a battery powered flashlight), destroying the "darkness" surrounding the enemies and only after that you are able to shoot and destroy them.The part I enjoyed the most was the story - it feels like an actual TV show, but with a great plot and plot twists. It can take a bit of time to chew through all the info you are presented with at times but it all makes sense and leaves you longing for more.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2015
												#1: Game says I don't meet the minimum requirements. How a 3.5ghtz dual core doesn't meet the minimum requirements of a 2ghtz dual core... I don't know. Combined with a Geforce GTX 560Ti, I shouldn't have had problems.#2: The characters look like absolute crap when they talk or move, like someone's first GMod animation on Youtube.#3: I hate narration being used as a tool to prod the story and this game is practically bursting with the stuff. You pick up items that the game seriously wants you to read in an investigation mindset and the character kicks on some kind of "I AM AN ACTOR!" voice for it. So I don't read them. Put the game trailer on loop and you'll feel what I feel.#4: Why is this presented in episodes? WHY ARE THERE EPISODE RECAPS!?? I WAS JUST THERE, I WAS PLAYING THIS GAME A MINUTE AGO. You're wrecking immersion thinking it gets you some sort of style points.#5: I was a night security guard and expected to get some thrill out of the darkness, but I was rather more annoyed by the 'burst' flashlight gimmick when you get 3-5 enemies. Replacing a battery doesn't actually give you full charge, it gives you a boosted recharge w/o a delay. Batteries are given like candy but not that useful... and yet you can reload a gun and a flashlight at the same time during combat.#6: The achievements want you to find manuscripts, coffee thermoses, and hidden caches of items. There are traps that have the same 'glimmer' visual effect as the manuscripts. Exploring in the dark, you're often constantly attacked, and the paths aren't very obvious. After the first couple of hidden cache's in the first episode, you get start getting attacked in every dead-end hidden cache area... and usually by a large mob. I mean, "Thanks for these 2 flares and couple of bullets, I've got to spend them all on this trap I walked into to get the next percent of this achievment." What's the point? Just padding out the game time.#7: Seems that every cut scene, your character blacks out and looses all his equipment. Have to start from scratch and get a new, weak flashlight and gun. After the 3rd-4th time, Wake should consider looting a pistol holster or something. This fills me with anger because of how much time I spent looking for caches and being frugal with ammo, only to have it taken at the end of the area.

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
												- Gorgeous visuals: Great play of light and dark, some stunning idyllic mountain-ish background settings (see screenshots/videos)- Interesting theme. City dude with writer's block going on vacation in remote town which is being taken over by an omnious dark presence controlling people and things; battle between dark and light; a lot of psychologial mindplay and questioning whether it is all actually happening or not; manuscript pages scattered around that describe the events before Wake has them happening to him and the townsfolk.- Game is designed like an episodic TV thriller. Theme is packed into a damsel-in-distress story which is not totally chliché all over, but I don't know, is love the only thing that keeps heroes going on in fiction? There is more to life than that, there are other ambitions and there can be more reasoning. But I guess it serves as some kind of red thread.- Gameplay has interesting ideas: Getting attacked by dark figures from multiple sides in small spaces, dodging their attacks (melee mostly), "burning" away the darkness that has captured them with a flashlight and shooting them, using other light sources for area-of-effect attacks or as defense barriers and seeking them as beacons of hope and restoration. Sometimes however it felt repetitive and (on my difficulty setting) too easy in it's execution. The game wants you to feel constantly haunted by the dark presence, there sure is enough action, but once you understand how to dodge and fight the enemies there is some lack of challenge, and with it the feel of being threatened boils down somewhat.- Settings sometimes become rather repetitive too. Many levels play in rather dense forest and rural areas. Which makes sense gameplay- and (I assume) geographical-wise. Most enemies attack you with melee, they would pose no threat if they were engaging visibly from longer ranges, but sometimes it felt a bit tedious and I just wanted to get out of those forests. Or maybe that was (at least partly) the feeling the devs were intending to create?- The game comes with some bonus "episodes" originally released as DLCs on the Xbox. They were very entertaining and refreshing, they advance the story further, add more interesting mindplay ideas and also bring in some refreshments gameplay-wise (you interact more with your surroundings, "summon" objects and light sources, not easy to explain but makes a lot of sense in the context of the story and mindplay.Overall a nice-looking, thoughtfully crafted and well optimized (it was running like a charm on my computer) episodic story-driven action thriller with an appealing "hero", some interesting gameplay ideas and some noteable music too (rock band Poets of the Fall has provided some tracks with perfectly fitting lyrics, and those songs are cleverly put into the game as there is a "rock band" (two old geezers somewhat past beyond their time) in it too loosely resembling PotF.

If you like writers as Lovecraft or games as Silent Hill, avoid this shamefull homage of writers craft and its simple manichaeism at any price.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2016
												7 Things not to do when you are making a video game.1. Dumb collectables. If you are going to make people collect something in a game, give them a reason to do so. Don't make collectables for the sake of making them. It is unimmersive and stupid.2. Bad voice acting. You can't convince people to take the story seriously if the voice actings for the majority of characters are cringy as hell.3. Inconsistent gameplay. I like many multi-genre games, but this is getting stupid. What is this game even trying to be? Is it an action horror game or third person puzzle platformer? Why are there several jumping puzzles and what do they add to this game?4. Not horrifying horror elements. No, "Absurd" does not equal to "Scary". Corny lines are not intimidating; they are corny. 5. Arena-styled level design. Don't ever make "this is obviously an arena, therefore you are going to have a big battle" type of level in every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ episodes. This is the most "gamey" thing you can ever achieve.6. Bad driving mechanics. Here's a general rule: either make a good driving mechanics, or don't make a long driving section if you don't have a good mechanics for it. Cars in this game remind me of MAKO in Mass Effect, and that is not a compliment.7. Walking Simulator gameplay before cutscenes. Why would you force players to follow a slowly moving, crippled npc just to have a cutscene to play afterward? What is the point of this lack of gameplay? Does this achieve anything? Why not just make a cutscene of those characters walking then? At least, that will save players from pressing W for like 20 minutes.Other than these, story is mildly interesting but nothing mind blowing or new. Graphics is mediocre. Gameplay is somewhat satisfying, but dodging mechanics is annoyingly unresponsive.

This fills me with anger because of how much time I spent looking for caches and being frugal with ammo, only to have it taken at the end of the area.

Posted: March 20, 2015
												This game was incredibly overhyped and in my opinion, below average. While it's not a terrible game, it's frankly boring, with repetitive shooting gameplay between cutscenes. Towards the middle of Chapter 4, I found myself wishing I was already finished with it. I really had to force myself to get to the end.That's not to say that I didn't find any good qualities in this game. Stylistically, I liked the cinematic visuals. There were even summaries at the beginning of each chapter, making me feel like I'm watching a TV show. The plot made some sense of the supernatural phenomena, but never came together for me. I didn't know what was really going on most of the time. The soundtrack was nice; I wish we heard more varied tracks throughout the game rather than the same two atmospheric tracks while walking everywhere. Voice acting was decent, but I didn't like Alan's voice very much in comparison to the other characters' voices. Something about the delivery seemed hollow.Gameplay is where things turned sour. I actually don't mind linear games, but each puzzle for plot advancement was too simple; the answers were quite literally laid out along Alan's path. Each encounter with dark entities relied on jump scares, and fighting got incredibly stale. I did have some intense moments, but most of the running and shooting was a bunch of hoopla that didn't contribute any substance to the story.Furthermore, my experience was negatively impacted by buggy controls. For example, the run and dodge button are the same, leading Alan to frequently dodge when there aren't any enemies around. Alan already has the worst stamina ever (seriously man... go do some cardio) so I don't need him wasting his breath. Another issue that drove me mad was that the camera kept resetting to the default position with Alan on the right side of the screen. l prefer Alan on the left, but the POV reset after every checkpoint and cutscene, even after getting out of a car! Lastly, something about the game physics looked really ragdoll-like. Not only was the fluid animation hard on the eyes, but it also made controlling Alan difficult, as he was zigzagging like a sidewinder across the screen.

Posted: October 25, 2015
												This is neither a competent action game, nor a competent horror game. For starters, I found it near impossible to get immersed, due to the really janky animations that put every character well into the "uncanny valley", only instead of this making it creepy, it just makes it really hard to look at. And that wouldn't be so much of a problem if it weren't that the game pretty much takes every opertunity to put the worst animations in the spotlight. I mean, I can understand this with in-game animations, but even the pre-rendered cutscenes suffer from this!Past the animations, though, the gameplay can pretty much be summed up by "walk and occationally point your flashlight at things simulator". And there was hardly a single death that I felt wasn't just the game working against me. This doesn't get better as the game progresses either, as towards the end it likes throwing as many of the most annoying enemies at you as possible. Why are they annoying? Because pretty much all you do to defeat them is shine your flashlight at them until they disapear, all the while taking unavoidable damage (this is especially true with the birds).All in all, there are a few moments in, say, the third quarter of the game that I actually found enjoyable (one of which is really awesome, but I don't want to spoil it if you do buy it), but trust me, I'm only scratching the surface here on what's wrong with this game. In no world is this worth $30, so if you really want to get it I would say don't spend any more than $5 on it.

												I'm sure people who like this ResEvil type of game will like this one but I found it to be too difficult to be fun. Facing off against 4 or 5 enemies is not scary as much as it is frustrating. It's done very well but the flashlight mechanic being tied to time really limits what you can do. The satisfaction of getting a cool double headshot or a rolling trip or something is totally missing because the flashlight has to burn the enemy before you can shoot them. This makes every kill feel the same and the difficulty spike is juggling more targets and managing resources rather than fun/better gameplay. This would be better if there were more ways to manage my resources or upgrade my weapons (Maybe there are. I'm 5 hours in and haven't seen anything) but I feel like there is only one path to walk on and one way to play each encounter. Backing out of an encounter resets it so I can't really kite and juke or hide and heal. It's all about getting the light on the closest guy, waiting waiting and shooting him before getting the light on the next guy waiting waiting and shooting him. Fail to acquire targets fast enough, focus the wrong target, or fail to wait enough before shooting and you have to start over. If they get anywhere near you, just restart from checkpoint and try to wait faster next time. I would recommend this game at about $8.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2013
												This is a wonderful story-based game.  A good storyline makes a good game.  In this game you play a famous book author, Alan Wake, who starts out his adventure on a vacation.  Things get serious when the characters in his stories come to life in what seems like a nightmare.  Soon, reality isn't what it seems.  This game plays like a cool TV series or playing a good book story.  It has episodes and Alan Wake narrorates his thoughts at times.  It's a horror adventure so there's scary parts.  You have to fight enemies, flip switches and find supplies to survive.  There are several things to find on your adventure like guns, ammo, book pages and flashlight batteries (you'll see why).  In other words the gameplay is like any other survivor-adventure.  But the storyline is real solid and leaves you wanting to find out what happens next.  At the time of this writing, Alan Wake is my #1 favorite story-based game.Pros:+ Storyline+ Game plays like a good book / episode story+ Cut scenes+ Graphics+ Soundtrack+ Voice acting+ Horror adventure+ There's book adaptation to this game:  Alan Wake by Rick Burroughs++BONUS!  Look in your game files for extra content  :)Cons:- No sequel (why?!)- There was a couple of places in the game that was sorta tough when being attacked and not knowing what to do.  It would be easy to replay it but I did have a couple of rage moments first time through.

Things get serious when the characters in his stories come to life in what seems like a nightmare.  Soon, reality isn't what it seems.  This game plays like a cool TV series or playing a good book story.  It has episodes and Alan Wake narrorates his thoughts at times.  It's a horror adventure so there's scary parts.  You have to fight enemies, flip switches and find supplies to survive.  There are several things to find on your adventure like guns, ammo, book pages and flashlight batteries (you'll see why).  In other words the gameplay is like any other survivor-adventure.  But the storyline is real solid and leaves you wanting to find out what happens next.  At the time of this writing, Alan Wake is my #1 favorite story-based game.Pros:+ Storyline+ Game plays like a good book / episode story+ Cut scenes+ Graphics+ Soundtrack+ Voice acting+ Horror adventure+ There's book adaptation to this game:  Alan Wake by Rick Burroughs++BONUS!  Look in your game files for extra content  :)Cons:- No sequel (why?!)- There was a couple of places in the game that was sorta tough when being attacked and not knowing what to do.  It would be easy to replay it but I did have a couple of rage moments first time through.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												6/10The Good: This is atmospheric third person action game with a poor man's Stephen King plot. After Alan Wake's wife is taken by darkness, he has to fight it to win back his woman. One of the main weapons against darkness, shock, is light. So everything that is attacking you in this game has to be weakened first with your trusty flashlight, and finished off by a small array of weapons such as shotguns and flashbangs. This makes the game semi "tactical". The story is somewhat entertaining. The graphics are nice to behold, and the music is atmospheric, though forgettable.The Bad: The biggest downfall of Alan Wake is the repetitive and shallow combat. There is barely any variation in mobs and mechanics, from beginning to end. Weaken them with light, finish them off. Rinse and repeat until game is over. There is no skill slope as in other games, where combat gets gradually more complex. I was hoping for more novel fighting scenes such as the one on the Anderson farm.While the story picks up towards the end of the game, I never much cared for its characters, and it is riddled with writing cliches and plot holes. Vedict: A fun, albeit flawed game. The topic matter of dreams and creativity could have been exploited for a much more interesting and surreal experience. I wouldn't pay more than 5 bucks for it, so get it on sale.

Posted: November 15, 2015
												Alan Wake is one of those strange games that aren't great or horrible that is a bit like a chore to play. It's definitely not a bad game. The mechanics are good, the graphics are solid, the voice acting is passable. But do I recommend it? Meh, you could miss out on it and be just fine but if you are looking for a solid survival horror then it'll do the job until the next Dead Space or Resident Evil.Oddly the story is both the highlight and detriment of the game. It is interesting and well told but sometimes comes off as a bit pretentious. There are a few loose ends and nothing is really explained too well in the DLC epilogue chapters. However I did like how the story tied into combat with light and darkness becoming literal obstacles and commodities along your journey. Unfortunately combat does become repetitous and downright frustrating in several segments. Granted that's why it is Survival Horror and not an Action title. There were plenty of occassions though where enemies were a bit overwhelming. The worst part was dealing with levitating inanimate objects becoming possessed. There is almost no way to avoid incoming attacks leaving you retrying those areas plenty of times screaming "this is bulls***!".Insofar at shock value goes, which is an important part of survival horror, there really wasn't too much of that. It wasn't overly violent and there weren't really many cringe worthy scenes. It reminded me of the movie Shadow Falls. Kind of like a horror movie censoring itself down to reach the young teen audience without their parents c***blocking them. All in all it was still a satisfying experience but for not being an upper echelon game I could have enjoyed an experience half as long in the Alan Wake universe. If you have an itch for Survival Horror I'd suggest playing some of the gems you may have missed over the years like Condemned, Dead Space, Evil WIthin, Silen Hill, or any of the Resident Evils. If you played them all then by all means play this as a diversion until the next triple A title gets released.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Having just finished the main campaign for Alan Wake, I'm struck by two things. One, I need closure! And two, what a damned well made experience of a game.It's simple, the story is well written, the graphics are nice, the settings are well realised, the gameplay is straight forward. the characters are good and the town is a great backdrop for the story to unfold. The tone of this game is pretty spot-on. You can have scary jump scares one second and then feel totally empowered the next as, you fight the "Taken." The mystery of what's happened to poor ol' Wake's wife at the beginning of the game had me gripped. And of course, what the heck is happening in the darkness?!I'll try and keep this brief. It's a thumbs-up! There may be some moments of repetition in the gameplay, but, if you pace yourself, you'll enjoy this game like a good book. I haven't played "The Signal" or "The Writer" DLC episodes, yet. So, I may update this review when I do.However, there is one glaring issue that definitely annoyed me. Framerate issues. When running the game full-screen, it could sit around 135fps or so. However, there were times when the framerate took a nosedive to 18fps...frequently. It was pretty horrible and it's also sad to see this flaw in the game, 3 years after it came out on PC. And, it definitely took away from my experience at times.But, while this problem occurred a number of times, strangely, it didn't happen everytime I loaded the game up. I can't explain why it only happened on some occasions, but, I just know that it did. Go figure.Other than that, it's a classic. Can't wait to jump back into the DLC episodes (free with the PC version) and see what happens next. Again, a BIG thumbs-up!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Alan Wake is a movie game. Last time I had such feelings when I finished playing Dreamfall. It's a film that you watch and sometimes participate in, helping the characters on their way. There is a lot of cinematic inclusions in it, the game constantly gives you various hints, indicates what you should do, etc; all the events go their way, and you have no actual influence on them, you are unable to change the plot. In other words, the game commands, and you obey. You are written into this story as tightly as all other characters of it. You are a player, and you are a mere spectator at the same time.Playing it was pleasant and entertaining. I really liked that process of burning the darkness out of those cursed people and bringing them the final rest. A flashlight becomes both a shining sword of light and a laser indicator that makes aiming very easy and intuitive. Actually, you feel incredibly cool when you overcome the enemies that attack you. It's all the more unusual as it's not a super hero that you are playing for; he's just a writer, not very strong, not very well trained, but still having enough guts and stamina to cope with all that hardships he had to face.It's not very long (14 hours in my case), but that's well enough. Each episode is in its place. Would it be longer, some boredom might appear and spoil the fun. It's rather addictive, especially at the beginning, so make sure that you do not lose the track of time. As for the plot, it cannot be called extraordinary, but I find it interesting. Most probably, it was made a bit inconsistent on purpose (well, what consistency do you expect to see in a story where the world goes mad?).To mention the negative side, I guess that the most unpleasant thing here was the product placement and hidden advertising in the game. For example, you need batteries for your flashlight, and not just any batteries, but those of one certain trademark whose distinct design is recognized clearly. I can deal with it, though; people need money to develop games, we all know that.I never wanted to play this game, in fact; I bought it just because it was on 90% discount sale. Now, I recommend it. Not for a moment did it make me regret my choice. It even had an unexpected side effect on me: back in non-distant past I used to write some fiction, and this game brought back my memories of the great fun of being a writer. Maybe, one day I will create a story or two again.

												Alan Wake is a strange game. Its story is somewhat good, but with really really bad dialogues. You simply don't want to hear them and don't give a flying **** for what people are saying in this game. Most of the time it's all irrelevant for the plot and aren't even funny or entertaining dialogues. You really, REALLY won't care at all, believe me.Aside of this, Alan Wake has one of the most terrible level designs I ever experienced in my life. Most of the time you're on big open useless woods. They look like non linear, but you just follow the roads or some easy visual language signs and you're right on your way. Instead of what it looks like, it is totally linear. All the rest of the scenery are just useless(except from one place or another where you can find some collectables or weapon caches. But they're not even that hard to find...). Not only that but, also, most of the time you will be walking in these useless woods without ANYTHING happening at all. A literal "walking simulator", for the most part.Besides, Alan Wake have a "ok" gameplay with interesting mechanics. But it's a shame that you'll only see this game shining(ba dum tss) in very few moments. There's one part or another in this game where you'll think something like "THAT'S what I was expecting from this game!". It's really a shame that most of the time you will not be thinking this, but will be like "oh my god, how could be this is a game? I'm only walking and walking" or "What a REALLY bad level design!" or "This game is SO frustrating! How can they throw me 10 enemies when I'm totally unarmed??" and things like these...I'm really disappointed with this game. Shame. These guys from remedy gave us the perfectly crafted Max Payne and now it's really hard to believe that they gave us a game like Alan Wake...

content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												6/10The Good: This is atmospheric third person action game with a poor man's Stephen King plot. After Alan Wake's wife is taken by darkness, he has to fight it to win back his woman. One of the main weapons against darkness, shock, is light. So everything that is attacking you in this game has to be weakened first with your trusty flashlight, and finished off by a small array of weapons such as shotguns and flashbangs. This makes the game semi "tactical". The story is somewhat entertaining. The graphics are nice to behold, and the music is atmospheric, though forgettable.The Bad: The biggest downfall of Alan Wake is the repetitive and shallow combat. There is barely any variation in mobs and mechanics, from beginning to end. Weaken them with light, finish them off. Rinse and repeat until game is over. There is no skill slope as in other games, where combat gets gradually more complex. I was hoping for more novel fighting scenes such as the one on the Anderson farm.While the story picks up towards the end of the game, I never much cared for its characters, and it is riddled with writing cliches and plot holes. Vedict: A fun, albeit flawed game. The topic matter of dreams and creativity could have been exploited for a much more interesting and surreal experience. I wouldn't pay more than 5 bucks for it, so get it on sale.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Don't care about thumbs ups OR downs reall; gonna be honest, it's mixed feelings anyway. Alan Wake is a writer battling off surreal forces with light. It's an interesting concept, with good technical performance, a good port overall, and some moderately interesting things about it. One is the story; it focuses heavily on narration and while unique, it moved too quickly, shoved too much dialogue into your face, in my opinion. Some levels are fun to run through and explore, but I quicky got tired of running through woods and similar looking locations. For some reason the game felt much longer than it was. Well, it was rather long to begin with. A LOOOT of "you need to go here! now here! now here!" around the town, and often times "it's right over there! there's just something blocking your way so you have to go around!" . Like, a lot. It became old fast. You also lose your weapons a lot, recurring trope. There are plenty of characters but... almost all of them are annoying and I didn't care for any of them. While Alan isn't a bad protagonist, if I have to hear him yell "ALICE!" one more time I'm gonna flip.The difficulty is weird too, i found myself dying constantly even on Normal, but i perservered. It's hard to dodge when enemies all have endless throwing axes and run up to, often surround you, from behind and all other angles. Controls themselves were okay, but the silliness of just how short the battery life is in this world made me wish they had them last longer, and you just found fewer batteries. Personal preference though. Ultimately...while the story is unique and it's not terrible, I'd really only recommend it for fans of psychological thrillers or decent 3rd person survival shooter types that aren't purely action. The story is unique, yes, but I mean that in a sense of "it doesn't sound like any other story i've heard of" not "it's really good". It was okay. Not my flavour of narrative, the speed at which Alan sputters out his lines, and the constant jerking around with the player making me constantly confused as to what was even happening til near the very end. Plot points were flying by left and right, and well, if you miss something, they probably won't go over it much again.It's not a bad game, I just don't think it was for me. The frustration with difficulty and combat mixed with the meh characters and only decent plot idea yet in-your-face way of telling it jus wasn't my style, so I really couldn't think of enough good reasons to recommend it, that's all.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2014
												Alan Wake is a psychological thriller that continuously bends the rules of reality. Incorporating third-person shooter mechanics with a story that continues to give more questions than it answers, Alan Wake is a game that takes psychological manipulation to a whole different level. However, Alan Wake suffers from almost a lack of identity. It tries to do too many things at once, and sometimes falls flat on its face.__________Synopsis: Alan and his wife Alice take a vacation to Bright Falls. Soon after arriving, Alan learns it was a ploy by Alice and his agent Barry to help Alan get over his writer's block. Furious, Alan temporarily storms off, but returns when he hears Alice screaming. Being sucked into the lake by an unknown force, Alan dives in after her, but fails to come back up. Waking up, he's in his car, as he seems to have driven it off the road and gotten injured. When he returns to town, no one recalls seeing Alice or even hearing about her. Plagued by strange interactions with the psychotic, shadowy figures of Bright Falls, and having recurring nightmares, Alan must navigate his way through the seemingly infinite series of nightmares and alternate realities to understand and overcome the evil forces that plague Bright Falls.__________Story: The main plot of Alan Wake is like a road that twists and turns, then flips upside down. While it is engaging and suspenseful, there are quite a few times where the plot fluctuates in periods of dull segments and seems to lack consistency at holding onto the excitement the story brings. Coupled with sections that are filled with unpredictable and random humor, the game suffers from a lack of seriousness that most would expect of a mystery/horror game, which sometimes compromises the integrity of a game that so heavily relies on its story to drive the point home.Graphics and Environments: Using towns and environments that are more spread out than most, the game gives a certain feeling of freedom during combat and exploration without being too open or too enclosed. Visually appealing landscapes also incite you to take in the view. Furthermore, the game does an excellent job of instantly shifting from what seems to be a harmless open field into a fear-inducing cage.Functionality and Gameplay: Mechanically, there is nothing wrong with Alan Wake; the controls are fluid and the usage of weapons and gadgets is simple and effective. The weakest point of Alan Wake is the combat; and it is unfortunately a very big, yet small part of the game. Defeating enemies requires you to shine your flashlight or other sources of light on them to dissipate their black shadowy shields, followed by laying into them with bullets. The game imposes upon you a sense of haste: Quickly dispatch these enemies, or be overrun. Often enough, you are forced to constantly kite enemies and run in circles to further increase your chances of not dying. Furthermore, the amount of enemies are in over-abundance, losing their effective scare-factor by the second time you encounter them Thus, for how much of a psychological thriller the game tries to uphold, it's constantly under minded by the combat system._________________________Overall, this is a story-based game. Combat is simply a filler to get you from one area to the next. Removing the combat completely or giving the player limited combat options might have made this game into a much more solid contender in the mystery/horror genre. I recommend you buy this game on sale.

Posted: February 15, 2015
												Having just finished the main campaign for Alan Wake, I'm struck by two things. One, I need closure! And two, what a damned well made experience of a game.It's simple, the story is well written, the graphics are nice, the settings are well realised, the gameplay is straight forward. the characters are good and the town is a great backdrop for the story to unfold. The tone of this game is pretty spot-on. You can have scary jump scares one second and then feel totally empowered the next as, you fight the "Taken." The mystery of what's happened to poor ol' Wake's wife at the beginning of the game had me gripped. And of course, what the heck is happening in the darkness?!I'll try and keep this brief. It's a thumbs-up! There may be some moments of repetition in the gameplay, but, if you pace yourself, you'll enjoy this game like a good book. I haven't played "The Signal" or "The Writer" DLC episodes, yet. So, I may update this review when I do.However, there is one glaring issue that definitely annoyed me. Framerate issues. When running the game full-screen, it could sit around 135fps or so. However, there were times when the framerate took a nosedive to 18fps...frequently. It was pretty horrible and it's also sad to see this flaw in the game, 3 years after it came out on PC. And, it definitely took away from my experience at times.But, while this problem occurred a number of times, strangely, it didn't happen everytime I loaded the game up. I can't explain why it only happened on some occasions, but, I just know that it did. Go figure.Other than that, it's a classic. Can't wait to jump back into the DLC episodes (free with the PC version) and see what happens next. Again, a BIG thumbs-up!

												Alan Wake is a psychological thriller that continuously bends the rules of reality. Incorporating third-person shooter mechanics with a story that continues to give more questions than it answers, Alan Wake is a game that takes psychological manipulation to a whole different level. However, Alan Wake suffers from almost a lack of identity. It tries to do too many things at once, and sometimes falls flat on its face.__________Synopsis: Alan and his wife Alice take a vacation to Bright Falls. Soon after arriving, Alan learns it was a ploy by Alice and his agent Barry to help Alan get over his writer's block. Furious, Alan temporarily storms off, but returns when he hears Alice screaming. Being sucked into the lake by an unknown force, Alan dives in after her, but fails to come back up. Waking up, he's in his car, as he seems to have driven it off the road and gotten injured. When he returns to town, no one recalls seeing Alice or even hearing about her. Plagued by strange interactions with the psychotic, shadowy figures of Bright Falls, and having recurring nightmares, Alan must navigate his way through the seemingly infinite series of nightmares and alternate realities to understand and overcome the evil forces that plague Bright Falls.__________Story: The main plot of Alan Wake is like a road that twists and turns, then flips upside down. While it is engaging and suspenseful, there are quite a few times where the plot fluctuates in periods of dull segments and seems to lack consistency at holding onto the excitement the story brings. Coupled with sections that are filled with unpredictable and random humor, the game suffers from a lack of seriousness that most would expect of a mystery/horror game, which sometimes compromises the integrity of a game that so heavily relies on its story to drive the point home.Graphics and Environments: Using towns and environments that are more spread out than most, the game gives a certain feeling of freedom during combat and exploration without being too open or too enclosed. content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Alan Wake is a movie game. Last time I had such feelings when I finished playing Dreamfall. It's a film that you watch and sometimes participate in, helping the characters on their way. There is a lot of cinematic inclusions in it, the game constantly gives you various hints, indicates what you should do, etc; all the events go their way, and you have no actual influence on them, you are unable to change the plot. In other words, the game commands, and you obey. You are written into this story as tightly as all other characters of it. You are a player, and you are a mere spectator at the same time.Playing it was pleasant and entertaining. I really liked that process of burning the darkness out of those cursed people and bringing them the final rest. A flashlight becomes both a shining sword of light and a laser indicator that makes aiming very easy and intuitive. Actually, you feel incredibly cool when you overcome the enemies that attack you. It's all the more unusual as it's not a super hero that you are playing for; he's just a writer, not very strong, not very well trained, but still having enough guts and stamina to cope with all that hardships he had to face.It's not very long (14 hours in my case), but that's well enough. Each episode is in its place. Would it be longer, some boredom might appear and spoil the fun. It's rather addictive, especially at the beginning, so make sure that you do not lose the track of time. As for the plot, it cannot be called extraordinary, but I find it interesting. Most probably, it was made a bit inconsistent on purpose (well, what consistency do you expect to see in a story where the world goes mad?).To mention the negative side, I guess that the most unpleasant thing here was the product placement and hidden advertising in the game. For example, you need batteries for your flashlight, and not just any batteries, but those of one certain trademark whose distinct design is recognized clearly. I can deal with it, though; people need money to develop games, we all know that.I never wanted to play this game, in fact; I bought it just because it was on 90% discount sale. Now, I recommend it. Not for a moment did it make me regret my choice. It even had an unexpected side effect on me: back in non-distant past I used to write some fiction, and this game brought back my memories of the great fun of being a writer. Maybe, one day I will create a story or two again.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												Having just finished the main campaign for Alan Wake, I'm struck by two things. One, I need closure! And two, what a damned well made experience of a game.It's simple, the story is well written, the graphics are nice, the settings are well realised, the gameplay is straight forward. the characters are good and the town is a great backdrop for the story to unfold. The tone of this game is pretty spot-on. You can have scary jump scares one second and then feel totally empowered the next as, you fight the "Taken." The mystery of what's happened to poor ol' Wake's wife at the beginning of the game had me gripped. And of course, what the heck is happening in the darkness?!I'll try and keep this brief. It's a thumbs-up! There may be some moments of repetition in the gameplay, but, if you pace yourself, you'll enjoy this game like a good book. I haven't played "The Signal" or "The Writer" DLC episodes, yet. So, I may update this review when I do.However, there is one glaring issue that definitely annoyed me. Framerate issues. When running the game full-screen, it could sit around 135fps or so. However, there were times when the framerate took a nosedive to 18fps...frequently. It was pretty horrible and it's also sad to see this flaw in the game, 3 years after it came out on PC. And, it definitely took away from my experience at times.But, while this problem occurred a number of times, strangely, it didn't happen everytime I loaded the game up. I can't explain why it only happened on some occasions, but, I just know that it did. Go figure.Other than that, it's a classic. Can't wait to jump back into the DLC episodes (free with the PC version) and see what happens next. Again, a BIG thumbs-up!

content:
Posted: February 17, 2016
												When the wife of the best-selling writer Alan Wake disappears on their vacation, his search turns up pages from a thriller he doesn’t even remember writing. A Dark Presence stalks the small town of Bright Falls, pushing Wake to the brink of sanity in his fight to unravel the mystery and save his love. Presented in the style of a TV series, Alan Wake features the trademark Remedy storytelling and pulse-pounding action sequences. As players dive deeper and deeper into the mystery, they’ll face overwhelming odds, plot twists, and cliffhangers. It’s only by mastering the Fight With Light combat mechanic that they can stay one step ahead of the darkness that spreads across Bright Falls. With the body of an action game and the mind of a psychological thriller, Alan Wake’s intense atmosphere, deep and multilayered story, and exceptionally tense combat sequences provide players with an entertaining and original gaming experience

content:
Posted: October 31, 2014
												Alan Wake is a game. At the same time, it is a mind-bending experience that asks the player to question every section of their journey. Is Alan experiencing reality? Can any moment of his story be taken for granted? If so, who is your friend? Who is your foe? Why are things happening this way? Can there be any happy resolution? None of these questions are hand-fed to you by the game; it is up to the player to ultimately make a decision as to what he thinks is truly going on.Alan Wake, from a gameplay perspective, is a tense third-person shooter. By keeping the camera close to, but still over and pulled back from, Alan's shoulder, it allows the player to feel the tension and intensity of the situation. Each engagement has a simple system to follow: Use the flashlight, or any device that creates light, to burn away the shield of darkness that prevents Alan from harming it. Then, light it up with a variety of tight, responsive, and powerful weapons. The enemies of Alan Wake do not use intelligence or tactics to overwhelm the player, but sheer numbers and individual brute force. It is up to the player to use the environment and the equipment they retrieve tactically to defeat the horde, and in a worst-case scenario, know when to sprint straight for the nearest safe haven.Alan Wake is a deep game; it's meant to be played multiple times. The story, while indepth and well structured just in the pacing of the game in of itself, contains many hidden facets found in its collectables that add depth to what Alan is experiencing, as well as the history and unseen events that occur in Bright Falls, Washington. Radio broadcasts, mysterious manuscript pages, and even the music itself all are important clues as to the truth of what is happening.Without a doubt, Alan Wake is a game I'd recommend to anyone. It plays tight, it has a deep, dark mystery that holds the attentions of its players, and it is a fascinating experience that always lends a new clue into the truth every time one plays it.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
												Alan Wake is an intriguing "psychological action thriller" game that is vaguely similar to the Silent Hill series. The storyline and characters are definitely the strongest points in this game. NPCs like Barry add humor and motivation to an otherwise, dark and gloomy setting. The story is interesting and there is a lot of suspense and action. Now, the weak points. Combat tries to be innovative, but it gets old fast. All the enemies are much too similar and the game doesn't get very creative with the weapons. You get guns, flares, flashbang grenades and that's pretty much it if you exclude the flashlights. There's no melee weapons or hand-to-hand combat which is a very puzzling decision made by the developers. It's quite frustrating to walk by a bunch of axes and chainsaws laying around without being able to use them. Also, after several parts and chapters in the game, you will be stripped of all your weapons. I can see how this makes sense at some points, but why don't the characters do anything to prepare for combat? I know it's just a game, so that doesn't really matter. If you can look past all the flaws this game has, I strongly recommend that you play it. I certainly had fun although I was frustrated at times.

Posted: December 29, 2015
												"And the light shineth in the darkness and the darkness comprehended it not".I'll be brief here. If you go into this game expecting a good psychological horror game, you're going to be disappointed. This is what I initially believed the game to be like, and I was very much let down on this front. The game, while "horror-esque" is mainly an action thriller/mystery with a decent emphasis on story. The problem here is that the story, while interesting, is too sparse to support the game by itself. What remains is a mediocre action title which left me somewhere between bored and wanting more. Seriously, I couldn't even finish the two DLC episodes ('Signals' 1 and 2 - they're free and come with the download) because by the end of the 4th episode (the main game is split into 6 'epsiodes' - basically the equivalent of 'levels') I was bored out of my mind and only thought of when this game was finally going to be over with.Tl;dr: To surmise, the story is decent, the gameplay, while interesting at first, gets boring and repetitive, and the 'horror' is neglected in favor of the 'action', which itself isn't all that new or interesting. Thus I do not recommend this even though I will give the game a 6/10 - a score of above average,

												A shockingly great mystery thriller thats dripping with atmosphere and style all around!Alan Wake has amazing production values and a well crafted story that plays like a well written Stephen King novel, with splashes of Twin Peaks. Gameplay is simple, but controls very well and has some great setpieces sprinkled throughout its lengthy campaign. Its also thematically in line with the story, which is rare and refreshing given how most games struggle with trying to marriage its gameplay with its story. It shows just how great interactive storytelling can be.Its a shame more people didnt try it when it came out, but thankfully its gained a cult classic status in modern gaming, which makes the wait for its sequel all the more painful. Still, do not give this one a miss!

content:
Posted: April 17, 2016
												HEAR ME OUT: This is a pretty good game as far as graphics, cinematics, gamplay, sound effects etc. But the reason I'm giving this game a negative review is because of 3 reasons. #1) The Objectives. This game has pretty simple objectives, but they are repetitive and they drag out FOREVER!!! It will literally take you hours to make your way through obstacles in the forest just to figure that you have to do the same thing again for the next task. The main reason for this is due to the enemies along the way.....which leads to my second reason. #2) The Enemies. The amount of enemies in this game are ridiculous. During the progression of the game, you encounter ALOT of enemies and I mean ALOT! They spawn like literally every 5 minutes, and its nearly impossible to run away if you dont have alot of flash bangs and flares because they run just as fast, if not, faster than you. Plus, you run of breath very quickly from sprinting, and its no option to upgrade your stamina. It's really frustrating especially when you waste all of your ammo and resources to defeat three enemies and then like 3 min later another 4 spawn right in front of you. It damn near makes you lose interest in the game do to the lack of progression and the repetitive nature. #3) The Story. So without spoiling, Alan Wake reminds me of one of those good horror/thriller movies that start off great.......and then once you get into the middle of ending of the film, it starts to either try to do too much or it just doesn't ultimately leave the audience satisfied. IDK...thats just my opinion, but aside from everything I just spoke of.....I would rate this game 6/10.

												HEAR ME OUT: This is a pretty good game as far as graphics, cinematics, gamplay, sound effects etc. But the reason I'm giving this game a negative review is because of 3 reasons. #1) The Objectives. This game has pretty simple objectives, but they are repetitive and they drag out FOREVER!!! It will literally take you hours to make your way through obstacles in the forest just to figure that you have to do the same thing again for the next task. The main reason for this is due to the enemies along the way.....which leads to my second reason. #2) The Enemies. The amount of enemies in this game are ridiculous. During the progression of the game, you encounter ALOT of enemies and I mean ALOT! They spawn like literally every 5 minutes, and its nearly impossible to run away if you dont have alot of flash bangs and flares because they run just as fast, if not, faster than you. Plus, you run of breath very quickly from sprinting, and its no option to upgrade your stamina. It's really frustrating especially when you waste all of your ammo and resources to defeat three enemies and then like 3 min later another 4 spawn right in front of you. It damn near makes you lose interest in the game do to the lack of progression and the repetitive nature. #3) The Story. So without spoiling, Alan Wake reminds me of one of those good horror/thriller movies that start off great.......and then once you get into the middle of ending of the film, it starts to either try to do too much or it just doesn't ultimately leave the audience satisfied. IDK...thats just my opinion, but aside from everything I just spoke of.....I would rate this game 6/10.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Unintentional running-scared-in-the-woods simulator. Overrated for sure, but worth a play-through.Contains classic horror-tropes and cliches, some not so cleverly disguised, but for the most part the bigger tropes (killer birds, poltergeists & ax-murderers) are played on a somewhat satirical note. The story told is nothing groundbreaking or one you haven't necessarily heard before - but to it's credit, up until the final cut scenes, you won't be able to outright call the ending. This game suffers from poor progression. The first chapter successfully reels the player in with flashes of climactic events yet to come. Anticipation builds, curiosity is piqued and then -- waiting ... waiting ... yep. The story comes to a practical halt, stringing you along with useless tidbits of information which have no greater meaning or impact as far as the plot goes. Alan Wake's saving grace is in the last two chapters, which reward the player's admirable patience with fulfilling and detailed sequences of events. Unfortunately, the transitions between chapters are blatant and without grace, reeking of inexperience in storytelling. To break it down; Episode 1 is consistent throughout, and moderate in it's rhythm - to effect - as all stories must set the scene and establish some background. Then come Episodes 2-4; whereas a good narrative will lay down the brass tacks and drop some hints with substance, Alan Wake's narrative is merely a distraction, desperate to keep the player's interest by use of one-liners and random musings which make no contribution to the overall story arc. Finally, Episodes 5 & 6 pick up where the intensity of Episode 1 dropped off, the player finds themselves running through the woods once again, but this time with a purpose and a need to tie up all loose ends.All in all, not a complete waste of time. Still, too lengthy a game for it's own story-telling purposes. Play it if you like cheesy horror flicks and you have time to kill. 6/10TL;DR: decent story, poor execution, combat & game-play solely for purposes of lengthening the play time.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Alan Wake is proof positive of the point that a story, properly told transcends all media and genres. A game that could be EASILY adapted for film or TV, Alan Wake is a game that is, in actuality, an interactive novel, and one that is just BEGGING for Star Trek's holodeck. Even in the intro sequence I found myself enjoying the game on a level that I have not enjoyed any other game before. Does that mean it's my favourite game? No. But even still it is a wonderful experience nonetheless. Even the fairly standard horror pacing and formula can't detract from this game, and so intricately tied to and interwoven with its plot the game really manages to tell a story while you battle shadow monsters with a Christmas light wearing sidekick (I am NOT making this up). While I am not a fan of the horror genre, and have never really read any Stephen King (to whom the tilts it's hat many times), the game was nevertheless thoroughly enjoyable. The only down-side to this interactive novel is that like a novel it is not immediately replayable. When you get to the last chapter, you don't feel any pressing need to start over again from the beginning, because what you have really enjoyed is not the thrill of the chase, being hunted by an insidious Lovecraftian shadow-demon, but the content of that story. But I think that is one negative we can all bear if games of this ilk were to become more common in the future. And really that actually makes the gameplay longer lasting easier to savour. Please Remedy, and ALL developers, give us more interactive novels, and less psychotically emotionless space marines killing freaking zombie demons from outer space.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												Don't care about thumbs ups OR downs reall; gonna be honest, it's mixed feelings anyway. Alan Wake is a writer battling off surreal forces with light. It's an interesting concept, with good technical performance, a good port overall, and some moderately interesting things about it. One is the story; it focuses heavily on narration and while unique, it moved too quickly, shoved too much dialogue into your face, in my opinion. Some levels are fun to run through and explore, but I quicky got tired of running through woods and similar looking locations. For some reason the game felt much longer than it was. Well, it was rather long to begin with. A LOOOT of "you need to go here! now here! now here!" around the town, and often times "it's right over there! there's just something blocking your way so you have to go around!" . Like, a lot. It became old fast. You also lose your weapons a lot, recurring trope. There are plenty of characters but... almost all of them are annoying and I didn't care for any of them. While Alan isn't a bad protagonist, if I have to hear him yell "ALICE!" one more time I'm gonna flip.The difficulty is weird too, i found myself dying constantly even on Normal, but i perservered. It's hard to dodge when enemies all have endless throwing axes and run up to, often surround you, from behind and all other angles. Controls themselves were okay, but the silliness of just how short the battery life is in this world made me wish they had them last longer, and you just found fewer batteries. Personal preference though. Ultimately...while the story is unique and it's not terrible, I'd really only recommend it for fans of psychological thrillers or decent 3rd person survival shooter types that aren't purely action. The story is unique, yes, but I mean that in a sense of "it doesn't sound like any other story i've heard of" not "it's really good". It was okay. Not my flavour of narrative, the speed at which Alan sputters out his lines, and the constant jerking around with the player making me constantly confused as to what was even happening til near the very end. Plot points were flying by left and right, and well, if you miss something, they probably won't go over it much again.It's not a bad game, I just don't think it was for me. The frustration with difficulty and combat mixed with the meh characters and only decent plot idea yet in-your-face way of telling it jus wasn't my style, so I really couldn't think of enough good reasons to recommend it, that's all.

The protagonist of the game, writer Alan Wake, trying to find the missing wife and encounters with the supernatural dark entity, taking possession of the city and its surroundings at night. Finding the scattered pages of manuscripts, Wake understands that his adventure subject to the plot, written and forgotten them of the novel. Adult Alan Wake is modelled Ilkka Willy (fin. Ilkka Villi) - Finnish actor and writer.February 22, 2012 for the Xbox 360 came out action game «Alan Wake''s American Nightmare», distributed through a network of digital distribution Xbox Live Arcade. American Nightmare is the plot branch, and not the direct continuation of the first game. A full-fledged sequel, Alan Wake, 2, on July 2013 unannounced, although this June Remedy Entertainment registered the domain AlanWake2.com .may 21, 2013 during the presentation of the console, the next generation of Microsoft's Xbox One, it became known that the next game from Remedy Entertainment will be a Quantum Break, not Alan Wake 2, as previously assumed. The next day after the presentation, in his official address, Sam lake told that Alan Wake 2 never saw light due to poor sales of the first part, and also due to lack of funding. "At the moment we are busy with our new big project, but perhaps we'll come back to Alan Wake when the time is right".The game's plot tells about the adventures of a writer Alan Wake, a best-selling author in the genre of «Thriller,» which appeared in the town of bright falls, Washington state, where characters come to life and the events of his works. Trying to understand what is happening and find out what happened to his wife, Alan finds out a lot of unexpected about the small town - used to live here writer Thomas Zane. His wife was killed, drowned under mysterious circumstances in the lake near which they lived, even though it was beautiful пловчихой. Zane, who dives to the bottom of the lake, one day finds a floating black mass, which enters into the transaction. The deal was that Zane writes a story, and releases the Dark Essence the bottom of a lake.
