content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												Alan Wake is a "linear survival horror" game, I guess you'd call it.The premise is that Alan Wake is a writer. A horror novel he doesn't remember writing -while he's in a dry spell and on vacation- suddenly becomes his life, with him as the protagonist fighting a formless evil that possesses objects and the minds of others while they are in the dark.This game is a repurchase, from when I owned it initially on Xbox 360.This game is very very well written. Characters, plot points, villians, etc. Good sense of timing and pacing.Let that sink in for a sec, because it's the most important part of this game.However, the plot is presented in a very cliche episodic format. (Video games aren't good enough on their own without also being TV shows, apparently.) There's a "Next time on" and "Last time on" every end and beginning of a chapter, just like marathoning a TV series. While the episodic structure is really more of a throwback to TV series with similar theming in intention, I think it kind of misses its mark on the referential and is simply annoying.There are other references it makes to the genre that do it justice and are appreciated, like the Night Springs TV show within the game and several more clever nods to horror novels.Besides all of the Stephen King stuff they throw in your face as if he's Jesus himself, the realistic topics are also somewhat uncomfortable (This is a good thing in this instance). With /just enough/ understanding of the perils an artist of any kind can face in their career, it is self aware and handles these subjects with respect.Liked all the characters. Alan Wakes agent gets a special mention.Enemies can be dull for a game with supernatural horror, but the game is mechanically very well rounded.Runs well on my PC as far as I can see, no complaints there.It's a good game. I enjoyed it, and I can recommend it easily to fans of the genre.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												One of the few single player games I have deemed worthy of re-play. Indeed, one of my favourite games ever.Alan Wake is, I find, a unique achievement. The balance and interplay of light and darkness (which is the crux of both the story and gameplay) is so simple a concept, yet so well fleshed-out here. As a horror/thriller game it really succeeds, and the constant threat of the darkness and the intermittent relief of the light keeps your emotions in constant flux. It isn't a 'scary' game, but the tension it creates through the frenetic gameplay and limited means of mitigating the threat of darkness, is very impressive.It's hard to explain how the game grips you. The story is a self-aware (and self-professed) homage to Stephen King's style, and it's a lot of fun to follow. The autonarration, episodic structure and even the Night Springs episodes really add to this, and it is truly charming. The ending is a little confusing and leaves you thinking that perhaps the writers of the game over-reached a little, but that said I haven't played the Specials so perhaps it all ties together a little better.The game certainly has its quirks and, in some cases, immersion killers (such as poor lip-syncing, terrible jumping mechanic, occasionally bad voice acting). However, they don't change the fact that most of the time you will forget that you're playing a video game and not actually living Alan's life. This is helped by the 100% glitch-free status this game has achieved (for me).Just a couple of simple points to add. The game is absolutely beautiful, and that's even by modern standards (since it originally came out in 2010). The sound design is also fantastic, so realistic that you find yourself noticing the little things like believable floorboard creaks and rustling of leaves and grass. A good pair of headphones is highly recommended. I find very little to criticise in the gameplay, particularly in how Alan controls. Yes he is slow, not agile and lacking in stamina, but that is wholly believable - he is a writer! I even enjoyed how terrible a driver he is! It is simply a joy to play.The more I write the harder I find it to rationalise why the game impressed me so. I guess it will be for me to work out the more I think about the game, which I can see myself doing!

content:
Posted: November 13, 2014
												I gotta say, this game shocked me. It really did something Im not to used to seeing in most games, especially one that did one thing; and I say one thing lightly, this game really did something unique while still falling  VERY  short of its full potential.Alan Wake was one of the best written games Ive personally played in a very long time. It featured a story of fully believable characters, and a tone that set the atmosphere perfectly. It captured its players in a story that was meant to make you feel something , and set out to do it in a wonderful way. It placed heavy empahsis on its moments of combat to futher those means of driving you deeper into this world that they've written. A world like ours, but dark, mutilated, disrupted. It captivates its audience using heavy visual cues, and sounds, and gameplay mechanics to give you a sense of this obstacle, this presence looming over your every turn, watching everything you do, while you do it. Its menacing to honestly try and think about that, while not psyching yourself out. Go on. I dare ya.Anyway, without rambling, and without sounding stupid, though Im honestly just trying to give you my thoughts on what I noticed, hopefully so you can appreciate the game like I did, this game is unique in a sense that its a story. Its really nothing more. Its a game used to deliver a piece of work that was honestly meant to be more of a story than an experience. A tale in the long list of works by Stephen King nonetheless, but still a very unique and wonderful story.Without spoiling the story for those who are hopefully reading this, and havent played the game yet, the story is really straightforward. It really stayed true, *sigh* somewhat, to a horror technique that Im familiar with, but not in the slightest am I truly knowledgable, so bear with me as I try to explain, Tension and Release.This concept of horror is used to scare people using a method of building suspense without actually scaring you. It comes in a variety of ways. sound, the rocks you see falling in front of you, or the ocassional barrel or chair flying through the scene, a large object falling in the distance and so forth. Its that flickering light you see in a otherwise normal scene, but seeing it flicker just lets you know something is wrong. (If you want to know more about this kind of method of horror, and how its applied to games more deeply, I highly suggest you check out Extra Credits video on it linked here >>>   Extra Credits - Shiver with Antici-pation - How Horror Games Create a Tension Cycle The gameplay attributes to this too. At first it may seem hard, but when you start getting a feel for the game, you realize, almost everything Alan does is slow, or cumbersome, its a chore getting into a fight. Im serious, almost every time it happened, I honestly said something along the lines of  "well great, there's 6 enemies and more on the way and I have 3 batteries, 19 bullets and no Save Haven in sight to save me." They did this on purpose. Its similar to the idea in The Evil Within, but I may be wrong, Ive yet to play the game myself. I only gathered this from what Ive seen of the gameplay, and asking people about their experience. The reason the combat is so difficult is because they want you to feel helpless. They couldnt really scare you if you had all the weapons with a light that never died. You would look forward to the fights, expecting them to be more rewarding than finding out more about the lore thats happening right in front of you. in essence, it would kinda be Resident Evil 6. And we dont want that. We wanna be scared guys.Also, before I wrap this up, I wanna mention the story, but Im only going to say what I felt about the story, not how the story took place. This story is amazing because, as a piece of work, being just a story, it stands alone its own. Truthfully, you couldve released this as a book, and it would have been just as great as the game, I'll be damned to say if it did, I would be ♥♥♥♥ed if Hollywood didnt do a movie on it. Its job was to scare you, and as a story by itself it does just that. It scares you and it scares you good.I didnt really touch on this, but real quick, I just wanted to point out, for a game that filled with a lot of gripes from people, its pretty obvious the developers cared about this game. There are alot of things that you noticed playing that let you know this, one of them being this game jokingly trashes video game developers constantly (you'll see why *laugh* seriously). But they game came across to me as too good. Its not a gem, but Ill be damned if I wont reccomend it because of that. The story, the gameplay, and the mechanics were damn near all perfectly aligned in this one. Not to sound conceited or anything but if I had to rate it, I would give it a 6 out of 10, but that is only including the story.If you liked what I had to say, leave a comment or something so we can talk about it more, comeon guys, I need people to talk about game design, this stuffs really fun!!!DUCES!

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Alan Wake is a game you may have heard about a while back when it was one of the first mainstream games to use deferred lighting. It's brought to you by Remedy -- you know, the Max Payne guys. It started out all right, and I finished the main campaign to give the game a chance, but it's a slog. Partway through the DLC episodes, I realized I was forcing myself to keep going, and stopped.PROS: Tech-wise, the game runs well on my machine and has all the common graphical options I need (including FOV). The game makes great use of deferred lighting, soundtrack, and monologues to create atmosphere. Many times, it felt like I was a character in a pulp thriller novel. The plot, delivered through the pages/monologues, kept me interested for the first half. The story is an interesting, possibly allegorical story with multiple interpretations told by an unreliable narrator. But then again...CONS: ...The plot's delivery through the manuscript pages and monologues adds a lot of tedium to the game. You have to search for pages (often hidden away in silly corners, sometimes easily mistakable for white patches), then bring up a menu, then listen to Alan read through the thing. And it does take itself a little too seriously -- Alan's voice reading the melodramatic pages over and over again gave me a headache.But hey, no story's perfect, it's a game, right? Well, the shooting feels pretty bad to me (I played on normal difficulty). I'll admit that the weapons have decent feedback, but combat flows horribly and wake feels sluggish. The flashlight makes it hard to tell where you're aiming, you get tired fast, you run out of ammo near important checkpoints and have to dodge the next bunch of enemies, you get mobbed by tons of enemies and have to figure out some absurd way to kite them, all sorts of tedium. And I could forgive a lot of those things if it weren't for the fact that the core combat loop is tedious too -- you (normally) have to shine your flashlight at a million of the same enemies for a long time to peel off the darkness protecting them and since enemies don't move very fast, shots are dead easy. Unless, of course, you're being mobbed, in which case you have to run around, kite enemies, and mash dodge in the hope that you will dodge a blow coming from the enemy that will invariably spawn behind you every second encounter. Tedium, tedium, tedium. Oh, and the final icing on the cake is that the game enjoys violently swooping the camera around, going into slow motion, and screeching when you get ambushed for the millionth time, so even after years of 180-degree snapshots in Quake, I somehow still managed to get a headache.So when I realized that I could be playing Deadly Premonition instead, I uninstalled this thing.

content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												Alan Wake should garner many positive reviews that will focus on the story and its "unusual" presentation and style. Know this; it would make an excellent book or movie. The problem is that even the best novel can be turned into a bad video game and that is essentially what has happened here.The story unfolds over the course of 20 hours as you run from one well lit area to the next, fighting waves of the exact same 4 monsters, using the exact same 4 weapons and the exact same strategy all the way to the end. The Enemy AI is rudimentary. The soundtrack is non-existent. Alan Wake will occasionally narrate and explain a new revelation, or what he is feeling or what you need to do next.The game lacks tradition incentives to keep you playing. There are no choices, no dialogue trees, no weapon upgrades, and no level-ups. Even Alan Wakes own survival is tied to the plot and thus never seems to be in question. The game thrusts you into the action without spending sufficient time on character development and then tells you that you need to do X, Y and Z if you wish to save various people you don't care about. This might work in a book or movie were we are simply spectators along for the ride, but it is asking a lot in a game where players must invest 20 hours of their own time to progress the story. I constantly found myself asking the question, "Do I really care about these people? Do I even care what happens to Alan Wake? Why do I need a key to open this door when I have a shotgun in my hand?" As a result, it is easy to lose interest. This might be one of the few games that you will have on your plate that you have to force yourself to finish.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												As I sit here considering how best to describe Alan Wake, the image that springs to mind was Lenoidas' final moments in the film 300: standing there in a captivating environment, looking pretty right up until he is swiftly cut down by an inescapable tidal wave of several thousand arrows...**************I have not made the acquaintance of anyone at Remedy games, yet I am certain not a single employee is familiar with the concept of "subtlety," or at least how to execute it successfully. This game is a fire-hose of pop culture references – Twin Peaks homages being the most egregious – and nearly every last one of them is clumsily implemented. The story has some intriguing elements regarding the themes of creation and the internal conflict that inevitably arises within the creator(s); however, it's executed in a fairly uneven manner that seems more interested in playing the mysterious "is it all real or in Alan's head" angle, and lacks a resonant through-line of a vastly superior title such as Silent Hill 2. The controls are also disappointingly loose, and the resultant gameplay is sloppy. Such issues are commonplace among survival horror games, often defended as "enhancing the tension" among apologists; yet loose controls need not be antithetical to good gameplay, as other survival horror entries such as Amnesia: Dark Descent ably demonstrate. There are plenty of moments in Alan Wake with ample tension that are not aided in the slightest by the easily-exhausted sprint function or the awkward aiming and character movements. Nor does it help matters that the jump function works about a tenth as well as it should; though, as luck would have it, this does nothing to stop Remedy from tossing in a number of platforming-based segments that wonderfully illustrate the blundering majesty of the game's physics engine. And on top of it all, the game is absolutely obsessed with speed ramping (THERE's that 300 connection) and wresting control of the camera away from the player to show you something any time it feels bored with what's happening in the game, which is all the time. This obsession with fashioning the game in a cinematic vein is incredibly detrimental to both the gameplay and the overall experience. I don’t need to be shown with an elaborate zoom that there is a threat looming ahead; I can already see it because it is directly in front of my f*cking face, obstructing my forward progress.The world of Alan Wake is indeed an impressive one to behold and explore. It’s just too bad it’s tanked by clunky gameplay, ham-fisted dialogue and story, and all-too-knowing references. (Maybe don’t start the next game off by name-dropping Stephen King in the opening seconds.)(4/10)

In most action games, the shooting is broken up by a large weapon and combat variety or different kinds of gameplay brought into the mix, such as platforming or puzzle solving. The weapon variety is non-existant, you've got a gun, a shotgun, a rifle, grenades and that's about it. And the puzzles are normally so simple that you'd rather go back to just shooting things. You'll come across many obstacles too and the jumping button just doesn't handle any of them rather well.TL;DR Engrossing Narrative, Poor and Tedious Game Mechanics.

												Alan Wake was mediocre.Edit: Gonna flesh out this review, because I think it'd help if I was more descriptive.Alan Wake is a fully functional horror game, that is creepy for about the first 5 hours of Stephen King aping. content:
Posted: November 8, 2014
												I remember when the game was first announced and had me eagerly waiting only to be let down by the X360 exclusive release of 2010. Being disappointed by Microsoft's decision I kept my distance from that version in hopes of a later PC release, which eventually happened after two years. Even though I didn't get my hands on it until 2014, having read the overwhemingly positive reviews from both users and critics, my expectations were still high.To me a good game is a game that you feel like playing again shortly after you've finished it. Unfortunately, this was not the case with Alan Wake. It's not like the game was a disaster but, given my expectations, I found it to be a rather mediocre title.The story is compelling and well-thought but it failed to get a grip on me faster than the dull and unimaginative gameplay got me bored. The mechanics are repetitive and the level design pretty straight forward. You don't get much of a variety of weapons to defend yourself and the enemies can be dealt with in one and only way. Aim flashlight, wait for the darkness to weaken then shoot. You get to solve a few puzzles every now and then but they never become much of a challenge. Most of the time you'll spend in game you'll be wandering around the woods of Bright Falls at night. The atmosphere is ominous and dark but it's not really frightening. Some times the darkness will overwhelm the player, forcing him to run for his life, but in my case it didn't feel scary as much as it felt frustrating. And speaking of frustrating, I have to mention the few sections of the game where the player has to get in a car, in order to cover the distance, which were absolutely horrendous. The vehicles' handling was pretty much terrible and no fun at all. On the bright side, broken into 6 episodes, the game's story unfolds in an interesting way and with nice pacing although the shallow gameplay makes getting from point A to point B feel like an eternity. The characters have depth and the voice acting is excellent although I could not develope any kind of sympathy for Alan for whatever reasons. Maybe it's just me. Aside from the storyline, a strong point of Alan Wake was the sound and music which were perfectly tailored for the game's setting.Overall, the game was a sour experience and I can not recommend it. I'd give it a 5 out of 10 at best.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												I was gripped by Alan Wake's presentation during the first hour of playing: gorgeous but ominous scenery of remote mountain-top villages hiding secrets that disturb the senses, psychological horror narrative that plays with perception and a sensitive inspiration from Stephen King's works and Twin Peaks that was well-thought and in good taste.But then the game drowned itself in a sea of subpar shooter gameplay.Warily, dreading the unwelcome diversion from a story I had just taken a liking for, I trudged on through the countless identical encounters. It can't be long, I thought, it's just an early combat level to satisfy the shooter crowd and then I'll get back to the good parts. It's not that bad, maybe I'll be able to avoid most of the encounters if I try - and just look at the pretty scenery oooh. Three hours later I was still in the forest repeating mandatory shootouts while slowly forgetting what Alan had seen or was trying to achieve in his arc. With sadness I had to contend that I would need to abandon Alan Wake to the forgotten part of my Steam library, its secrets forever unexplored. Maybe I should recommend this game to people who are bigger fans of action-shooter genre games. There might be moments in life when I can enjoy a shooter, maybe even one as clunky and dull as the parts I mention in this game. However, the mindset that one must be in when I desire to play Alan Wake - a mindset so tastefully enhanced and sustained during the exploratory/narrative segments of the game- is so dissonant from the mindset of generic shooting, that I feel it doesn't let one enjoy either aspect. Story detracts from gameplay and vice versa. Such a shame that one cannot turn the combat off.

												6/10Alan Wake is the sort of game that will be a cult classic, but isn't good enough to be recommended to anyone but hardcore fans as there are too many things wrong with it.Shonky camera, Wake will never run forward or backwards properly but slanted to one side. It's made worse because they keep sticking you in mountainous forests instead of anywhere interesting.Alan Wake isn't a very scary game eitherSo, what is good? Great graphics/visuals, I really liked the soundtrack and environment, combined it all does a great job of making you feel like you're in a small northwestern American town. I liked the driving physics also, very realistic and accurate (only downside is console controls making them a bit hard to drive).Story is pretty good and interesting if you can endure the long time in between with combat and hiking through forests to the next objective.Overall, good story, would have been MUCH better as an open world game and the many forest hiking levels needed to be 30% smaller and not filled with so much ♥♥♥♥♥♥ boring combat. Limited replayability. Maybe just watch an LP and save yourself the 10 hours of un-fun combat.

So you might ask why did it take over 16 months to finish? Was it because I was super busy with life? No, not especially as I can always find a few hours during the week. Was it because there are other games that took up my time. Yes, but not because I valued them over good old Alan. You see it took me only about 2 minutes of the game to realize that this would be a struggle the likes of which have rarely been seen outside of Star Wars. To begin, 3rd person games have difficulty with their camera controls most of the time. Alan took this to the extreme with its constant cut scenes which change the angle and expect you to turn and adjust within half a second of regaining control. The camera control improves when the game gives you access to vehicles. Mostly because the camera becomes static and you're too busy struggling with the driving controls of the cars.But the thing that caused me to quit playing the game 4 times was the decision to give Alan the stamina of a 400 lbs 70 y/o grandma. Some of the fun of a game is finding your own way to solve the puzzles, or to deal with the boss fights. But with Alan Wake you were forced time and again to have to kill every single bad guy, every single time to progress. So why did they limit your character with such abismal stamina? Was it staying true to the setting? "Alan is a writer, he won't be in very good shape" Maybe, however, you'd think that in an scenario where your wife has been taken and weird shadow-ie things are chasing your with axes you'd be able to sprint more than 10 feet. I'm in pretty lousy shape most of the time, but the two times a year where I attempt to start an exercise routine I am able to run 5 or 6 blocks before I collapse. Were the developers trying to give the player a better experience with the limited stamina? Maybe, but there were so many other issues: camera, driving, dodging mechanics, overly exact looting, etc that made the game difficult to enjoy why would they waste their time on stamina?So, was anything in Alan Wake done right? Yes, the cinematics were great, the character modling was awesome. The story was fresh and interesting. I particularly enjoyed the sweeping camera shots and the seeing the layout of the city. Excellent framework for a game, I just wish they had put in a few more weeks work to tighten up all the shoddy bits.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												(Spoiler free review)The first couple hours of this game were great. The story was interesting, there were a bunch of twists and turns, and the environments were decently varied.I am now 7 hours into the game and find myself having trouble just staying awake while playing this game.It's become the game equivalent of an iTunes preview of a nursery rhyme stuck on loop.Pros:- Interesting story (at the beginning)- Graphics are nice, with forest areas looking especially good.Cons:- One of those games that isn't hard so to speak, but you find yourself dying constantly- Almost always taking place at night, in a forest, with blue color grading- Some plot explanations are weak and overly simple- One  of those games that tries to be both a TV show and a game at the same time, while completely misunderstanding the purpose of each medium and why they should never be "combined".- Game treats you like a complete idiot with "hints" to help guide you across completely linear paths in an almost insulting manner- Alan explains every bit of environmental story-telling you come across- Fighting possessed objects by shining a light at them... why- Practically impossible to run from any combat scenario (don't run out of bullets)- Enemies that throw hammers at the speed of sound- Clunky driving segments- Combat that is tedious, repetetive, and unsatisfying- 95% of combat encounters begin with a "spooky" chord and the camera moving to show you a group of the same 3 guys you fight throughout the whole game advancing on your position- Alan's manager guy is commonly found saying things that directly conflict with the current mood- Incredible amounts of walking in straight lines through blue forests- Enemies that are supposed to be scary say the dumbest♥♥♥♥♥♥sometimes- Unlike the beginning, the plot later begins to slow down almost to a hault, making it hard to be driven by the story to continue- If using mouse/keyboard, camera always stays to one side of Alan (good), but if using controller, camera is not locked to a specific side and moves between sides as you turn the camera (bad)- Puzzles are just easy time wasters- Lots of custscenes- Game dumps exposition about the town on you, which would be fine if the information mattered and wasn't just filler- Alan talks to himself CONSTANTLYOverall I'd say the game is highly overrated and there are much better alternatives.It's not the worst game I've ever played, but certaintly the most boring.

content:
Posted: June 15, 2014
												A very late review, game came out in 2012, only now am I reviewing it in 2014, and even then it has been several months since I got the game, but I still wanted to get my opinion across. This game showed promise, a very cool idea that is for once truly original, I really can't think of any other games like it.Unfortunately, this is where the praise ends. First, let's take a look at what the game is. How do we categorize it? In which genre does it belong in? What games does it have to measure up to? The most touted response is horror, some even have the nerve to claim its psychological horror, the type of horror I view in very high regard because a lot of thought and effort has to actually go into a game to achieve that. My reply? No. A straight no.Anyone can tell this game wants to be a horror game, it tries so hard, and yet this dream gets shot down by one glaring fault, narration. Seriously? I won't even go into how obnoxious the main character is, because it doesn't even matter. Imagine you being in a dark forest, creepy noises everywhere, the tension builds up, you know something is watching you, it could come at you at any moment now, AND THEN? ahhhhh, the soothing voice of Mr.  Alan Wake the main character that you are playing telling you exactly what is going on at this moment. My god, if they really had to force narration into this game, then this was the worse way they could have possibly went about it. To put it simply, how am I supposed to feel scared, when even the main character feels so detached from his own universe?So this game tries to be, but is not horror, then what about Survival? These 2 genres go hand in hand so much these days its getting harder to find a game that's actually not both at the same time. Once again, Alan Wake tries, but fails, to nail the survival aspect. Now before I go further, know this, I played on normal difficulty, which is the default setting and the intended difficulty for the player to receive the full experience, so don't go calling me out for not playing a harder setting if you disagree with me, normal is the default, and it shall be judged as such, if the game cannot even provide its full experience in the default difficulty setting, then it simply fails as a game.With that out of the way, does this game nail survival? No. That's another straight no. How do I tell? You might wonder. Well there are several ways. FIrst of these would be supply scarcity, are the things you need to survive hard to find? Or found in barely sufficient amounts? No they aren't, once again I stress that I play in normal difficulty, the default setting, and in this setting the game bombards you with supplies. Only during the beginning of levels (or episodes if you prefer the in game term) do you actually feel pressured by your lack of inventory, this doesn't say anything good about the game at all, given that all survival based games start the same way, its how long the game manages to drag this feeling across your playthrough that really matters, and Alan Wake fails miserably at that. Have a big fight ahead? You can be sure you will find enough ammo to destroy every single enemy in your way, SOMETIMES RIGHT BEFORE THE FIGHT ITSELF! In fact this becomes quite an accurate way of gauging what's around the next corner. Oh I just found a shotgun, 3 boxes of ammo for it, 2 boxes of revolver ammo, 3 stacks of batteries, and a flare gun with 2 extra rounds of ammo for it? All in the same shed? DING DING! Tough fight ahead. The game does try to solve this issue, but not by limiting your supplies as you would expect, instead it wipes your inventory after every single episode! Now I can understand this from a plot standpoint, you won't exactly be able to carry all your weapons into a sheriff's office/ through a car crash and come out without losing them, but more often than not it just doesn't make sense that Alan would ditch everything he just acquired, even a perfectly normal flashlight, especially when he is so self aware about what he is going through, and knows exactly what he needs to survive, that being light and weapons.But survival isn't just about the above, it also has to be coupled by a feeling of helplessness, afterall, if your character can rambo and falcon punch his way through enemies, then all the (lack of) supplies in the world wouldn't matter at all would it? Alan Wake nails this part down, unfortunately though, it hammers the nail in so hard that it completely smashes the wood apart. Your character can be likened to an obese chain smoker who just recovered from heart surgery, seriously he can't run more than a few feet before he starts gasping for air. Now you can argue that this adds to the challenge, the "survival" aspect. Really? Does Mr. Wake not have a chemical in his body known as adrenaline? It completely breaks the willing suspension of disbelief when a character who is supposedly being chased down by bloodthirsty phantoms can't run for his life for more than a few steps at a time, this isn't survival, this is frustration! Other than that, the level of finesse displayed by Alan's other movements are close to what you'd expect from a writer who's been shutting himself in and lacks physical exercise, almost too close, but I won't nitpick further.I don't think this game can really fit into any other genres besides the ones I have mentioned, so I believe it is safe to say that because the game has failed miserably at achieving what it was going for, that the gameplay is a failure and the only saving grace is the story (which is what most fans ask you to focus on when you play this game anyway). Whether this does it for you or not is purely subjective, so I can't comment much, you can obviously tell I didn't find it good enough though, besides, if you only want to tell a story, please remain as a book or film, don't try to be what you're not. What I can say about the story though, is that Alan Wake follows what I like to call the Souls style of story telling. What this means is that you only get the general idea of the story through scripted exposition, the rest of it (required if you really want to make sense of everything that is going on) can only be found through finding particular objects in game, much like the Souls series or games like Bastion. Where this game goes wrong though, is that instead of finding interesting objects, and piecing together what the clues or flavor text on them are trying to tell you, Alan wake has you finding more than 100 sheets of the same sheet of paper, I get that he's a writer, but I don't think I need to clarify on how boring this is. To make things worse, whereas most items in other games have their own self contained story about the world to tell, this game literally spreads its story across 100 puzzle pieces, which are completely missable to boot. If the game had other things going for it, this wouldn't matter, but with the story and plot being the final saving grace? No.. just no.Edit:A revision to the final Paragraph:It seems through closer examination and reviweing that I wasn't completely accurate about manuscript pages. The actual idea behind manuscipt pages was actually a sort of neat little device where you could read about what would happen to you in the very immediate future from pages strewn around the place. I had thought that these notes were intergral to the plot, but it seems they actually really have little correlation to the story at all.Why did I make such a mistake, well it was because I got the impression that these notes formed a story, integral to the plot, and when I found them seperately and they each revealed nothing important when pieced together, I just stopped reading them altogether. Turns out this was actually good for me, because imagine if I had figured out very early that I could read almost EXACTLY what I would encounter later in a SURVIVAL/HORROR game. Further explanation not required.

Posted: August 6, 2014
												Having heard so many good things about this game, I was certainly hopeful going in.  However, despite doing a decent job as a thriller/horror experience, the almost unbelievably tedious and clunky combat mechanics had me calling it quits after just a few chapters.  Combat isn't even that hard per say, but its semi-broken targeting system, awkward movement and dodging, and its extreme repetition in terms of enemies and tactics required really drags everything down into frustrating tedium.  I think this game would have actually been a lot better with little to no traditional combat, and instead focusing its action sequences on more of a fearful avoidance of baddies and environmental dangers (e.g., the Amnesia games).  That would have allowed it to spend more time on conveying a compelling and harrowing tale through more of the things it pulls off well: frightful tension and suspense, fearful dreamscapes and flashbacks, and gradually unravelling the mysteries of whatever dark forces are terrorizing Alan, his wife, and the inhabitants of the formerly cozy backwater.The mysterious darkness and its seeming relation to Alan's own writing was an interesting concept that I would have otherwise wanted to see taken to its logical conclusion, but it was also really hard to empathize and become invested in Alan as a character since, to be frank, he is consistently painted as a self-absorbed jerk.  In general, if you're willing to suffer through the terribad combat elements, this game is probably worth your time; but if not, then you might want to look elsewhere for something that gets story AND combat right.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												It did not take me long to decide this game was a mistake, and that is a shame for a game with so much potential. On the plus side, visually this game is a masterpiece. As someone who lives in the Northwest from which I understand this game's environment was inspired I must say I have never seen a video game so wonderfully depict the foggy coastal forested mountain atmosphere. At night the moonlit creepiness fits the mood of the game to perfection and creates a memorable gaming experience.Also, I found the plot to be refreshingly unique as it followed the fate of a writer who found himself living out the disturbing pages of a book which he hadn't even written yet.Unfortunately, that is where its good points end. The plot of this game may be unique, but it was executed horribly. Starting the game out in the middle of a nightmare after a car accident with little or no backstory to soften the blow was actually a cleaver move I thought, but once the story gets properly underway being suddenly and inexplicably torn out of it to go through another nightmare following a car crash resulting in a desperate nighttime escape through a dark wood (almost) precisely like the first starts to feel a bit forced if not outright contrived. I began to wonder if the whole story wasn't going to be a series of excuses to throw the user into yet another moonlit escapade trying not to get killed by axe-wielding phantoms in a dark wood. In fairness, the game is a horror-fantasy adventure, but even so I did expect to have a bit more of a structured plot to hold it together. Perhaps with more patience it would have gotten better in this respect, but I was turned-off too quickly and too thoroughly to find out.And no, it wasn't just for that one reason. In fact that was the smaller of my issues with the game. The larger issue was the cripplingly awful nature of the combat. During these creepy wanderings through the woods running into phantoms trying to kill me with axes was an inevitable occurance. When it was just one, this could actually result in a rather exciting and heart-pumping experience that really completed the game's horror feel. However when there were several it started to feel quite tiresome. I would often enough find myself running out of battery power before my foes were defeated. Dodging requires skill (which is nice) but becomes fairly impractical when there's more than one opponent coming at you. Killing them before they can close the distance and overwhelm you means burning batteries and once your run out it's just over. No, you can't outrun them so don't even bother. A shame really, considering a tense chase scene through the woods would only add to the horror feel of the game. It might also give you the chance to flee to a more lit location, such as the occasional streetlamps you find along the way, and avoid your impending doom. No such luck. It gets especially idiotic when in order to get power to the area light you first need to kill all the phantoms so that you can start up the generator without getting mauled. Of course if you've killed all the phantoms you don't need the area light any more... Thanks game designers. No there's no need to turn it on for later, since as I mentioned you can't outrun the beasts so there's no leading them away or fleeing to safety.You'll find the occasional puzzle in the game, such as moving cranes in order to create a log walkway to get access to the next part of the map, but they're all fairly simplistic and feel almost out of place and superfluous in what is clearly not a puzzle game.All in all it felt like a poorly implemented horror first-person shooter. Perhaps my greatest lament is that I can't simply turn off the phantom zombies and simply enjoy the gorgeous ambiance and brilliantly rendered environments. They're almost worth the purchase price by themselves.

												The story is very interesting but the gameplay leaves much to be desired. It's incredibly linear in the sense that 90% of the time you are just following a path in the woods while you shine your flashlight on enemies and finish them off with your gun. content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												It did not take me long to decide this game was a mistake, and that is a shame for a game with so much potential. On the plus side, visually this game is a masterpiece. As someone who lives in the Northwest from which I understand this game's environment was inspired I must say I have never seen a video game so wonderfully depict the foggy coastal forested mountain atmosphere. At night the moonlit creepiness fits the mood of the game to perfection and creates a memorable gaming experience.Also, I found the plot to be refreshingly unique as it followed the fate of a writer who found himself living out the disturbing pages of a book which he hadn't even written yet.Unfortunately, that is where its good points end. The plot of this game may be unique, but it was executed horribly. Starting the game out in the middle of a nightmare after a car accident with little or no backstory to soften the blow was actually a cleaver move I thought, but once the story gets properly underway being suddenly and inexplicably torn out of it to go through another nightmare following a car crash resulting in a desperate nighttime escape through a dark wood (almost) precisely like the first starts to feel a bit forced if not outright contrived. I began to wonder if the whole story wasn't going to be a series of excuses to throw the user into yet another moonlit escapade trying not to get killed by axe-wielding phantoms in a dark wood. In fairness, the game is a horror-fantasy adventure, but even so I did expect to have a bit more of a structured plot to hold it together. Perhaps with more patience it would have gotten better in this respect, but I was turned-off too quickly and too thoroughly to find out.And no, it wasn't just for that one reason. In fact that was the smaller of my issues with the game. The larger issue was the cripplingly awful nature of the combat. During these creepy wanderings through the woods running into phantoms trying to kill me with axes was an inevitable occurance. When it was just one, this could actually result in a rather exciting and heart-pumping experience that really completed the game's horror feel. However when there were several it started to feel quite tiresome. I would often enough find myself running out of battery power before my foes were defeated. Dodging requires skill (which is nice) but becomes fairly impractical when there's more than one opponent coming at you. Killing them before they can close the distance and overwhelm you means burning batteries and once your run out it's just over. No, you can't outrun them so don't even bother. A shame really, considering a tense chase scene through the woods would only add to the horror feel of the game. It might also give you the chance to flee to a more lit location, such as the occasional streetlamps you find along the way, and avoid your impending doom. No such luck. It gets especially idiotic when in order to get power to the area light you first need to kill all the phantoms so that you can start up the generator without getting mauled. Of course if you've killed all the phantoms you don't need the area light any more... Thanks game designers. No there's no need to turn it on for later, since as I mentioned you can't outrun the beasts so there's no leading them away or fleeing to safety.You'll find the occasional puzzle in the game, such as moving cranes in order to create a log walkway to get access to the next part of the map, but they're all fairly simplistic and feel almost out of place and superfluous in what is clearly not a puzzle game.All in all it felt like a poorly implemented horror first-person shooter. Perhaps my greatest lament is that I can't simply turn off the phantom zombies and simply enjoy the gorgeous ambiance and brilliantly rendered environments. They're almost worth the purchase price by themselves.

												Since there's a character limit (I wish it was removed)... what did I like and what did I hate about Alan Wake ?Well, I hated the story, it was told in a way that didn't make any sense to me and it was far-fetched, really far-fetched. I love mystery movies and shows (Twin Peaks, Mulholland Drive, The Twilight Zone) but Alan Wake just didn't do it for me. Sorry, I can't help it. The idea of using chapters was cool though.The graphics were pretty, real pretty (except for the faces) and the lighting in this game is wonderful. Really well done. Same goes for the voice overs and sounds in general.The gameplay itself is easy and simple. Literally. All you do is press switches, light things up and shoot them. It became boring halfway through. The driving segments didn't help either, since the cars themself drive horribly. The action is still enjoyable if you mix things up, say, trying to get as many Taken together and blowing them up with a grenade. It's up to the player.[Rating: 77/100]

Posted: October 2, 2016
												Ohhhh boy. I bought this back on the 360  when it first came out because it looked/sounded amazing.I recently retried it on PC remembering "Wow, that game was awesome, I'll try it again!".It was not awesome. The graphics are alright, though some weird animations and perhaps slightly less than desirable performance for a game this old. No where near unplayable though. The gameplay is decent, a bit easy perhaps and some weird controls (dodge is mapped to the run key, so when you start to sprint you always dodge first).The biggest problem is the voice acting. The voice acting is SO bad. It was fine for that era, but holy hell this game trying to be creepy is honestly giving me second hand embrassment. It's far more hilarious than scary. Some of the characters sound alright, but between the dated awkward visuals and the bad voice acting- them trying to mimic a Stephen King movie does not work.I love the concept, and if you can SERIOUSLY look past how bad this game has aged, then give it a go. But to be honest unless you've missed out on video games over the past 10 years I don't see how you can ignore how bad this is to enjoy the story/atmosphere.
